Pretty darn good but  not earth shattering.  We showed up around 5:00 pm before the rush.  Parking was available and pizza came out pretty fast.  I think our server forgot about us as we sat there for about 20 minutes waiting for the check.  I'd try it again though.

Best deep dish pizza I've had. The sauce and the crust were equally delicious. One of the toppings we ordered was with garlic and it was a lot of garlic! We ordered their buffalo and bbq wings and the bbq sauce was amazing!
Dont get the personal pepperoni pizza. It's very impersonal. Very much lacking in cheese and flavor. Deep dish more like fake dish.  Good service though.

Well.  This is my second time here.  First with the wife and now with the boys.  I love the deep dish.  What a relaxed place and good environment.  Pizza takes 50 min.  But if you relax and have good people to chat with, it's all good.

I was in Chicago for a business trip and wanted to try some Chicago style pizza.  Our Uber driver told us Pequod's was the place and he was right.  I love good pizza and this may have actually been the best Pizza I have ever had.  If you are in Chicago and have the time (45 min wait for us) it is worth it!

Always great, and always worth the wait.  Pequod's is, in my book, serves the best pizza in the city of Chicago. If you plan on coming though, know that during peak hours will could easily have an hour or more wait until you get seated, and then another 40 minutes to an hour before you get your pizza (not because they are slow, but because the deep-ish dish pizzas they serve take a long time to make).  The bar has a good selection of beer, and the service is always friendly.  On my most recent visit, about 2 weeks ago, we learned that the owners of Pequod's had opened a bar next door called Whale Tale. The great thing about that place is is that when you put your name in for a seat at Pequod's, your buzzer will work next door at Whale Tale. The people over there know that you are most likely there waiting for a table, and so the service is appropriately fast.  Back to Pequod's though. Sure, ambiance-wise, it's a Blackhawks bar, but the pizza is the star of the show. Their pizza is, like I said before, deep-ish dish. I usually describe it as like a halfway deep dish. Pizzas are made in cast iron skillets and there is a layer of cheese baked in underneath and around the crust giving it a perfect, crunchy, parmesan seasoning all the way around. To me that is the best part. Pizza topping selections are plentiful, and they are not shy about loading them up onto the pizza.  I've never had a bad experience here, but there was only one time that I was here that I didn't have to wait less than an hour for a table (I think it was the middle of the afternoon for some reason).  I can not recommend this pizza enough. You should also note that they do have priority seating that you can access and set up from home before you venture out and take your chances with the wait time. That is definitely worth looking into.

My now husband and I knew we were meant to be when we determined our favorite Chicago pizza was undoubtedly Pequod's. When faced with the decision of where to have our rehearsal dinner last February, the solution was a no-brainer. The evening of the rehearsal dinner went perfectly. Their upstairs private party room is a little tight, but it was cozy, intimate and casual - just what we were looking for. The service was awesome. As a type-A bride-to-be, I have to say the only negative was their lack of traditional planning/coordination. We "booked" our event about 9 months out with an email from Pequod's saying, "You got it, the date is yours." We didn't sign a contract or put any money down, which felt different from the other vendors we booked. Regardless, after I allowed myself to trust in their process, we followed up with them a few times leading up to the event and they were warm, kind, and accommodating when we wanted to come tour the space. Would recommending hosting an intimate event here! And this goes without saying at this point - there pizza trumps all.
I'm a thin crust fan but Pequods is my favorite deeper dish. The wait is long but the pizza is worth it.

I have friends that enjoy it here so I tried it out twice and just not impressed. I wanted to like it but service was rude both times and I'm just not impressed with the pizza. So much sauce...just not a good balance for me. On a positive note it is a convenient place to stop before a mid-day movie.

This was my 2nd time dining in. Service was great staff is very polite. It was my surprise for my Hubby. It was our 10year anniversary. I was able to enjoy the thin crust pizza. They said it would be able 45 minute to wait on the pizza to come out. They served us in 20 minutes. We were pleased.
Great Pizza, use lots of napkins, as it can get messy. Burnt cheese crust is a nice touch

Its a bit of a throw down with Chicago deep dish between Pequods and Lou's Personally we feel that Pequods has tastier and more plentiful toppings. As some folks may have seen in our other posts we are into thin crust better. However when we get the chance we certainly try to frequent Pequods.

We had waited over an hour for seating our group of 7... they do not take resv, walk in only.  The pizza pies were incredible!! The only thing was they had recommended 3 pies for our party and we only finished 2.  Trust me ... we tried! It was very cheesy and tasty!!

After asking everyone we encountered for a pizza recommendation we ended up here.... apparently this is where the locals go! The restaurant has 2 floors and nothing out of this world in terms of appearance. Staff was very nice, we ordered their deep dish Supreme. The pizza was good but if I was to go again I would stick to just plain cheese or pepperoni as I think the combination of the sauce and toppings was overwhelming but tasty nonetheless. The garlic cheese bread is highly recommended. I have a good overall experience and would recommend.
Pequods....... Love love love your pizza!.The best in the city. Whats up with the service. Our pizza was cold, our bartender she didn't even care. Still love you!

Recommended to me as the only deep dish Chicagoans actually eat and can see why. The caramelized crust lives up to all the rave reviews, tomato sauce is not too sweet and cheese is just enough. Put your name down, grab a buzzer and have a cocktail next door at Drinking Bird.
Chicago city staple. Not the traditional deep dish but still amazing. Has been featured on many food channels.
Whoever answers the phone for late night delivery is a total butthole. Cool customer service guys.

Pequod's is a Bar that serves Pizza. Plain and simple. It is a very specific kind of Chicago pizza (you won't have to search very hard for the pictures) that incorporates a very airy dough, tall (deep-dish) execution, crispy-crunchy edges, and not a whole lot of cheese on top. As far as the setting, Pequod's looks and feels like a dive bar. Fortunately for Pequod, it is a good dive bar and it does what it does very well.  I got what I came for, and didn't really expect anything different. It is a solid place if you want to go throw a few back and eat some pizza with friends. Honest (and very likely unpopular to many) opinion? The pizza isn't anything to write home about. It's good enough, but you have to really want this kind of pizza, else you'll be disappointed.  The bartenders and servers I encountered were friendly, helpful, and swift. Service was great and I had a great time. If I were in Chicago again I'd probably try someone else's take on the indigenous pizza, but Pequod's is a good choice for those seeking the experience.

Came here saturday night around 6 PM and this place was paaaacked. Wait to dine in was an hour and then another 1.5 hour for your pizza to be made. We made an executive decision to carry out so we could eat faster hehe We ordered a small with mushrooms and then went across the street to Kibbitznest (which you should totally do if you have a long wait because that place is awesome). It took a little longer than what they quoted us so when we went back they surprised us with a large pizza woooooop  Took it home and devoured it. Personally i'm a thin crust fan (east coast represent) so I'm generally suspicious of deep dish. But I was surprised they actually had a decent amount of sauce unlike other deep dish I've had. Mushrooms were really good and the cheese crust was phenomenal. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was how dry the bread is. But all in all, would come back for this lunch special I hear so much about.

Friendly greeting upon arrival, got there early enough that the wait time was only 15 minutes. Started with the cheese sticks, they were good and served their purpose, take the edge off while waiting for our pizza. Ordered a deep dish with sausage, onion and green pepper. It was very good, but it could have used more cheese. Overall it's a great pizza with a unique flavor.

I called 5 minutes before I arrived with small kids and told there was no wait. After parking and walking in I was told it was a 30 minute wait. The only excuse I got from the front desk was that someone else answered the phone and didn't ask them about wait times.  I thought this was a show of bad service. I have eaten here before and food is typically good so I gave it two stars.  Came back another time. Wait for 30 minutes for a table which I knew about and was fine but pizza wait is another 60 minutes after you sit which seems crazy. After sitting and waiting 30 minutes, was told that pizza wait is not up to 90 minutes.  Pizza came and was under cooked and definitely not worth my 2 hour wait. Downgrading to one star.

Toppings,Cheese and Sauce very delicious really make the pizza more than decent, the crust tasted super buttery which wasn't the best combination with pizza but ok. The atmosphere was hectic due to Hawks game that was going on. Will definitely visit a quieter time next time.

I am so disappointed. Pequod's is one of my favorite deep dish pizzas. But they totally disappointed us tonight. My husband calls and orders for pick up a large sausage and onion pizza. They say it'll take an 1.5 hour. Ok, we'll do it because we want pequods. Husband gets there a little earlier, gets the pizza, and IT'S THE WRONG ORDER. They tell him to make a new one would take another 45 mins. He decides to just take the wrong pizza cause it's past 9pm and we're hungry. They give him a gift card and he leaves. We are now eating cold pizza at 9:35pm. I checked the balance on the gift card. It had a previous balance of $25. It now has $5.  Terrible customer service.

Not my choice. Was looking at comparing Chicago style pizzas and this was so bready, like Pizza Hut deep dish on steroids. Flavor was good but we got extra cheese and I was just scraping the topping to eat with a smidge of the crust. Won't go back! Think Giordanos and Lou's is hands down better!

This is as good as it gets. It'll be busy, but my group of three saw an opening at the bar and went for it.  The bartender was quick to serve us, and always checked in on us.  It was an early afternoon, so we just wanted pizza.   Every bite is fantastic, and I savored for the crust at the end.  Seriously, one of the best pizzas I've ever had. It's very filling.  The 14-inch pizza was too big for the three of us, and this includes two with huge appetites.
better than Giordanos!! yummy deep dish pizza with caramel crust and we ordered wings as well as raviolli which were equally yummy! :D

A couple of servers at Alinea recommended this place, so I had high expectations.  There's barely any cheese. The crust is about 7/8 of the pizza, the sausage wasn't fully cooked and it's burnt to a crisp.  Possibly the worst pizza I've had in Chicago. I'd rather eat 10 pies from horrible Giordano's than one slice of this trash. Dominoes would be a massive improvement.

Best deep dish in Chicago, no doubt. My only complaint is that the pies can sometimes be a little inconsistent and on occasion the cheese-to-bread ratio gets out of whack. I generally solve that by always ordering extra cheese with my pepperoni pie. The pizza is better when you dine in, no question, but the delivery is still enjoyable as long as you don't let it sit. Reheat in the oven, not in the microwave, natch.

Came here once as it came highly recommended.  I'd say it's my second favorite deep dish to Lou's.  Had to get extra sauce which I'd recommend to break the huge amount of cheese on the pie.  We waited probably an hour before we were able to get some bar seats which was fine.  I'd go back, but not worth waiting a long time.

I heard good things about this place. So we decided to order take out. We had 9 pickup orders, mostly personal pans and one was incorrect. I feel that you'd have to eat there for the full experience, but the lady through the phone order was quite short with me. The pizza was alright overall, but service was only satisfactory. Parking is abysmal in this area.

There was so much hype about Pequod's Pizzeria that my husband, a friend, and I finally checked it out. It was extraordinarily busy, but we were seated quite quickly. The service was also prompt despite the norm of having to wait 45 minutes for a stuffed pizza at any establishment. Our server kept appetizers and drinks coming while we waited. The pizza was good. Was it as good as my favorite Chicago stuffed pizza? No, it wasn't quite that good in my opinion. Nevertheless, Pequod's offers a very solid Chicago style pie that everyone should check out at least once.

Pequod's was my first crack at authentic Chicago style pizza in Chicago. In fact, it was the very first stop we made upon arrival into the Windy City and it certainly did not disappoint.  Their specialty is the "caramelized crust" edge on their pan style pizzas. The cheese was oozing out onto the side of crust and it was full of cheesy goodness. This is how they differentiate themselves from the competition and they execute it very well. We got a large sausage and pepperoni deep dish which was essentially a meat lovers pizza. Each bite was bursting of flavor and left us completely stuffed at the end. The only issue I had was that it was too crusty for my liking. I prefer a traditional deep dish that's not as doughy but that's just a matter of preference. The ingredients here were fresh, they don't used canned tomatoes which is splendid.  As with all authentic Chicago style pizzas, the waiting time will be long since they have to bake the crust to a nice golden brown.  Getting the buffalo wings as appetizers in the meantime is a solid move. They were delicious and it certainly made the wait for the pizza more bearable by chowing down some delicious wings. They have a good selection of craft beers too which is nice. As a few people in our group were San Diegans, we had to go with a pitcher of our beloved Ballast Point Sculpin.  Service was friendly and efficient as well. We were there until past closing at 2am and they did not rush to kick us out. They provided prompt and courteous service even though we were literally the last customers of the night.  Overall, Pequod's definitely earns their reputation as being one of the finest deep dish pizzerias in Chicago. Although I prefer Lou Manati's, I am not at all surprised that many people have Pequod's ranked as the king of Chicago deep dish.

The atmosphere: We got here before the rush on a Friday evening (around 6pm) so I can't complain about the wait, but shortly after it got very busy. All the take out order individuals cram into the small space which is uncomfortable for the seated patrons.  The pizza: Dry (almost burnt) crust. Like everyone else says, the ratio of bread to everything else on the pizza is too much. The cheese is very stringy and you feel like you have to chew each bite for ten minutes so you don't choke on it. For all the toppings I ordered there was zero flavor, where's the seasoning?  I've definitely had better and I wouldn't suggest this to a friend.

You can't say enough about this pizza. It is always awesome. Consistently great quality. Good service. This place does everything but work off the excess calories. If you haven't eaten here, you must...

This place was highly recommended from couple of friends. Don't mind the wait, but no parking anywhere but the street. Very little waiting room. The service was good the app and salad pretty good. They started off great winning my heart by the ORings coming with BBQ sauce. They were were good. Cesser salad was good. The pizza looked awesome, unfortunately the crust was burnt and many of the bites had a very burnt taste. I totally understand the "caramelized crust" but that is mainly burnt cheese, this was burnt crust

Was told it was a 15-20 minute wait for a table, and 55 minutes to get a pizza (deep dish or not). It was about 5 minutes for the table, and 20-25 minutes for the pizza. Salads and appetizers were good (garlic bread, jalapeno poppers). Large pizzas are huge. I like a lot of sauce and cheese but I have to say, there was more than I would put on my own. Made the crust which had a nice thinness a bit soggy. Sauce tasted good and toppings were fine. Overall service was good. Place to go back to, hopefully when it is a bit less busy and we can get a bit more comfortable table.

Heard so much great things about the pizza hear so tried it out tonight. The wait wasn't bad. Sat down in about 20 mins. Order a cesar salad which was a cesar salad but 1 grape tomato, (watching out for that food cost) . We were told that the pizza will take about 45 mins. That's was understandable but it really was more like 1 hr and 20 mins. After tables around us, that we sat after us and got their pizza way before we did. When we got our pizza after waiting an hour and 20, it's was burnt. I mean I notice the style of the crust was that way but the whole bottom part was caked of a thick layer of burned crust. Sorry but that just killed the flavor or the whole pizza. I wasnt asked if we're satisfied with everything at all, not until I flipped all the slices over, and I believe a manager came by and asked if we're ok and If the kitchen was preparing another one for us. I said no. I asked for the bill right after I got my pizza sauce, which also took awhile (Understandable it's pizza that had to get heated up). But I asked for the bill right away. The server didn't even wonder why or asked if everything was ok. Not until I told her and showed her the pizza, She was nice enough to take it off the bill. By far it was a horrible experience. I hear nothing but good things about this place but maybe I'll try it again but not anytime soon. Recommend not go when it's too busy cause it seems accidents happen and pizzas  comes out burned
Best pizza in Chicago hands down. Crust is perfect, toppings are great and they use real tomatoes instead of some canned sauce for toppings. Absolutely delicious.
My husband a huge fan, Pizza crust made by angels. Not sure how they get it to crispy - yet thick; sauce and toppings were excellent. Fast service- friendly - parking ok

I have no idea why nobody opens a place like this anywhere in NYC or Charleston Sc.  I cant find any deep dish/pan pizza anywhere on the east coast for that matter.  I dream about this pizza, it is so satisfying and hearty it really cant be described except overwhelmingly delicious!   And for all of the yelpers who look at the top of the pizza and say; "why is there so little cheese?"  IT IS UNDERNEATH, they don't pile all of the cheese on top of the sauce, that's a defining characteristic of this type of pizza!!  Come on people get with the program, this ain't NY style.

Always a great meal here! My boyfriend and I don't eat dairy and they always make our cheeseless pizza and it never fails to disappoint! We also had the wings here and they are very good too! Just go here, it's always good and the service is good too.

Chicago is known for it's pizza and this is another pizza place to experience.  Go early cause they are packed always specially weekends.  I say try tue or wed early afternoon and for god sakes get deep dish!

It was deep dish pizza and it was good but it was not mind blowing. The style of the restaurant is more "Bar-like" not super family friendly. Overall, the pizza was good but I also would have been happy with Round Table.

Since discovering Lou Malnati's last year, I've decided that I like Chicago deep dish more than I thought I did. On our way to the airport, we were limited on time and therefore came here upon a friend's recommendation. I liked the feel of this spot. A bar/pizza joint. The service was excellent. Everyone was so friendly and nice to newbies like us.  I liked their caesar salad. It was nice to munch on it while we waited for our pizza that takes about 20 minutes to make. So in comparing the two, I think I like Lou's better for a few reasons. Pequod's crust was too burnt/crunchy for me. There wasn't enough cheese. I like Lou's because of the perfect chunky tomato sauce to cheese ratio, as well as it not feeling insanely heavy by being too heavily breaded. But I do like this spot's vibe and their beer selection.

Give yourself time if you are going to dine in. I've been here at least 5x and every time the wait for a table was at minimum 45 minutes and no reservations.The pizza takes forever to come out...food is an art I get it, just a warning. My suggestion would be to call 30-45 minutes before you intend on coming to see what they wait time is like. Their pizza isn't bad, I'm just a die hard Lou's fan. The crust on Peaquod's pizza is fluffier and softer than Lou's buttercrust. Have it and you be the judge Lous or Peaquods?! Service was nothing special.

We had read a couple good reviews of Pequod's Pizza recently, so we headed into the city to try this award-winning pizza.   It was okay but not as cheesy as I had hoped! We had literally just watched videos of slices of this pizza being served and this amazing stretchy cheese...I felt like ours was missing so much cheese.

Did someone say Chicago deep dish pizza? Obviously when visiting Chicago, you have to get pizza.  SO my cousin and his friends took me here. We were able to get in right away. I heard it can get very busy. We started off with a salad because we were pretty hungry and knew it would a little bit for the pizza to cook. We got a deep dish pizza with olives, green peppers, pepperoni and I don't even remember what else. All I know is that it was amazing! Seriously one of the best slices of pizza I have had. So good. I wish I could go back now! Pizza is my jam and I wasn't disappointed.
The pizza here is awesome!!! A bunch of us went after work and had a great time.  The service was really good and our server was very patient with us.
The pizza was ALL cheese. I realize this may be their trademark however a real pizza is all about the crust (bread crust)
Good, but not great. Tight tables between the bar and booths, got bumped into every time a patron or server walked by. Service was average. Prices were great.
My fav deep dish pizza in Chicago. Less hassle than the others in terms of getting a seat. Their crust is the best. Never undercooked. Always reliable
Loved the deep dish pizza with its caramelised crust.. Sauce is really good. Would definitely recommend! Service could be more attentive though.

My favorite pizza in the world. I am not usually a thick pizza fan, buy I am a true pizza lover. This is the best I have ever had. The dough is awesome. Sauce slightly sweet. Topping are quality. We always get a pan pizza with mushroom and giardinera. This place is basically a local bar with the best pizza in the world.
Loved this deep dish pizza. Takes a while. Comes out on cast iron skillet, but flavor of crust, sauce, and toppings are legit.

Very chill place to go and sit down, get a pitcher  beer, and a pizza and you will be the happiest person ever. I've also gotten delivery and never been let down. Thin crust is solid, but if you are venturing Pequods, get the deep dish. It is possibly the greatest in the city of Chicago, right up there with lou's and art of pizza. The caramelized crust is something to tell your mother about (i know i told her bout it last night).

I live in San Antonio and wanted some Chicago deep dish pizza! One morning hopped a plane and took the "L" toward downtown. I was told by a former resident of Chicago to try this place! Walked around 1130 just in time for the $4.99 lunch special. Which was a personal pizza and a drink! Long story short the pizza was amazing I recommend getting sausage on it! Pairs perfect with the local beers. Took one to go back to Texas. Got back home the same day and went to bed with a full belly! I'll be back for another day trip Chicago! Worth it!!!!!
17 years in the city and this is hands down my favorite pizza!!! Amazing flavor and the caramelized crust (which looks burnt) is the BEST part!!

Absolutely love this place. I'm a huge Lou Malnatis fan and this is my new favorite. Now let's be clear, Pequods is not deep dish. It's Pan. So everyone comparing it to deep dish is way off! Anyways the crust is caramelized cheese and it's the best part! If your in the neighborhood check it out!!

Pizza is good but the place is a cluster. Made an order for pick up and was told it'd be ready by 6:15p. Got there at 6:30p and it took them over 45 minutes to transact the payment and retrieve my pizza from the back. Not worth the hassle and trying to find a place to stand while you wait.

Visiting from Orange County. Looking back, I don't know why I waited 2.5 hours for pizza. It was good, no doubt, but by the time your pizza comes you're ready to eat the table. Ordered the deep dish with ground beef, spinach, garlic, and jalapeno as well as a caesar salad. They don't have an extensive list of toppings, especially non-pork options. The bar next door must make bank.

Went on a weekday for lunch and there was no wait. The pizza was good and I can see why Chicagoans are big fans of Pequod's. I think I still like the butter crust of Lou Malnati's better but that might just mean I need to give Pequod's another visit soon.

The pizza here was just alright in my opinion.  I got the personal pan w/ pepperoni, mushroom, and onions.  It took them like 40-45 min to make it and while it was made well, I expected a lot more from the sauce - it just tasted very average, not anything you would expect on a famous pizza in Chicago.  I was also taken aback that they didn't bother cutting my pizza - maybe because it was so small.  But I was about to stuff an entire 7 in in my mouth - I still needed it cut! So I just did itself - it didn't look pretty, but it got the job done. I prob would not come back here again just because the sauce is very, very mediocre.  And since there's plenty of other pizza places to go to, I would just try a different one.  But yea, this place is way overhyped from everything that I read.

Went here expecting SO much more than I actually got. Pizza was really not that good. I would honestly say that Giordano's, Gino's East, even Lou Malnati's are all a million times better than the crust/sauce/cheese here. The staff was very inattentive and careless. It took her about 13-14 minutes to bring our drinks, after we waited about 30 to be seated and 10 to be greeted by a server. We ordered our pizza which took about 40 minutes to make (super reasonable for a deep dish). After trying to get her attention for about 15 minutes after being completely done with eating our food (which took about 25 minutes because we were STARVING), we told her (our server) that we were in a rush so head out and if she could bring our check. She was rushed and said okay and brought us our checks. We put in our card and she took the payment and we did not see her for the next 40 minutes, after requesting her to please hurry up because we were running late at this point. I have never been this disappointed with a place's food AND service (well, lack of service, actually).  Save your taste buds, go somewhere else. Actually, go anywhere else. This place sucks.

This is our go to place for Chicago deep dish pizza. It is extremely hard to get into on the weekends. We have tried twice and been told an hour to an hour and half wait. Add in the wait to cook your pizza, and you're looking at 2-1/2 hour wait to get to fed. My advice if you intent on Pequods for a weekend night, don't go hungry! This last time we went on a Tuesday. A 10-15 minute wait was acceptable. We actually got seated in 5 minutes! Pizza was delicious as usual. Their sauce is great fresh, sweet tomatoes. The salad was disappointing. Lou Malanatis has better salads, they use romaine lettuce and their dressing is fresh, made in house. Our Cesar salad was made with leaf lettuce and the dressing was overly thick and salty. We ordered beer but unfortunately they were out of our preferred Allgash. Disappointing.

Visiting from San Diego I tried three places while in San Diego. Connies, Luminatis and this place.  This place wins hands down. Ordered the deep dish with sausage jalapeño and onion. Shared a pizza with a friend for $30. Totally worth it!
Service was great. Food was good but it definitely did not make my top 5 pizza spots.

Best pizza in Chicago- it's as simple as that. Definitely expect a line, but definitely know that the wait will be well worth it in the end. If you're ordering delivery, it's gonna take a GRIP, but again- worth the wait.

We were like a group of 8 - 10 and we had a like an hour long wait before we actually got in and started getting ordering drinks and food. Both the appetizers and pizza was good, drinks were fairly good too. The staff is friendly but very slow service. The crust is definitely burnt, to the point where we thought they burnt it too much. With the idea of deep-dish and adding some veggies with burnt crust, it kinda felt as though it was too runny/oily so most folks didn't really like the pizza, but on the other hand, I thought it was good, except tasting burnt parts on occasion.

I'm a big fan of Lou Malnati's for deep dish and it's my go to place but I kept hearing great things about Pequois and wanted to give it a try. The wait on a Saturday was pretty long (we were quotes 2 hours but it ended up being 1 hour). There's a Barnes and Nobles across the street so you can pass the time there. The restaurant/bar is pretty small although there is an upstairs I didn't see. We got down to business and ordered a small sausage along with a Pequod salad. The salad was standard and the whale cheese was a cute touch. The deep dish was generous and delicious. That infamous caramelized crust lived up to the hype, the crust is lighter than Lou's, and the sauce is bright and flavorful. I was bummed the sausage wasn't an entire layer like at Lou's but that might be personal preference. Overall, really good deep dish that I think will win over devotees and first timers alike. A fun atmosphere that is a great place to grab a few drinks and eat some pizza.
Love this place!  Best pizza ever.  Priced right as well!

The thin crust pizza was so, so good. I'm still thinking about it and it was two weeks ago when I had it for the first time. I didn't know the background of this spot. We just saw it was close to the movie theater nearby and it had some good reviews. We ordered a thin crust with pepperoni and ground beef. Pizza heaven on a platter I tell ya! Let me just say I came away impressed. Crust is a nice golden thin crust and not fake thin or soggy. Cheese and meat were fresh and quality. From the outside by all appearances it's very much a neighborhood dive bar/dining spot that one may not guess has excellent thin crust pizza. But this spot had waaaay better thin crust than many bigger chains or touristy stops I've been to that tout good pizza. If you're a big pizza fan you definitely have to try this place. I haven't tried the deep dish so I can't speak for deep but the thin crust was all that.

5 stars for dining in, 3.5 stars for takeout or delivery. Their pizza is about the best you can get when you eat it fresh at the restaurant - although waiting for a table can sometimes be a pain during prime times. But it is worth it if you have the time. The pizza loses something when you take it to go or have it delivered but it's still very good. There's not much bad to say about Pequod's.
The lunch special is $5 caramelized personal pizza at the skokie location is a must have- bucket list worthy.

Not a fan.  I've been a few times and it seems like every time it's not only over crowded but the pizza is burned.  Maybe that's their style, but I think it ruins it.  There's other deep dish outfits in town that do it better.

This was the second place we tried on our quest to taste "famous" Chicago pizza. So far we're not understanding how these places have earned their reputations. We ordered our pizza to be delivered and it came in an hour. That was perfectly fine with us (it was a Saturday night and was actually delivered on the lower end of the time frame I was given). Pizza arrived hot and fresh. Just to clarify, Pequad's does not make a deep dish pizza. I see a lot of reviews calling their pizza deep dish and it's not, it's a pan pizza, which means it's a very thick crust. We knew this before we ordered and we are fans of pan pizzas, so this wasn't a surprise for us. We ordered a personal sized pepperoni, and a large pineapple. Overall, the pizza was edible. Sauce was mild in flavor (but at least it had some flavor compared to the other place we tried), there wasn't a ton of cheese (this could be good, or bad depending on your preference), and the crust had no flavor and was way too dry. I don't think I've ever had pizza crust fall apart due to being too dry. That was the biggest downfall of this pizza...dry crust that isn't very flavorful equals a lackluster pizza. The cheese caramelization on the edge of the crust was right on the cusp of being overdone. If it had been cooked any longer that cheese would have been burnt to an inedible state. Thank goodness it wasn't cooked to that point, but it was really close. Maybe if it was cooked a couple minutes less the crust wouldn't have been so dry and the caramelized cheese along the edges would have been in a more enjoyable state  I don't eat dairy or eggs and I decided to in order to find out what makes Chicago's pizza great. So far that decision hasn't been worthwhile. You're letting me down Chicago!
It's good. There are many things that could have been better - but the ingredients were good. Overall 7/10. Service was meh - lots of upselling.

With chains like Giordano's and Lou Malnati's serving up deep dish in Chicago, Pequods is certainly a hidden gem. However, it is my FAVORITE deep dish pizza in Chicago and I never fail to mention it to those looking to try deep dish for the first time. I took my family here and they also agreed it was the best pizza they've ever had. There's more of a sports bar vibe from Pequods than from the other chain restaurants, it's often dark, open late, and there can be tons of people depending of if there's a game or not.  What sets Pequods apart is their crust on the deep dish. It's perfectly cooked so that it's carmelized and crispy which makes the pizza that much better. You can't get crust like that elsewhere.  Keep in mind that deep dish pizza can take a while to cook so either be prepared to wait (it's worth it) or order some appetizers in the mean time. On weekdays, you can call in and order ahead of time so that the pizza will come out faster once you've arrived.  They also don't take reservations so on weekends and nights when there's a sporting event get there early or be prepared to put down your name and wait.

Disappointing Pequod's experience on Super Bowl Sunday.  My friend had a party, and ordered (through Door Dash) at noon for a 6:30pm delivery.  Now, I get that's it the Super Bowl, so they were likely busy, but they should've been prepared.  And that's why my friend ordered at noon. The door dash driver was there on time, and kept sending my friend updates that he was just sitting there waiting for them to give him the pizzas to deliver.  He finally arrived an hour after we were supposed to originally get them.  Getting late pizzas wouldn't have been such an issue, but the order was completely wrong.  One was supposed to be a thin-crust half-Hawaiian, half-cheese, but instead it was cheese and pineapple on one side and cheese and ham on the other.  The deep-dish was supposed to be half sausage and half pepperoni, but the pizza instead had no meat and had green peppers on the whole thing.  The pizza tasted okay, not great, but the garlic bread we got wasn't good, either. Again, I get Super Bowl Sunday is a big day for pizza places, but this should not have been a surprise to them  Getting the pizza late AND having the order be completely wrong, especially for the price paid, is extremely disappointing.  I'm sure the experience in the restaurant is much different/better, but this was not a good experience.

Pizza was good,  it was just more crust than toppings.  Able to split a10" for two people and not get overly stuffed. Great atmosphere, and our plan to go mid - afternoon on a Saturday worked well with only a 15 minute wait time.

The lines are nuts at this place, but the pizza is really good depending on what you order.  The first 3 were not good, so then I asked around and friends say try the thick crust one that they recommend is their most popular, so I did and now I get it.  Really good, not my fav, but good and they deliver.

If you plan on coming here on the weekend, make sure you call hours ahead of time to get priority seating once you get there. The place is super crowded on weekends, with hour waits for pizza. The service was okay (could have been better).  After waiting an hour for pizza, I thought it would be on the same level of delicious as Lou Malnati's. The pizza was burned, and it tasted like Tombstone frozen pizza. The bread was too dry. Not my kind of pizza.

Don't go here on the weekend, the wait is ridiculous! Or plan on having four hours to hangout! If you've ever been to Detroit and enjoyed an amazing Detroit style pizza such as Loui's or Buddy's or for those that haven't made it there but may have had Jets! You know that it's all about the crust! This place has the crust dialed in! Its that Carmelized cheese baked to the edge crust that makes the whole slice worth it! This pizza was great it was like the best of both worlds Chicago meets Detroit and I loved it! I'll be back someday for 2nds! A little tip would be don't waste your time with veggies on these pizzas! Sausage maybe some pepperoni is the best way to enjoy! Get a salad too, very good!
its really not that good. lous is way better

In the ongoing battle of the best Chicago deep dish, I made my way over to Pequod's on a recent trip. What I like about this place is it's not located in the middle of the The Loop tourist trap. You get to see more of Chicago as you trek out here. The restaurant is simple and to the point. It's set up like a classic pizzeria with small tables scattered about and condiments on the table. Read the menu immediately upon sitting as the servers are quick to  take your order since the pizza takes quite a while to cook. I went with a pepperoni deep dish pizza. The pizza was very good, but honestly not as good as I was expecting. Flavors were good so was the sauce, but I have to say that I think Lou Malnati's is better. None the less, I plowed through as much of the pizza as possible and left there full and satisfied.  Great pizza, but in my opinion, not the champion of Chicago deep dish. Still Lou Malnatis.
I would've loved to say it was great pizza, but they cancelled my delivery order.  I've never heard of a pizza place cancel your order 2 hours before it needed to delivered... on a Tuesday.

Heaven in the form of pizza. Forget the places you've heard about before and go here if you want good, Chicago pizza. The crust is perfect, the cheese ring around the edge is perfect, all around perfect pizza. Anyone who tells you this isn't Chicago pizza is wrong and you don't need that negativity in your life.
I've been to both locations (the OG is in Morton Grove) It's not as good as the Original according to my husband, but I love both locations. Best pan pizza in Chicago in my eyes.

THE BEST DEEP DISH.  Don't let other's persuade you. If you are looking for deep dish, come here. Leave the others behind. All Chicago pizza places have a wait, but this one is worth it.  What makes them different from the rest is their amazing crust. Caramelized cheese crust. SO GOOD.  Just headed over, do it, right now!
Got pizza for take out. I ordered deep dish pizza. It was good but I still find Lou Malnati's way better. I got half of my pie with Pesto and I really suggest you to do the same! It was super good!
Not a deep dish fan, but this place has amazing burnt crust deep dish pizza. A little pricey and delivery waits could be long but worth the wait.
Pizza was wonderful. A little tight quarters but who cares the service was great. Great place to sample Chicago pizza!  Here after a wedding rehearsal.
Awesome pizza! Ordered a large sausage and pepperoni pie. Huge for two people. The beer on draft is really good. Definitely coming back next time I'm in Chicago!

The pizza here is excellent. It's as good as Lou Malnati's just different. We waited a very long time to get in. By the time the pizza came we were starving even though we ordered an appetizer and a salad. I wish it wasn't such a long wait. I understand that pizza takes time to cook.

This establishment made me feel like I was a local Chicagoan, especially after working up an appetite at Goose Island brewery right before! Their caramelized crust won me over & just had to put pepperoni, jalapeños & pineapple on it to seal the deal.  I tried Lou Malnati's too & thought it was good, but I found that THIS is the Chicago pizza experience people talk about!

My favorite Chicago deep dish. Lou's is a close second, but something about the crust at Pequod's is just utterly delicious. I love the meaty meat toppings, abundance of both delicious cheese and sauce, and did I mention that crust‽ I don't have much else to say as I haven't eaten in the restaurant and I always make the same order, but had to share my love for Pequod's.
Best Chicago style pizza in the city; the place you actually order from regularly as a Chicagoan. Pan - sausage and pepperoni Ate there in person recently; ate upstairs and it was a fun change!

Great pizza! Had been hearing about it from other people so was curious to give it a try. I liked the option to add on so many different toppings - we were feeling particularly "adventurous" so we got anchovies on half of the pizza, and it was SO good. The deep dish here is definitely really yummy, although I must say that I'm not very good at telling similar foods part so I couldn't really tell you how it was different from Lou's. Maybe slightly less cheesier?? Idk. But regardless I would say it was definitely great!

Solid pizza experience. I'd consider this to be a "hole-in-the-wall" find. Pretty good Chicago deep dish pizza but not quite as good as Giordanos in my opinion. The sausage topping is great though. Medium easily serves 3 people (and that's if they have big appetites). Mozzarella sticks were extra cheesy, stringy, and crunch on the outside. There's an attempt to do a sports bar theme but it's not totally cohesive. The music choice is cliche radio hits but that's all negligible in my overall rating of the place.

Crust: 5 stars!!!  Taste/Toppings (sausage, ground beef, basil): meh 3 Service: average Pricing: 4 stars - competitive pricing Tip: Call day of to get moved to "top of the waitlist" which in my case, meant that when I arrived, instead of a 2 hr wait, I had a 1 hr wait for 3 people. Imagine you're sifting through your laundry, determining what to load in the washer next, do you pick your underwear? your stacks of stinky tshirts post-gym? or perhaps, those slacks with food stains? Now, apply this logic determining what you value in pizza to determine which deep dish place is your favorite. Pequod's ain't perfect, but it can be perfect depending on your pizza preferences.  In my college heyday, I gorged myself with quite a bit of Giardano's and Lou's, but never got around to trying what many deemed to be the "best deep dish" in town aka Pequod's.  What I got: Personal size half sausage, and half ground beef + basil Crust: PERFECTION. Described to be a "caramelized" crust and boy, can you see it! Giardano's has the soggy cardboard crust of death. Lou's crust has great taste but still can get dry or mush in the middle. Pequod's has a beautiful crunchy crust THROUGHOUT including the middle bottom. Tell me thy saucery! Everything else: sausage was pretty bland, Lou's sausage is by far superior. I also like the ground beef itself by Giardano's better. Passing grade for the cheese. I did like the fact that the sauce is not too watery. Atmosphere: very casual, has seating upstairs and downstairs, 45min or more to get your pizza cooked depending on how busy it is. Bar and hockey type of atmosphere. Bottom line: If perfect crust is what you desire - this is a must go. Too soon to call it for me in regards to the superiority of this to Lou's, definitely better than Giardano's and Uno's. May not be worth it for an extra long wait though. Will be back to try other toppings!

Deep dish done right. We had our medium pie delivered. While the delivery time was a little longer than what we would've like, the wait was well worth it. In a town with a pizza place on every corner, Pequad's stands apart. Try it, you won't regret it.

Pizza gets 5 stars but service get 1.  Went on a Tuesday afternoon for lunch and asked to sit in a booth (there were only a handful of people there).  Were told there weren't any available (what?!) and were sat at a high top table.  Not exactly my favorite seating for an afternoon lunch...tends to be very uncomfortable.  We found the hostess to be incredibly rude and later she was seating a large family in another section of the restaurant and when she came back up was making very loud and rude comments to another waitress about the family.

The service was nice... pizza took about 20 mins... the wait is worth it though probably one of the best pizzas in Chicago if not the best I've ever had... I'll have to come back for the $4.95 lunch special personal pan pizza and a drink

Oh the caramelized crust!!!...Honestly my favorite pizza ever, anywhere. It differs from the traditional deep dish pizzas found elsewhere in the city. More along the lines of pan style that must be attacked by knife and fork.  Having been to the Pequod's in Morton Grove originally. I fell in love. So when it was time to visit my family for the holidays. This was my first stop immediately leaving the airport. I've been craving it for over a year since my move to San Diego. And it did not disappoint.  We got my go-to deep dish with pepperoni, sausage and jalapeno. The cheese gets crispy and caramelized along the edge providing that crunch to go with the soft dough and buttery pie-like bottom crust. The toppings are plentiful and savory.

If you are up by Wrigley, you need to stop in this pizza place! My favorite pizza in Chicago is Lou Malnati's but this is a very close second. We ordered a thin crust and a pan pizza and they were both awesome. The topping were free and the pizza had the perfect proportions of cheese, toppings and sauce. The service was excellent. We had a waitress that was training and she did a great job.  As others have said, parking is difficult so we took an Uber.

By far the best pizza in Chicago. The cast iron baked pan crust is so ridiculously good I have dreams about it. The place does get really busy during popular hours and the service starts to slow, but the pizza is well worth the wait. Definitely a must try if you haven't already.
I'm from NY and a bit of a pizza snob.  I was never a fan of Chicago style pizza until I ate here.   The small is big enough for 2 to share and was VERY GOOD!

I have to agree with others who have said that Pequods pizza is good, but it has too much crust compared to  sauce and cheese. The amount of toppings is fair, but there should be more cheese and sauce and less crust. I don't think I'd order it again.

If you love pizza the way I love pizza then this is the spot to go! Pequods is Pizza Heaven. I have tried multiple pizza spots and this one is my number one in Chicago. I can start from the unique buttery and tasty deep dish burnt crust to the perfect amount of sauce and cheese with the toppings! Totally worth the cheat meal and food comma. It is usually packed so prepare to wait for at least 30 minutes to be seated on weekends. Once you're seated the service is legit. Pequods is a must go!

There are two floors! The first floor was super crowded when I walked in, but when we were seated on the second floor it wasn't as bad. We were seated quickly.  The waitress came quickly with waters and explained the menu to us. We ordered and the pizza came out in about 40 minutes! The toppings were great, but the crust on the other hand wasn't as impressive.  The crust seemed a bit overdone and was a tad too hard for me. Possibly was just a busy day and they rushed it or left it for too long. Would come back to try again!

Stellar deep dish and different than the typical giordanos, Gino's, and Lou's. The crust here is different, and the sausage is made in house apparently. These differentiating factors make the pizza here unbelievably tasty and heavy! Great with a refreshing beer to wash it down. I also like starting with a salad, and their house salad is a great starter to the meal. Even super crowded on a Monday afternoon, so that tells you something about their delicious pizza. I wasn't a big fan of the service though I have to admit. This is probably the only reason pequod's isn't a five star joint for me, but excellent pizza and vibes nonetheless!

After a year of living in the Windy City, I've finally gotten the chance to try Pequod's to see what the hype was all about in regards to "Chicago's Best Deep Dish Pizza!" Then I realized that everything is relative to what you like in a pizza. is it the sauce, the cheese, the dough, etc. If you are a bread fan, then this place will certainly live up to your expectations. But if you're like me, then you'll just find this to be another great deep dish variant, but not the most "amazing" one that I've ever bitten into. For starters, Pequod's reputation means that it gets busy no matter the time or day. My friend and I came here for a New Year's lunch, and luckily called in to "get priority." We essentially skipped to the top of the line once we arrived because we called in early to make a semi-reservation. I suggest that you do the same! We were seated at a booth and I really loved the layout of the restaurant. I felt like it had just enough space without feeling overcrowded, and loved the brick walls and sports bar vibe. Our meal started with their Fried Sampler plate which was bomb. Loved the mozzarella sticks and jalapeño poppers the most. About 20 minutes later, our large deep dish pizza came out with sausage, Canadian bacon, green peppers, and basil. Each topping was an additional $2.50 on top of the pizza price. Right off the back, the pizza smelled real good and I could tell that it was a lot of bread! Pequod's is known for its quality dough, and I can see why! The thin tomato sauce layer held together some amazing pieces of meat. I would say that the best sausage on a deep dish pizza was definitely from here. Personally, I prefer a deep dish with more cheese, sauce, and toppings rather than the dough itself. Because of this, I can't really call this the best deep dish pizza in Chicago, but it truly is one of the best I've had. If you're into bread, then this is surely for you!

hefty portions of toppings on the 12" medium pan pizza we ordered. wait staff is extremely helpful and courteous. came on a Saturday afternoon around lunch time, and didn't have to wait for find a table. there is plenty of room, including upstairs preferred seating!

I'm a Chicago native so you can bet I have tried just about all of the Chicago Deep Dish pizza's out there. This is definitely my favorite of them all! I have been coming here since the bar next door used to Flounders (currently called the Drinking Bird I believe?). When it was Flounders, the owners would let us bring the tasty goodness of their neighbor (if their kitchen was already closed) after drinking shenanigins with close friends. Which of course always tasted like heaven. Whether or not I have had an adult beverage or not, this my favorite of all deep dish pizza's. The caramelized crust is just mouth watering. The care they put into the ingredients and the customer service is apparent every time you come here! Funny story, the first time I brought my best friend and her husband to Pequods, he was like why's the crust burnt?! I said no, not burnt it's caramelized. Now when he was in Afghanistan he would tell her how much he missed his "burnt crust from Pequods!"  I may not go into the restaurant very often, but I'm sure glad they deliver. You can't go wrong with what I refer to as "The Chicagoan Deep Dish" - because we all know that Giordano's (while tasty as well in its own right) is the tourist attraction.

I ordered a 12 inch Peperoni & onion pan pizza. The crust is really thick and tastey. The 12 inch is the perfect size for two hungry people...just enough for leftovers :P only downside was that we had to wait an hour and fifteen minutes but it was so good and so worth the wait! You know what they say.. you have to wait for the best things in life amirite?! FIVE STARS! Go pequods!

Note - this review is based on customer service, not product.  We ordered a pizza on a Friday night while packing up for a move and were told it would be a 1 1/2 hour wait.  After well over 2, I called and was told they had no record of the order.  After being transferred several times, I finally spoke to an unaccommodating manager who offered a forced apology only after I asked what was going to be done about the situation - as if she didn't believe we had even placed the order.  She said they could place the order again but it would be over an hour to receive.  They did, in fact, find the order later on as it was listed under an incorrect address and still all they offered in return for waiting 3 hours plus for a misplaced order was a free small salad.  The charge remained on my card for almost a week before being reversed.  I used to love Pequods so it was unfortunate to feel like our business wasn't valued.  We'll be ordering elsewhere from now on.

Honestly, this is some of the best pizza that I've had in Chicago. I absolutely love the caramelized crust and flavor of these deep dish pizzas. The service is great and the atmosphere is pretty laid back. You can't call yourself a true Chicagoan if you haven't enjoyed Pequod's. And tourists, go out of the way to come here if you can.
Tessa served us a thick pan pizza.  the.best   it was huge it was phenomenal it was the greatest!!! The pizza was fresh and delicious  Chitown favorite!!!!

I LOVE their pizza -- my husband and I agree that it is hands-down the best deep-dish pizza we've had in Chicago. They caramelize the crust and it is wonderful. The star down is for wait-time when it's busy. They're really great when it's an off time and they're not busy. Super friendly and helpful, but they need to do something about how they handle customers during the busy times. They don't take reservations, instead they have a priority seating list that puts you at the top of the wait list when you arrive. When I went with a large-ish group, they told me we'd have about a 45 minute wait. It took about 90 minutes, and we had something scheduled (and paid for and reserved) right afterwards, so it was super stressful trying to get dinner before we went to our event, and we weren't even really able to enjoy ourselves -- just ordered a couple of pizzas, had a beer, and had to take off. So, not the best place to go for dinner if you have somewhere else to be later, but still good food. Like I said, when they're not busy, the experience is great. They always have a game on and have great food. The service staff makes great recommendations for beer when asked and the atmosphere fits in well with a sports bar -- a little dark on the inside, but all the better to watch a game, eat pizza, and have a drink. If you come with a large group, be prepared to be a little squished. They don't have a ton of room and are quite busy during the dinner hour.
Best deep dish in Chicago. Period.  Good, relaxed atmosphere. Great beer selection. Probably only do once every 6 months as an incredibly calorific experience.

Eeehhhhh.....hhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh.............. I was really excited to try this place.  No, let me back up a bit.  I've had "Chicago style" pizza once before.  I wasn't thrilled with it!  Kinda like a bread bowl with cheese.  So I never really had a desire to try it again on any of my trips to Chicago.  On my most recent trip I was like, let's go for it.  And did a search on a suggestion.  I found this place and the pictures looked absolutely amazing. The service was very friendly.  The restaurant itself was nice... the Cubs had just won the world series like 3 days before so it had a good atmosphere.  The pizza itself tho... I was kinda just disappointed.  I didn't think the sauce had much flavor at all.  Two strikes on chicago pizza for me... I don't think I would go for another try.  Guess I'm just an east coaster who lives her good italian NYC style pizza.

Kept asking around all the locals and uber drivers where the best deep dish was and pequouds and lou malnatis were the names that kept coming up. I chose here because it seemed like the better place to drink a beer too. It didn't disappoint though. Great pizza!
It's good - but, I don't see how this is "the best" pizza.  I mean, I'd eat it but I don't consider this Chicago's best.

This was my first time in Chicago and I couldn't have the complete tourist experience without a taste of deep dish pizza.  This place definitely delivered!  I'm a New York pizza kinda girl and a little skeptical about this infamous deep dish pizza but the caramelized crust is absolutely delicious and all the oooey goooey cheese is what dreams are made of.  You do have to wait a while for the pizza but I am telling you it is totally worth it.

I'm not from Chicago. I've been here on 3 separate trips, however, and have tried deep dish at the "best" places in Chicago each time. Clearly, you have to grow up with this stuff to like it. It is not pizza. It must have been invented by someone who had never eaten or even seen a pizza, but just heard it described by someone who didn't provide much detail. This stuff is closer to lasagna, but not in a good way. Pequods is in a cool neighborhood and is a cool little bar/restaurant.  The people were nice here, though the service was slow and not very attentive.  I had to get up and get myself silverware and napkins. I found the pizza very bland, but the lunch special of 4 95 for a 7 inch pizza was a good deal and quite filling (even though I couldn't finish it) would I go back? Not for the pizza. I'd drink a beer here though.

Came to Chicago for the first time and was craving the city's famous deep dish pizza. While I heard many different recommendations as to who was "the best" - Pequod's was definitely at the top. Trusting my fellow foodie friends, I ordered a small pepperoni, mushroom, and jalapeno pan pizza. HOLY MOLY was that pizza good. The caramelized crust is out of this world - I could slice off just the outsides of the pizza and eat it by itself. BUT enjoying the pizza bit my bit and getting to the crust at the end of each slice is just as good of a reward. Overall, a very solid, delicious (and filling) pizza. While I can't speak to the other "bests" out there, I'm not sure that I need to - this place was amazing and I highly recommend it.
All i can say is that their pan pizza is great, but keep in mind that the bread will get absolutely soaked and soggy if you take it to go.

Like others have said, forget the pizza chains in Chicago---Pequod's is the best! We have dined in a couple times and ordered delivery a dozen. The pan pizza (deep dish-esque) is what you order here. Yes, it takes a long time (sometimes two hours for delivery!) But, they are upfront with you about the cooking time.  Personally, I prefer delivery/carryout, as the restaurant itself is kind of bland and cramped.  Order a pan pizza with whatever toppings you like. Get a side of ranch if you're into that (theirs is great). Relax and wait for the best Chicago-style pizza in the city.

I work in the area and I always see the lines of people waiting. My boyfriend and I decided to check this place out on a Saturday, we didn't have to wait and were seated right away. Staff was friendly, attentive and awesome. The pizza was to die for!!!! We found our new favorite pizza place.

If you love deep dish and are a little tired of the typical Giordano's (blech), Gino's East, or Lou Malnati's, Pequod's will delight.  They serve their pizza's a little more well done, so it is almost crispy crust and burnt edge pepperoni.  I highly recommend the pepperoni!!

Amazing! Worth the wait for sure, not to mention you can go to the bar next door and have a drink while you are waiting.   This is the best Chicago has to offer no doubt. The Pep/sausage was to die for!  I can't wait to visit again.

I've been to Pequad's a few times, so let me start by saying that the pizza is great. With that said, however, we had such an awful experience with their customer service that they deserve no more than 3 stars. I've been eating deep dish pizza my whole life, so I understand that it takes a long time to make; however, at Pequad's apparently it's supposed to take an hour and a half. That's what a manager tried to convince us of when, on a not so busy afternoon, the table next to us was seated, ordered, ate, and left all in the time that we waited for our pizza to come out. It was pretty frustrating at the time, but in retrospect kind of funny.  I'll most likely go back, because that crust... sooo good, BUT it's going to take a while for me to get over this.

Never eating here again due to poor customer service and a ridiculous wait. I had relatives in town and I called ahead to put my name on the "list" since they don't accept reservations. When we arrived, they said it was a 60 minute wait. Went up to the hostess at that time and they said it'd be another 45 minute wait. So we waited because at that point, we had already invested a lot of time. Went back to the hostess and there still wasn't any seating, and on top of that the pizza would take another 30 minutes to make even after we got seated, so we left. The pizza isn't worth the hassle, I'd choose giordanos over pequods any day.

As a Chicagoan, I love all pizza. Thin, thick, stuffed, pan, deep dish, bagel bites, pizza for breakfast, cold pizza straight from the fridge. Pequod's does live up to the hype. I wouldn't say it's the best pizza, mostly because I don't have a favorite. I love all sorts of pizza, remember? Don't come here starving to death because you will most likely have to wait 15-30 minutes for a table. And then after you order a pan pizza, you'll have to wait another 20+ minutes. And for that reason, we ordered mozzarella sticks so we could have something to munch on. Nothing amazing with the mozzarella sticks and, unfortunately, ours were only slightly warm, which means the cheese was not ooey gooey.. boo. Anyway, the pan pizza is HEAVY. I would say a small 10" pan pizza is enough for two people if you don't want leftovers. In my opinion, the more toppings, the better! So we usually get pepperoni, sausage, green pepper, onion and mushroom. Their pan crust reminds me almost of thick focaccia bread doused in butter and cheese and baked until a nice, crispy outer crust is formed. It's definitely a delicious pizza straight out of the oven, however, I don't recommend take out since the pan pizza can get a bit soggy.

Ordered pizza for delivery here in late November and it arrived lukewarm after about an hour. Cheese wasn't very melted and it seemed they had rushed out the order late as if it had been forgotten. We called to complain and they agreed to give us a discount on a future order, not to refund any portion of the order that was undercooked. We reluctantly ate what came because we couldn't wait another hour. Too bad, really, because this place has been a neighborhood favorite for years. But after this experience we won't be coming back. Too many other good pizza places around.

Been here twice now and can say it's officially my favorite deep dish (or pan is what they call it or stuffed etc... the crazy excessive fat delicious chicago style pizza!). To me it comes down to the crust. It light, buttery and crumbly with the caramelized crust. Our favorite topping is with sausage and giardiniera Mmmmmmmmm. First time came on a Saturday night, it's a nightmare, 2 hour wait then 45min wait for pizza once you order. Went today Sunday lunch at 1pm, walked right in, no wait for a table. So I'd recommend lunch time for sure to not have the wait dampen the experience!

BEST PIZZA EVER. I genuinely don't know what else to say about this place other than the three words posted about. For the first time, I am speechless about what I ate.  I got the deep dish pizza. It looks burnt at first but they actually line the baking sheet with cheese and so it's just cooked cheese. It's delightful and brilliant. Beware, it is also so so filling.

Really like this place. The crust of this pizza is the best thing ever. The pizza tastes really fresh but sadly takes 45 minutes to make! I would suggest coming here right when Pequod's opens BEFORE everyone files in for the football game happening that weekend. Another thing, if you're really into cheese, Pequod's is not the cheesiest of the deep dish places. So, if you're looking for something like that, I'd either get the cheese pizza (or ask for more cheese) or check out Lou Malnati's or Giordano's.

I wasn't impressed with the deep dish pizza. I ordered a small deep dish with pepperoni and mushrooms. It was too bready and dry from the lack of tomato sauce. It wasn't very cheesy either. The caramelized crust tasted burnt. It was edible but I wouldn't order it again. The cheesy Garlic bread I ordered as an appetizer was way better than the deep dish pizza. The wait for a table was about 30min on a Friday night for 2.

This is the BEST place for deep dish pizza! My favorite part about the pizza here is how the edges of the crust are slightly burned so it's really crisp. I've tried 3 different deep dish pizza places in one day to compare them all (Pequod's, Giordano's, Lou Malnati's) and Pequod's is the best in my opinion! I can't comment on the service here; I always order for pick-up because I'm too impatient to wait, unless I am catching up with some friends and passing time anyway. Keep in mind that you will always have to wait for deep dish pizza if you expect a quality, fresh pizza no matter where you go.

A friend recommended this place for great pizza. We were so excited because it was busy and it had a great atmosphere. We decided to get two personal pizzas and asked for extra cheese (which is an extra charge). When we got the the pizzas we literally had no cheese on the pizza. Couldn't even taste any cheese. We were really disappointed as the reviews showed pizza with a ton of cheese. It was not Chicago style, which was what we were expecting.

I'm a big fan of deep dish pizza and Pequod's is definitely one of my favorites. I'm used to the suburban location, which is a lot smaller, but this location was larger and much, much busier, which was expected. Went here on a Sunday night around 7:30p with a pretty large group (11 people).  There wasn't a problem getting seated, which was nice, but we were a bit crammed in a round booth table.  The server was really nice and very patient as she took our drink orders right away as we waited for some of the others to get to the restaurant. There wasn't that big of a selection but they had a decent sized list. We ordered two orders of the appetizer platters which was just enough for our large group. I really liked the fried zuchinni, but wasn't that big of a fan of the jalepeno poppers.  We ordered 2 large and 1 medium pan pizza. It took about maybe an hour to arrive but it was worth it!. We had one with Italian beef and giardenera, another with just sausage, and the last with mushroom and spinach. Everyone enjoyed all of them! The crust was crisp to perfection. Definitely enough for 10 people! There were some leftovers but not a lot For first timers--I recommend ordering an appetizer since pizzas take a while to cook, and if you are ordering the deep dish pizzas, go no more than 2 toppings, as it might get a bit overwhelming.

Hands down, Pequod's is the best Chicago deep dish. Pequod's is always a staple of my Chicago trips. I always try to eat there at least once while I am in town. The first couple times I was in Chicago, I did the touristy thing and went to Giordano's, etc. I did not know about the Holy Grail of Chicago pizza yet. A friend of mine told me I was missing out and needed to stay away from the tourist trap pizza places and experience true Chicago pizza. I had high expectations for my first time when I went to Pequod's, and they definitely were met and exceeded! I was not disappointed. If you go on a weekend, you should expect a wait, unless you utilize the call ahead seating that they offer. The pizza does take some time to make, but it is expected. Their pizza is actually true deep dish pizza, with the perfect combination of dough, sauce, cheese, and toppings. (Instead of having loads of cheese and toppings filled with a thin layer of dough.) I can't even put in words how amazing the flavor is, especially with the caramelized cheese on the crust! That's probably one of my favorite parts!!!  The atmosphere is great inside as well, especially to watch your favorite team. Lots of televisions and you will have a view of multiple screens from wherever you are seated. I was impressed with how reasonable the price was at Pequod's as well.  If you haven't had Pequod's deep dish yet, you need to go try it ASAP. It will change your life and you will not want to eat any other Chicago deep dish ever again.

This might really be a 3.5, maybe even close to a 4, but this place is just so over-sold.  Yes, it's good pizza, but people go nuts over it, and I just don't get it.   They don't do anything really special to set themselves apart.  Yes, they do what they do well, but there's not really anything that grabs you.  The crust is nothing special.  The sauce is not particularly captivating.  The ingredients are of good quality offer nothing special.  There simply isn't anything about Pequod's that would make it a destination for me.

Among my hometown Chicago friends, Pequod's is the #1 recommendation for deep dish BESIDES the chains (Lou's, Giordano's, etc.). And why? The crust. It's great. Unfortunately, I think they simply under-season their pizza. The rest of the pie ends up a little bit bland for my taste, especially given the slightly inflated price (relative to the chains mentioned above). That said, if you're going out for deep dish (versus ordering in/picking up), this is one of the best places to do that - the environment is comfortable and kitschy in only the right ways.

This is the best of the best of the best... provided you order it fresh, at the restaurant.  I dislike bar atmospheres, which this place definitely has, but I more than tolerate the dark, the noise, the raucousness for the sheer sublimity of this perfect expression of Chicago Pizza. The platonic ideal, to wax philosophical. It's also more than worth the long wait/the long prep time if you call ahead (recommended). It's a chain, but *barely,* with just one other location--the original, in the suburbs. Nothing like the tourist-friendly polish of Giordano's/Lou's, with a freezer in the front for tourists to ship "authentic Chicago"!!!! pizza souvenirs to their buddy Joe in Montana.  Now, it's well-known that the mere fact of being geographically served within Chicago's city limits does not a true Chicago Pizza make. There are four or five valid choices, in order of my personal preference: Pequod's, Giordano's, Uno's, Lou Malnati's, Gino's. The final four in that list are pretty close in ranking, and reasonable people can quibble about the order. Pequod's is in the #1 slot by leaps and bounds.  Be prepared for a thick, doughy, bready crust which caramelizes to crisp perfection. It's not "burnt" and won't give you cancer. Just exquisitely cooked cheese and tomato sauce. The deepest pan of all deep-dish joints. Fresh ingredients (I usually order with double mushroom, broccoli, and garlic). And the most FILLING pizza you've ever had. Two or three slices are all most people can handle. As I said at the start, this pizza is really best eaten fresh. Ordered as delivery or takeout and reheated at home still results in an excellent, exceptional pie... but a good chunk of the magic is lost and it becomes more in-line with the others.

Pizza is good pan and thin but wings were not cooked well they came out cold at the same time as my pizza the place is super cold seems like they want you to eat and get out had my coat on the whole time I was eating.

Pequod's was pretty busy around 7:30pm on a Sunday night. We had a party of 11 and we were seated right away which I think was pure luck lol because this place is always packed. We were able to sit in the corner booth by the fireplace which was a nice touch cause it was pretty cold on that side.  We ordered 2 appetizer combos which had breaded mushrooms, fried zucchini, mozzarella sticks, and jalapeno poppers. I liked all the options and it was cooked perfectly. I would def order this again to have a taste of 4 appetizers. I also think it was around $10 for a platter which isn't bad.  We got 3 pizzas. 1 large sausage pizza, 1 large veggie (mushroom and spinach), and 1 large half giardiniera and italian beef. There was a confusion when we ordered the last pizza because we wanted the full pizza to be italian beef but only half of it have giardiniera on top. All the pizzas were delicious and cooked great. It did take like 45-1 hour for the pizzas to come, but it was well worth it.  I'm very loyal to Lou's, but Pequod's is pretty up there. If you're visiting Chicago, you should def check this place out.

Went here on our last night in town and since Chicago is known for their deep dish I had to go to the best.  Read this was the best deep dish in town. I'm not a deep dish person but when in Rome, right?  We came for dinner and there was quite the wait. We ended up finding seats at the bar so we ordered our pie. We shared the small which was more than enough. One slice filled me up and we actually had to take the rest home. Overall a good pizza joint.

We ordered a pizza for delivery and the order was wrong / the delivery driver had no change thus making it difficult to give her a tip . The pizza was doughy / it looked like a mess when we opened the box . The charred crust was tasty but that was about it . Gino's and Lou's much better in my opinion . What a disappointment - maybe it's better dining in but delivery was not good

I hosted my birthday here last night and requested a table for 10 a few days prior to the day at 7pm on a Saturday (a very busy time). I received a confirmation within 20 mins. I then wanted to increase the reservation by 2 and also received a quick confirmation. Upon arriving with many people waiting, we were seated right on time. It made my birthday experience great and is much appreciated. I highly recommend this place and also utilizing the prioritized seating request. Lastly, the pizza and service was great as always! Thank you!
Great pizza! I take all my out of town guests here when the visit. Its a laid-back bar atmosphere, not too loud, and always busy.

My rating is based on the delivery ordering experience.  I called in to place an order and was greeted by a very rude and impatient employee on the other end of the line.  Someone having direct communication with customers should have better customer service than what I received.  The experience was so awful that it left a distasteful flavor in my mouth before even trying Pequod's for the first time, which I was super excited for.  To make matters even worse, they got the address wrong so the poor delivery driver had to turn around to get back to my  apartment.   The pizza crust bottom was soggy by the time we got to enjoy the pizza, over an hour later.  The za was decent but nothing extraordinary.  I'll try Pequods another time as a dine in customer and hopefully have a better experience, but in the mean time I'll keep exploring other pizza options.
Excellent - fav deep dish in Chicago. A place locals go, or so I;m told.
I expected so much more for all of the hype attributed to their deep dish pizza. Our family aren't huge deep dish fans, however, this seemed like toppings on garlic bread - simple.

My girlfriend and I had a bad experience here a few months ago, and I posted about it on Yelp. Within minutes, the manager emailed me to apologize for what happened and told us to come back whenever we wanted and that he would buy us dinner.  We did that tonight - and everything was excellent (and free). My girlfriend and I split the Pequod's salad and kept it simple with the pizza (large deep dish wish pepperoni and sausage). We have plenty of leftovers for tomorrow, and the staff and managers couldn't have been nicer to us. I've been to this location probably a half dozen times and will continue to go in the future. Thanks, Pequod's, for your excellent customer service! (And pizza!)

I don't care for deep dish pizza, however the bf swears by this place so I had high expectations. First bite, not really impressed. The bottom of the pizza was kind of hard, not sure what that was about. We did pick up a to go order and ate it about 30 mins later, not sure if it would be any better if we ate it right then and there. I have yet to find a deep dish pizza that I like, will continue the search and maybe one day find a place.
Well worth the wait for dining in or delivery. Their crust is perfect, I'm not a big fan of deep dish so the fact that it is a bit thinner being a pan crust its just delish!

Have to admit that this place knows what it is doing when it comes to pizza! I've had the big name deep dish pizzas around Chicago and none of them compare! Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to this amazing pizza!!!!

The pizza was good. Service was as well, the waitress was nice. I got the personal pan with pepperoni and it was the perfect amount! I asked for fresh basil after I placed the initial order. The server told me it would make it on the pizza, but it didn't. Other than that, everything went great! I arrived on a Monday at 10:00 pm, so there was no wait for a table.  I don't know if I'd ever wait over 30 minutes for a seat like some of the other yelpers have indicated. The dining room/ambiance is nothing special, so I'd just get it to go at that point.
