Best Deep Dish in Chicago!  If you're from STL try their ranch as your new favorite dipping sauce!  Their delivery time of 1hr/45 minutes always seems standard & to be expected, however patience is a virtue & it's 100% worth the wait!  I love getting Sausage, Spinach & Garlic Deep Dish with the slightly burnt crust it comes with & it's delicious dipped in ranch ;)

Hands down the best pizza place in the entire city - and in the entire world in my opinion. The deep dish pepperoni pizza is absolutely to die for. When I bring people to Chicago this is the pizza place I take them to. Be prepared to wait a while for the pizza to come out.

BEST PIZZA PLACE HANDS DOWN. I have lived in Chicago my whole life, and this is the best!! Awesome atmosphere and when you call ahead they will put you first on the waiting list. I'd recommend calling a few hours before you get there- don't just show up, the wait is usually over an hour!

Just starting off that this is my favorite deep dish pizza place. Great pizza! I go pretty often but this is the second time in which I had very poor service. We ordered 1 10" pizza that took an hour and half to make. And the server only came to our table once even though she kept going up to every table around us, it was really odd. She only came when the pizza arrived (someone else brought the pizza and served it to us.) and she noticed that our waters were empty. So for the entire hour and half that we were waiting for our pizza, she didn't come up to our table. Our pizza also ended up burnt and I to flag the waitress down to tell her. Manager took it off the bill and gave use a gift card though. Staff just didn't really seem apologetic to be honest. No thank you or sorry when we left, waitress just handed us the gift card because we got up from our table. Note this is the second time I received bad service (there's another yelp review about that experience from someone else).

Out of all the highly rated deep-dish spots we bookmarked ahead of time prior to visiting Chicago, this was our favorite pie.  It's a no frills type place and the wait can be easily over an hour and the pies take a bit to come out as well, but this is one place where the wait is worth it.  Our pies had a great crust, perfect amount of sauce, cheese and toppings, would definitely visit again-well worth the hype.

New favorite pizza place in the city! Although the wait times can be lengthy around lunch time the wait is completely worth it! The lunch special is a wonderful deal and pequods offers a nice selection of drinks and desserts. The only downsides I can think of the is the long wait time for the food (pan pizza takes a long time to make) and the low light. Will be back soon whenever I'm in Lincoln park!

I've tried this restaurant once due to a friend's glowing recommendation, and was severely disappointed. We ordered delivery, so in fairness I haven't tried in person, but to say the order was botched would be an understatement.  My fiancé and I ordered two pizzas and a salad.  She is a vegetarian, so naturally we ordered a vegetarian friendly pizza.  Her pizza came overly dry, with very little sauce, and cold veggies.  My pizza came with burnt crust, and very poorly distributed sauce and ingredients.  The salad never came. The driver didn't alert me to it, and when I asked where it was he blamed the kitchen and said he only takes what they give him and doesn't have time to confirm the order. He offered me the cash equivalent to the salad since I paid with a card, and that he couldn't run the salad back to me since he was too busy.  Is this what you call customer service?  I called and asked for the manager. She replied with "what would you like us to do, we're busy".  What I would like is for you to take a basic level class in customer service and give a customer what they pay for.  She was useless and unapologetic.  Do not recommend. Won't be trying them again.

Really great pizza and they give you huge portions. I especially like the crunch texture of the crust. The wait time is a little long for their signature pan pizza, approximately 45 minutes, but it's worth it!  The staff is super friendly and accommodating. In fact, when we had some left over and wanted to go watch a movie across the street, they let us keep our pizza in their fridge till we were done with the movie.  This is definitely a place I'd go to again if I'm in town. Fully recommended!
In my opinion, best pizza in Chicago. I love the crust and I would recommend it to anyone! May take a bit long but definitely worth it.

Holy cow. I finally tried Pequods pizza after living in Chicago almost my whole life. What took me so long. My 21 year old daughter and i had the day together today and she wanted to try it. It was amazing. The burnt cheese crust was something amazing and absolutely delicious. Perfectly cooked.  The restaurant is really cool inside. Ambiance is terrific. It looks small when you walk in but they have multiple seating areas. Parking is a challenge but well worth it. Service was a little slow as our server wasn't as attentive as you would like, but the food really made up for it. Prepare to wait to be seated at peak times. Go on off hours to get in and out faster. I can't wait to go back again...

A place to drink socialize and eat Pizza is no worthy of the title chicago deep dish Medicinal taste Slapped together with conflicting mix of flavors  Crust was crunchy but lacked the taste of Lou Malanattis Not worth the wait or $$

The day after Christmas many restaurants were closed. So I'm sure that a very brisk carry out business coupled with a completely full house had a bit to do with our 30-minute wait for a table plus an hour-and-a-half wait for our pizza. Terrific pizza, slightly overdone. Nice service in a difficult environment. Respectable beer menu. Worth 2-1/2 hours of our lives? No, not really. 4.75 rating with a reasonable wait.

Hard to top this place when it comes to deep dish.  Had it for game 7 of the 2016 World Series- so maybe its just referred joy... In all truth, Pequod's is worth the wait if you are in the mood for deep dish.
Omgosh, can you say scrumptious!! Seriously, this deep dish pizza is to die for. Great service, good ambiance, and deliciously tasting pizza. You absolutely must try it. I can't wait to be back!
By far the best deep dish pizza in Chicago!! Blows the competitors out, but keep in mind this shows in the delivery time! Be ready to order 2 hours before you want some pizza!

Was seated immediately and the staff was great and got us our beverages quick. We ordered 2 personal pan pizzas which was more than enough. Be prepared to wait around 40 minutes to get your pizza, you will understand why it took so long once you see it. I got pepperoni, hamburger and extra cheese and It was delicious. The cheese was caramelized golden brown on the sides and that's why the crust was my favorite part. The hamburger was literally a burger they cooked then cut up in big chunks and put on the pizza. Great environment and made us feel like we were where the locals were in Chicago.  BEST PIZZA I HAVE EVER HAD.

Worst service I've ever had! I used to be a server for years so I am very understanding. We had a reservation for 6:30 and they told us it would be a half hour wait! Then after an hour and 25 minutes we asked to order our pizza at the bar till we got our table. They refused and "said" we were the next table. I asked to speak to the manager and he was so rude to my friend. He even said, "you need to take your friend out of here." I have never experienced such horrible service. Be honest with your costumers and kind when you totally mess up and lie :(

What a fun and lively place to go out to eat for some classic Chicago style zaaa! I arrived with a group of 4 on a Tuesday night. Pequod's was busy (as to be expected). We were able to get our first round of drinks from the bar while we waited to be seated. I was very content with the speed of the service from the bartender. Once we were seated, the waitress greeted us promptly and helped us with the menu a bit. She was quick and efficient. Over all the service was immaculate for how busy the restaurant was. Well done.  Now on to the food. We ordered bruschetta, wings, and a 12" traditional style pizza with spinach, onion, green pepper and onion. The bruschetta was buttery and light. The wings had a killer buffalo sauce that I would like to purchase to my own use at home. The deep dish pizza was to die for. The crust was super crispy but the dough and cheese in the middle was warm and gooey. Perfect for a cold winter night. Something about their recipe just screams true Chicago deep dish.  I would recommend this place to anyone who's got a craving or wants to show some out of towners how Chicago does pizza.

Crust is my favorite. I keep going back and forth between this and Lou's being my favorite. Pizza alone, Pequod's may win, but sides and salads don't compare to Lou's. Wish they had more locations...must try for deep dish.

Everyone loves their thin crust pizza.  Many I know say it's the best in Chicago.  That's high praise.  It has almost a cult following.  I like it a lot.  I also like some other places for thin.  (This isn't Neapolitan thin, but just regular thin)

Best deep dish in Chicago, and one of the Chicago spots I miss most since moving out west.  It takes forever, as good deep dish tends to, but Pequod's takes waiting to another level. Luckily there are some ways to get around this: a) arrive early, or go on a weeknight; or if there's a wait, put your name in and b) head to the co-owned bar up the street for drinks and appetizers or c) hang by the bar in Pequod's and grab a brew while you wait.  I've done both b) and c) and recommend b) because you can actually sit down, and the wait can stretch up to 2hrs. After you brave the gauntlet of waiting, being seated, and deciding what you want to order, the pizzas are hefty and delicious--two mediums will feed four hungry adults and there will still likely be leftovers. It's not a sports bar but there are some TVs which was great for watching the Cubbies in the NLDS one night I went. Love Pequod's!

I ordered delivery on a medium deep dish pizza upon recommendation from a friend. I'll break this review into two parts: Food and Delivery/Service. Food: This place does a good deep dish. The outer crust is crispy to a point where it's almost burnt (in a good way) and the sauce and toppings they use are solid. If food was the only category to judge in picking a restaurant, I would give this place 4 stars. Delivery/Service: There is much left to be desired here, hence the overall 2 star rating. I had ordered delivery at 5:37pm hoping I would avoid the dinner rush. They quoted me 1.5 hours and asked what specific change I needed since I was paying in cash. I responded with $10 so I could give $41 (2 $20's and a single I had) for my ~$25 medium pizza; this would have resulted in a ~$6 tip which to me is fair. Here is where it goes bad, the delivery didn't show up until after 8pm (2.5 hours after ordering) and the driver only brought 5 singles so they forced my hand into tipping $10. Normally not a big deal, but being forced to tip 40% on late delivery seems wrong to me. I called the restaurant to understand what went wrong and the woman that answered could not have cared less and explained that late delivery was normal for them. Maybe just tell your customers up front it's up to them to find correct change and that your food will show up at some point that night...  Given there are many places in Chicago that have good deep dish, good service, and on-time delivery, I would recommend to take your business elsewhere.
Best deep dish in Chicago. Maybe the world. Long wait times but it is worth every minute. A must every time I'm in the Windy City.

I had the pan pizza it was pretty good. All the appetizers I had were good but the chicken tenders were cheap horrible processed ones. Drinks are reasonably priced and good service. Overall good place to check out. Would of gave 4 stars if it wasn't for those disgusting chicken tenders.

I hate deep dish. I don't care for it. I don't like all the cheese, the sauce, and the bread. BUT, Pequod's is THE ONLY place I will eat deep dish at. They do it the best! TIP: If you're going on a Saturday night, make sure you get there early, we got there around 5:30pm and we still waited about 20-30 minutes for a table. The environment is loud and busy, so if you wanted a "romantic quiet sit down," this is not the place for you. Anyways, the pizza is made fresh and will take about 40+ minutes until you get it, but I must say IT IS WORTH THE WAIT. I shared a small with another person, and it was enough since I personally don't eat much. I had 1.5 slices and I was quite full.  Their service is amazing as well, our waitress was super nice and attentive even though it was so busy inside.  LOVE LOVE LOVE Pequod's. BEST deep dish in the city, hands down!
Very delicious pizza with generous amount of cheese and perfectly seasoned. They crust is so crunchy and tasty. Absolutely one the bests in town. Only downside long time of service.
Favorite pizza place in Chicago. Can't get enough of the Pan pizza... drool

Pequod's pizza is cheesy goodness. Thin crust or pan pizza, you really can't go wrong at Pequod's.  Bonus: get the mozzarella sticks. For some reason, I think they're better here than anywhere else in the city.

One of the best pizza places in the city for deep dish or pan pizza. Make sure to bring plenty of friends because, speaking from personal experience, there is no way just two people could eat one of their medium sized pan pizzas. It is usually quite crowded on weekends or game nights so be prepared to wait a bit, but the wait will most definitely be worth it.

Getting deep dish in Chicago was a no brainer for me during my first trip to the city. With so many choices and opinions, it was hard to choose which one to try. After some recommendations and online reviews, we decided to try Pequod's. I was pretty much sold when I heard 'caramelized cheese crust' (a specialty of theirs).  For appetizers, my friends and I got the cheesy garlic bread which is super cheesy (!!) with the right amount of garlic and butter, it was a great way to trigger our appetite while waiting for the pizza. I've been warned by locals that the pizza at Pequod's is delicious but not the best representation of a Chicago-style 'deep dish' pizza, and I can see why. The crust is best described as a thick crust and the pizza itself was not the "so deep you'll get lost in the ooey gooey layers of melted cheese and toppings" kind of deep dish. Because of this, my boyfriend was not too impressed. I, on the other hand, thought it was pretty good and would have no problem returning (but maybe after trying other deep dish spots). What made this pizza truly stand out and worth trying is the caramelized cheese crust. The cheese added a nice texture and salty/cheesy flavor to the dish. Overall, the pizza is a solid 4 and the crust, 5 -- I mean, who doesn't love burnt cheese?

One of my favorite places for pizza. Deep dish. Thin. You name it. It's freakin' delicious. Whenever someone is new to Chicago and asks what place is good for pizza. Say Pequod's. I love the buttery crust.. the edges are nicely caramelized and crispy.. The wonderful cheese to sauce to topping to dough ratio is just right. Their selection of craft beer is great to go with your hearty pizza too. It's Hawks season so when you go here on a weeknight expect it to be busy. I love this place. It's always satisfying.

Best deep dish pizza in the city of Chicago!  Buzzing and energetic atmosphere with a great staff and service.  Splitting a deep dish with another person is ideal so it's a great date spot (especially if it's a first date because its a fun, casual spot).  Also not a bad spot to go with a group of friends to watch the Cubs or Hawks.  If you haven't been here yet, you have to give it a try.

It was a new experience for me to tell people all across the city that I'd had pizza, and when they asked "where at" I said "Pequod's" and the response was *universal* approval. "You won't find better in the city. Good job." It was almost as if people were surprised that I, some guy from Vegas, would be able to divine the local secrets of Chicago pizza. This place was awesome.  That's the important part. Second most important: you're going to wait for it. We put our names in and went down the street to a bar they had partnered with to wait, instead of just sitting around waiting for a table in the actual restaurant. They gave us a buzzer and we started drinking. About 80 minutes later, the buzzer went off and we headed back to our table.  We ordered garlic cheese bread for starters, and it was pretty good. I'd give it 4 stars if I had to grade the bread alone. It was still good, no doubt, the bread could have been a bit better if I had to pick one thing to improve.  After we ordered our pizzas, one thick and one thin crust, we waited again and ate our garlic cheese bread and drank our drinks. The pizzas arrived. I'm not a big fan of Chicago-style deep dish. I consider myself a thin-crust man. The thin crust is thicker than I expected, more of a "pan" style, "normal" thickness. The deep dish was exactly what I expected. Even though I'm not a deep dish person, I ate two pieces and had to stop myself from having a third lest I leave no room for the thin crust. The thin crust was excellent, and the thickness was deceiving: it was crisp and delicious even though a bit airy. I am a big fan of both these pizzas.  The toppings tasted great, the sauce was great, the service was pretty good. I'd come here again in a heartbeat. And I understand why everybody was so happy for me when I told them I'd come here.

Honestly, have gone here multiple times and it was delicious. We went last night and we're funneled next door to their new restaurant called whale tale? or something like that: so I guess this is more a review for that place. We were told they had the same pizza etc. Well, while the place was nice on the inside, but The pizza was AWFUL. Not sure how they did it, but managed to burn it on one side and the other side had a bunch of raw tomatoes and mushrooms on it. The pizza was flavorless, which is not the way I remember it. The waiter was super rude; when he asked if we wanted to take it home we said no it was not good, and he scoffed and was like, "well haven't you had our pizza before." And he brought it out any way and acted like we were dumb because we didn't like the pizza.

Called in for order..only gave my first name.. Kim.. it says Kim Nguyen on receipt. *kinda of racist..* came home and the pizza was not what I ordered. Called in to tell them and the host argued that my caller ID is showing Kim Nguyen.. the phone I'm using is not even the phone I used to call in for the order. This is crazy.... let's see if they actually gave me my refund.

After trying many pizza joints during my Chicago visit, I really enjoyed Pequod's pan crust deep dish style with the rising dough. Also, their crust had a nice crisp, burnt looking cheese crust along the edges. This was definitely my favorite deep dish style and one of my favorite deep dish pizzas I have had!

First time trying Hawaiian pizza and also this new place. I'm a stuff pizza kinda girl my goto place is Lou's but let me tell you this changed my world the crust is amazing just the way i like it brunt and crispy it's not as buttery as Lou's but it's amaze balls. I will def goo again and get a large deep dish instead of a personal size and re do the Hawaiian  pizza . And lets not talk about the sausage it was so good not your typically you find are you local pizza place. Can't wait to go back also the bartender JACK was great host also tried beer we never did before.

Well, this was a flat-out disappointment. I'd been hearing great things about Pequod's for years:  Hell, since before I even knew Yelp existed.  Now, I'm no Chicago deep-dish junkie--the dreadful Chicago-style place in my hometown kept me away from the stuff for years--but I've now visited the city enough times to have had several of these pizzas that I thought were terrific.  From what I gathered over time, Pequod's was supposed to be one of the two or three best.   To judge by the pie we had on this night, it fell sadly short of expectations.   The crust:  One-dimensionally crunchy and virtually flavorless. The sauce:  Insipid and bland. The veggie toppings:  Hacked up in unpleasantly large bites.  (The sausage was pretty good, though.) That heralded caramelized crust was pretty great, but it could not make up for the rest of this mediocrity of a pizza. Maybe this was just a dud, a bad night. We liked everything else about Pequod's:  The casual, cramped, old-school feel of the place; the friendly, if somewhat relaxed, service; the solid Italian salad we shared as an appetizer (very good housemade dressing); and the beer list. One day, I'd like to give Pequod's another shot.

Horrible customer service. The horrible women taking my order hates her job. Yelled at me and hung up on me. Horrible service for a supposed chicago establishment. If they don't care of staff training, they don't care about the guests. Arrogant place. Never again.
Omg I was referred to this pizzaria the pizza was not good at all they use phony pepperoni and their pizza sauce is to sweet.i just didn't care for it I had way much better pizza.
It was very good. I'm more of a "stuffed pie" guy than a "thick crust" guy, but better than Malnati's.

I came here on a Saturday, and it was packed! When we got there, there was a wait, but we were able to grab a drink at their associated bar two doors down. We had one drink there before our table was ready. We had the cheesy garlic bread and created our own pizza. The cheesy garlic bread was great, and while I am not the biggest fan of deep dish pizza, it was still some of the best that I have had!  It would have been nice if they had taken our order when we first got there and were waiting, as once we got seated upstairs it was about another hour until we got our pizza. Overall, good experience and I would definitely come again!

My first Chicago style deep dish pizza did not disappoint! The place is pretty divey and unapologetically so. Since the pizza itself was going to take about 30-40 minutes, we ordered their cheese bread to start. The cheese bread is almost artery clogging with the amount of cheese that they put on it and was the perfect size to share between three people without being too much.  We ordered a pepperoni, sausage, and basil pizza. The crust came out looking like it was burnt but it was just how they caramelized cheese. The crust itself was very crispy on the outside while fluffy and doughy on the inside. The addition of the caramalized/burnt cheese was definitely my favorite part of the pizza and was quite addicting! The pepperoni was pretty standard and I liked their sausage a lot better because it was more flavorful. The only real downside is that the pizza was mainly a really thick crust. Though it was tasty, I could only really get through one whole slice before being sent into a carb-induced food coma. Once we got over the intial wow-factor of the crispy cheese, we mainly picked away at the toppings of our next slices. Overall, I think Pequod's was a great introduction to Chicago deep dish for me and I can't wait to try other spots to be able to compare!

I've come to conclude that I am not a fan of Chicago style deep dish pizzas. So my rating remains neutral with Pequod's only because it was better than Giordano's pizza, but still failed to really impress me. I can't seem to figure out if you are to order, at most, 2 toppings or as many as you want. Because whatever we ordered with all those toppings (photo provided), it was not physically possible to pick up a slice and eat it with 1 hand, let alone 2 hands! I'm a grab-a-slice-and-go type of gal, and I couldn't figure out how to eat this except with a fork and knife. Which is fine. I can be a lady when needed. ;) But, again, it's just too overwhelming for my taste buds. And while others around us were devouring a whole entire pizza, we, sadly, couldn't get past a few bites. Honestly, it just seems like I'm just eating of bunch of baked/roasted pizza toppings and not an actual slice of pizza. There doesn't seem to be a balance between the dough, cheese, and toppings. Sad to say, I guess Chicago style deep dish pizzas and I are not meant to be~~

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago! It's truly everything you assume it would be. Be aware of a long wait ahead- usually about 1.5 hours. Also the pizza usually takes 40-45 minutes to make as well. Great option is to sit at the bar and eat there for quicker pizza eating. :)

***Pequod's Pizzeria is an okay deep dish pizza spot though I definitely prefer Lou Malnati's*** Pequod's is a pizzeria and bar located just outside of Downtown Chicago. You will have to take a taxi or drive to get there. It feels like you are in a Chicago institution once you step inside with the patrons, the small business look and the Chicago sports décor throughout the room. It has less of the touristy and restaurant chain touches / trappings of the more well-known Chicago deep dish spots. What Pequod's most excels at is their crust. It is a true pan pizza and has an exceptional caramelized crust. This caramelized crust does not just deliver a great crispiness to the pizza crust, but it also delivers a really addictive flavor. Pequod's burnt crust has the kind of distinction that Pizza Hut hopes to achieve with their pan pizza crust but does not. The sauce and toppings are all fine, but the center of the pizza has a lot of soft bread / crust, which keeps the pizza from being one of the best in the city. Service was fairly quick and friendly. Prices are okay given that the portions are generous and the pizza is so filling. I am not a huge deep dish pizza fan though it was nice to try a more local deep dish pizza spot in Chicago. It did not change my mind about deep dish pizza, but if you are a fan of deep dish pizza and live in the area, Pequod's is worth a try. I am not sure what the parking situation is, but it looked like there was free street parking in the area.

I've been coming here for decades and this was the first time I was completely disappointed.   An inch of dust on everything,  an apathetic staff, and food not up to par.  My pizza was just shy of being completely cooked.  My salad came out at the same time as the pizza but without any dressing.   One person got a pasta dish - a whopping one tablespoon of sauce and the bottom half of the bowl was full of water because the pasta was not not drained.  It was so bad I will try the suburban location for the first time next time I have a taste for pizza.

When I am craving pizza and happen to be in the city, I always head to Pequods! Located on the corner of Webster and Clybourn in LP, it is the perfect spot for Chicago style pizza.  My favorite thing to order is the pan pizza with extra sauce and tomatoes. The sauce is on the sweeter side, which I love! The appetizers are pretty good as well. The chicken wings and fried mushrooms are my favorite though.  Every time I've been there, the service is great. Friendly and fast!  I think Chicago wins with all the pizza choices, but Pequods is by far on top of the list!

This place would easily get 5 stars for the food. The pizza is delicious and I am hundreds of miles away and want to eat another one right now. However, the service is abysmal! Waited more than the 45 minute wait for 1 small pizza for pick up. Why on earth does it take that long? Actually, if I place my order now, it should be ready when I get there after a four hour flight  Pizza is good, but be prepared to wait and wait and wait. I would go there when you think you'll be hungry in an hour or so. Do not go there when you are already hungry, or you will be miserable.

I'm not sure I can put into words... just how amazing this place is. The crazy part is, this wasn't going to be our stop for the day. We were trying a different pizza place... they said the wait was 3 hours, and we just couldn't wait that long. Pequod's got us seated in under 20 minutes and what followed was possibly the best pizza experience I've ever had. The pizza was fabulous. Pan pizza, caramelized cheese around the crust, and the flavor was out of this world. We will be returning to eat here again, wouldn't think twice about it. Also, the staff was very friendly.

To this point, this is my favorite deep dish of all time. We got half cheese / half pepperoni and both halves were awesome. I get why some people are mixed on the thicker crust, but I love it, and the burnt ends are incredible. The whole thing was really kind of perfect, in my opinion.

Pequod's food is pretty good, not near the rep, and service is pretty wack a lot of the time. I know they're busy, but it's just pointlessly chaotic and kind of rude a lot. Last straw was waiting 45min only to find we'd crossed off the list accidentally...and being told it'd be another hour.  Ha ha!  Thanks anyway.
This is hands down my most visited spot for deep dish whenever I have guests in town or just for myself because it's that's good. Don't even think hat other spots could be compared to this one.

My 2nd favorite pizza place next to Giordonos! Came in on a Sunday night around 7PM and wait was about 15 minutes. I really like the bar vibe at this restaurant and sports playing in the background. Pizza was amazing! took about 40-45 minutes to bake a deep dish and they are super generous with the topping you order. Service was good too, nothing to complain about! definitely make a visit!

I've heard a lot of great things about this place - specifically the caramelized crust.  So naturally, I had to check out one of the great Chicago pizza joints while in Chicago.   The wait wasn't too bad - approximately 30 minutes on a Sunday night.  We were seated upstairs.  My only regret is that we weren't able or asked to order ahead of time.  These deep dish pizzas take a long time to cook/bake.  When the pizza arrived..... disappointment.  The caramelized crust just reminded me of BURNT crust.  The pizza was so doughy.  Toppings were sparse.  A centimeter of toppings and cheese, on top of an inch of dough.  Atkins lovers would cry. Now, it's not terrible pizza.  I still ate it.  But given all the other Chicago style pizza joints in Chicago, I wouldn't come here if I was here on vacation for just a few days.

Overlooked gem in the ever-ongoing question of Chicago pizza. Caramelized pan crust is unlike anything else in the city. Those who know, know, so be prepared for a long wait on weekends and Hawks games. Drop by the Drinking Bird for a cocktail afterward, or catch a movie across the street, for a great night out.
Bomb pizza! Kinda reminds of pizza huts pan pizza the way the crust is. Highly recommend!

As a life-long, hardcore Lou's devotee, it's hard for me to admit that this is Chicago's best pizza. Malnati's is great, but this is truly unique and truly amazing. Service was a little off the night I went in, and the wine list is pretty bad, hence the four stars, but the crust on the pizza, the crust, man! The delicious crust is to die for.

Winter is coming, and what better way to prepare for hibernation with a delectable dairy dish! The deep dish pizzas are worth the wait at this hole in the wall sports bar in Oldtown Chicago. These heaping mounds of sauce, cheese, and your choice of toppings are definitely not what the Italians envisioned when they invented the first pizza. Order your choice of a small, medium, or large platter either to share or devour yourself. But beware, this decadent dish packs a punch. I've seen many a ill-fated customer loosen 1 or 2 belt buckles after trying to conquer these savory behemoths. What I recommend you to do is gather 2 of your most lactose tolerant friends, order yourselves a medium deep dish with sausage, green peppers, and of course, Pequods own freshly grown Chicago basil and prepare for a scrumptious dish.

I have never dined in, and can only speak for delivery. But if delivery pizza is this good then I can only assume it's the same as dining in. I absolutely love their deep dish! The crust and bread is ridiculously buttery and worth the calories. I like to get the deep dish with pepperoni, with green and red peppers. Tell them to make the pizza well done- gives it that extra crisp!

This was the worst pizza ever. Ever, in history of pizzas or pizzerias.  My family and I tried to get in once since they were highly recommended after a movie at Regal, they were too busy and not friendly at all. This week, we went and finally made it! No line around 5ish pm. We had a small pan for 2 and after eating 2 small pieces, I could not move and breath the entire evening. I felt so heavy and bloated! I read the reviews and one woman was saying they don't let the crust mature and that makes you bloated, which makes sense. Basically the pizza was not done at well. It was like eating semi done crust where the cheese did not even melt. The toppings were not evenly distributed. The waitress was so indifferent, as most of the stuff, some college not caring kids. Bathroom was clean and that's the best of all, OMG. I want my money back, yes, I do. So worthless!!!! P.S. The wine list does not exist. They serve wine, but you don't know what the choices are and how much does it cost. Ridiculous!

This place is legitimately one of my favorite places to get deep dish pizza. Their crust is light and buttery, but the burnt cheese crust that you save for last is the best part.  Also, their service is great. Everyone is nice and friendly; they do their part to make you feel at home.

We called for priority seating here on a Saturday night (they don't take reservations), and still had quite the wait, but it was worth it! The food was fantastic. We ordered jalapeño poppers, which were great and only took about 10 minutes to get to our table. The pizza took longer, about 45 minutes after our already two hour long wait. But the pizza was fantastic. It's not quite true Chicago deep dish- the crust is pretty thick- but we still loved it.  I'm holding back on 5 stars because service was a little chaotic. Our waitress was nowhere to be seen most of the time, and it took a while to get our waters.

Yeah, I just don't get it. The pizza is an amorphous entity where it is unclear where the crust ends and the rest begins. Definitely pan pizza and not deep dish. And more importantly, just not very flavorful.
Delicious deep dish pizza!! We ordered and got it delivered and the delivery was pretty speedy for Deep dish. Would definitely have it again.
Waited 30-45 minutes never got paged so went inside and was told I would be seated next and they proceeded to seat a table of 6 and one before me and the manager didn't seem to care at all
Great pizza! Had it at 2:00am and thought it was way better than Giordano's! Pequod's is great!

I've been to Pequod's a few times before and was excited to go with some friends who were in from out of town this weekend.  We arrived at 4:30pm on a Saturday and were a bit surprised to find there was already a 30 - 45 minute wait for a party of 5. (This was the point we should've just gone somewhere else.) We were seated at 5pm and ordered our pizza and an appetizer around 5:15. No one mentioned a longer wait time on food that evening. The appetizer came out almost immediately and then our server all but disappeared. Around 6:15 I was able to flag her down and ask if she knew the status of our pizza, expecting it to be up soon. She came back about five minutes later to tell us she wasn't sure what had happened but a manager would be coming. A manager then came with nothing to report, returning again to tell us that the ticket was lost, they didn't do it on purpose, and it would be out in ten minutes. He also vented to us about their three hour wait for a table. (Uh, maybe because you can't keep orders straight in your kitchen?) When a member of our group expressed his frustration, he said he'd "do something for us" on the bill. Look, I've worked in the service industry. I get that people make mistakes. But the manager couldn't even be bothered to apologize!  Our food eventually came about 90 minutes after we ordered it, and the pizza was good, but it wasn't worth the inattentive service and long wait. Aaaaaand then the bill came -- with no discount given despite the manager's promise to do something for us. We paid it all and just left because we were all ready to go home at that point. It'll be a long time before I visit again.

After reading the reviews for a few different pizza places, my boyfriend and I decided to check out Pequod's while in town last night.  We got there around 5:15 on a Thursday and were seated right away on the second floor where it is much calmer and quieter. When we left an hour and a half later, the place was packed and the downstairs was very noisy. So yes, get there early if you don't want to wait!  We ordered two appetizers to hold us over while the pizza was cooking: jalapeño poppers for him ($7) and half order of hot wings for me ($5). My wings were very good- spicy and plenty of meat on them. Plus they give the option of ranch or blue cheese which was nice and also novel for me because at many upstate ny places it's blue cheese or nothin' and I'm not a fan. I'm not sure how long the pizza took but it didn't seem long at all because it came out very soon after we finished with the appetizers... perfect timing!  We got a 10" deep dish pizza with pepperoni and black olives (~$15). My boyfriend wasn't sure about getting the small pizza to split for fear of not having enough, but it was plenty! We actually each could only eat about one and a half slices- and there were four all together. The pie itself was very tasty. Crunchy and chewy crust, lots of toppings, tangy sauce and I actually really liked the toasty burnt cheese ring around the crust which is their specialty.  I realized that deep dish is not my favorite--- I'm a thin crust girl at heart! But I'm glad I gave it a shot and I don't think there's a better place than Pequod's to do it.

Everything was stellar except that their crust is waaaaaay too thick, even if their cheese, sauce and toppings are on the generous side, as well.  I am impressed that despite the thickness of the bread, it was not in any way soggy from the other ingredients piled on top of it. Meatball topping is great. I just cannot abide by their thick bread.
Best deep dish pizza in Chicago. I love the crust and how its slightly burnt. No other pizza is comparable any where. Expect long waits on weekends and game night. parking can be difficult too.

Well, this was a pretty solid pizza. Arrived at 6:45p on Sunday night. There was a hawks game on.  The wait was approximately an hour. We ended up finding a bar seat.   The wait for pizza was advertised at 50 minutes but ours arrived after about 35 minutes.  In the meantime we ordered a Peqoud Salad (half size), which was more than enough for 2. Also ordered a tasty 3 floyds beer. Only 4 tap selections, but at least a couple were craft.  The pizza was excellent. It had melted cheese on the side edge that was a little burnt and tasty. We also got meatballs and spinach on it. Both great options.
Deep dish pizza with a unique crust. Good food, with inexperienced staff.

I had been meaning to come to Pequod's for the longest time and finally made it here on a Monday night.  Pro tip: Go on a weekday.  We were seated immediately.   My fiancé and I split a deep dish pizza, and it was quite tasty.  Not mindblowingly great enough for me to make the trek back up to Pequod's soon (I live within walking distance of a Gino's, Giordano's, and Lou's), but I certainly enjoyed myself.  The service was kind, and restaurant's atmosphere was comfortable but nothing special.  I would return if in the area!
Not my fav chicago style but good.  3.5

Pequods is not a competitor to Malnatti's, Gino's, uno's.   Pequods has their own thing going.  It's not exactly that different from the aforementioned kings of chicago deep dish, but it is.  It's unique, and qualitatively very good. In your deep dish quests, pequods is a must try, as for some it will be the best, others will never like any more than Malnatti's. Also, please don't even mention giordano's.

I read all the reviews this morning, called ahead and ordered a deep dish veggie pie. The reviews gave me so much anticipation and when I arrived, the service was expeditious and courteous. However the pizza was so MEH. Idk why, maybe I expected sobering other worldly? The cheesy part of the crust was great, the sauce good, toppings were fine. The dough sucked tho, I wasn't really feeling the entire thing. Oh well, next time I'm in Chicago I'll try another!
Pequod's is amazing. Perfect crust, not too doughy like some others, probably my #2 favorite pizza place in Chicago. Worth a try!
Waited almost an hour for pizza, which it was burnt all around the crust... you be the judge
So good! Best deep dish. So oily and full of delicious unhealthiness that though I did indeed have a second slice I should've stopped at the first.

Wow, that is an excellent pizza. Believe the hype folks.  We ordered a meatball and gardinera pan and it was delicious.  No wait, on a Saturday afternoon.  Wife says we'll be back to try the thin crust too.

Can't go wrong with the lunch special for around $5.00. Good solid flavor, some people complain about crust but the crust to typing ratio is atl balanced. A must try for any friends or family in from out of town or first date.

Went here for the first time this week. A friend and I wanted to get a pizza, and we had both heard some pretty good things about Pequods and decided it was time to give it a try.  There was a half hour wait which is to be expected. We were given one of those timed buzzers and headed to a bar a few doors down. After 30 minutes it was finally our turn to get a table.  We were lead upstairs and wow- this place is unsuspectingly huge. They occupy the full two floors of this building, AND there's still a wait on a Wednesday. I'm assuming that means they're crazy good.  Most of the tables upstairs are smaller bar top tables, perfect for two people max, so I can imagine it gets really cramped, fast.  The menu is simple; your typical pizza-place type of menu- apps, salad, pasta, pizza. They have a full bar and a pretty basic beer list. Think Miller Lite and Stella Artois.  The pizza toppings are pretty simple. No specialty pizzas, just classic Chicago pan pizza.  We ordered a medium pan pizza with mushrooms, basil and giardiniera. The medium comes with 6 slices (small comes with 4- which is perfect if you don't want the left-overs because we only ate 4/6 of our slices). Overall the service was okay. The waitress was polite but not very attentive. The staff may also share tables because we had at least three different people attend to us over the course of our meal.  The pizza itself was good, but not the best I've ever had.  The crust from Pequods is definitely what stood out to me, aside from the hour wait we had for it to just show up at our table. Ahh- the half hour wait for a table is all making sense to me now.   Basically they're average at best. But I appreciate how they've kept their business simple and fussy free.

AMAZING. Seriously, if you are in Chicago and do not go here you are missing out. Me and my friend went here (world series weekend) on Saturday. We went on the website and requested a table for 2 at 4:30 p.m. about a week prior. When we got there we were immediately seated. I highly suggest you do that, the website claims it cuts the wait time in half. I know this place is always crowded so I was super happy when we were seated right away. We probably picked an early enough time. The place was pretty packed. When we were seated we ordered our pizza immediately (since the wait for a pizza can be up to 2 hours - ours was 2.5 hours). We also ordered fries and mozzarella sticks as apps, good choice because we were STARVING and smelling pizza and seeing people eat around you was not helping the wait. Oh boy I just wanted my pizza lol.  We were told to order extra sauce, and thank the lord we listened to that kind gentleman because when our pizza came out it was AMAZING. We got a medium, extra sauce and pepperoni. I seriously am craving this pizza as I'm typing this it is that good.  Any and every time I am in Chicago I will go to pequods. Seriously, it is that good and 100X better than the other chain pizza places (Giordanos and Lou Malnatis) I've tried them all and Pequods is by far the best.  EVERYONE GO TO PEQUODS!

This was by far the worst experience I have ever had with a restaurant. The customer service was terrible. I ordered delivery and had to repeat myself and spell everything out, which I was fine with to assure I got my food even though my address was not very difficult. I initially told my address the first time to see if we were located within the delivery zone. I waited the 1.5 hours that was quoted and still had not received it so I called. They had me repeat my address again multiple times and said it was out for delivery and would be here in 5-10 minutes... the time went  by and it still hadn't arrived... My boy friend called again and they said they had no record of the order.. then when asked to speak to a manager continuously put him on hold and did not put a manager on. Finally a manager came on again asking for the address and then said that the phone number and address were both wrong and that is why we didn't get our pizza. The manager did not even apologize. I would not recommend this place. The next battle will be getting my money back.

I've never had an issue with the wait, and it's right across from the Barnes and Noble I frequent and Wegster theater. I think the longest I've ever waited was fifteen minutes despite everyone always saying it's a long wait (lucky timing, mayhaps?).  I got the sampler platter once which was "meh", but what you're really there for is the pizza, I imagine. I've had the pineapple and ham, the sausage and mushrooms (and I usually hate mushrooms) and a few other combinations and always have to force myself to stop eating so I don't puke from being so full. The wait staff kind of leaves you alone unless you look like you need something (in a good way, I'm never glancing around for the waiter in desperation for a refill or something equally insane). Personally I don't buy the "crisped" edge thing. It tastes burnt but hey, I eat the hell out of it. Everyone else likes that blackened crust (which they do on purpose, it's not a fluke or an excuse) thing but I could do without, personally. But, I know I'm getting it when I order and I keep going back so I've gotta be a little bit of a hypocrite because Pequod's is one of my go-to's.

This is the best pizza I have ever ate and I have ate a lot of pizza.! The crust is like no other. I disagree with some previous reviews I read stating you need to ask for extra cheese and sauce, the pizza was perfect.

I absolutely loved this place! I love deep dish pizza and compared to other restaurants like Lou Malnatis and Giordanos, Pequods definitely wins. The place was pretty packed, probably because of the bears game or the fact that it was Halloween, but we called ahead to make sure they had a table and were seated immediately! The service was quick! I was really impressed! Can't wait to go back again. Definitely recommend this place!

Oh, deep dish. Tried 'em all, including now the locally-recommended Pequod's. Cheesier than others, bottom crust a bit thicker, and it sticks together better than most -- but it's also pricier than most, and with it comes a wait time longer than most. Maybe I just don't like deep dish that much. Thin pizza was below par. At least the employees were all super nice?
Love the pizza here. I don't know if it was because I was ravenous or that the food was really that good but I dream of Pequod's pizza all the time!

I think this is actually a long-running Punk'd type thing, where they must be filming people waiting forever and then pretending to like the worst pizza I've ever had (worse than Papa Johns).   Yeah the crust gets caramelized into whatever is stuck on the bottom of your oven.  You can eat that with no wait, just grab a spatula and get at your oven!! I do not get the hype.  Giordano's for life.

I went to Riot Fest 2016 and I wanted to have chicago pizza before I went home. After doing some research, I saved this place on my phone and on my last day in Chicago, I went here and it was the best pizza I've ever had in my life. I still dream about it! I can't wait to go back to Chicago and have pequods.

Woman on the phone on Saturday night October 29 has the WORST customer service I have ever experienced. I called 4 times because each time I called it would ring and then just start beeping. If you answer a phone, you at the very least, tell the customer please hold, not just automatically put them on hold. On the fourth time I called, after sitting on hold for almost 5 minutes on the third time I called, she was just so rude. Don't be a hostess, or even a person dealing with customers in any manner, because just being kind can go a long way. I get that it's a Saturday night, and I get that it's a busy night, but if you are rude to people for no reason, you will not appreciate the way you are treated back. Pequods has pretty good pizza but every time I have dined in and done takeout/delivery, the service is just awful. I would've thought by now that after several online reviews, and I am sure in-person complaints, management would have taken steps toward improving the service.
I love Pequod's. It was my first meal when I moved to Chicago and my last meal when I left. It will always have a special place in my heart. That carmalized crust! Woo baby!
The carmelized crust is as good as they say... but the rest of the pizza is only good.  For my money, I prefer their thin crust. Beware LOOOOOOOOONNNNNGGGG lines to get in

I'm not a native Chicagoan, but to me this is the best pizza in Chicago. I'm not a fan of deep dish so Pequod's pan pizza is my go-to. Whenever friends or family come to visit we love having an excuse to get Pequod's. The dough has a great bite and the edges get caramelized to crunchy cheesy perfection.  I'm pretty sure it's understood in our house that stealing the amazing cheesy bit of crust from someone's slice is unforgivable. We always get their sausage as a topping. I think they make it themselves and it has so much fennel. Yum! Also - the salad! They cut the cheese into little whales. Love it.  The only advice I would give on this place is that the pizza is so much better if you go have it in the restaurant vs. delivery.

I love this place. This is my go to when out-of-town visitors want to truly experience Chicago deep dish pizza.  The pizza here is way better than Lou Malnati's and Giodano's. Worth coming out here and waiting in line in order to get your fix of delicious pizza. I usually go with basil, mushroom, and sausage, and I would highly recommend that combination. You will need a medium to feed about 3 people (each get 2 slices) - and trust me, you will be plenty full. Note this is deep dish, I have not given their thin crust a try.  I've converted so many people to Pequod's. It the true local Chicago deep dish pizza experience. My only complaint and the only thing that's holding Pequod's from getting a five star rating is the fact that the quality sadly is not consistent. There will be times when Pequod's completely knock the ball out of the park and give you an amazing pizza, but there are also other times when the crust is burnt or not fully cooked.  They don't take real reservations - you can call ahead but what happens is that you get to jump to the top of list, which will still require some wait (unlike most other restaurants, where you will have a table ready as soon as you walk in). I have ordered for pick-up in the past (it took about 50 minutes), but the pizza experience is not the same. That same day, delivery was about 2 hours. So I would plan ahead if you would like to order a pizza and eat from your home.  I would say to truly experience Pequods, you have to eat the pizza there. When it pops right out of the oven, it is amazing. The long wait is crazy. I have waited 2+ hours in the past. There is a Barnes and Nobles nearby and that's where I go to hang out while waiting. It's worth it and just do it!
Easily the best deep dish in Chicago. I don't recommend the sausage on their pizza, though.

On my flight over to Chicago I watched an episode of "Delicious Destinations" which was all about places to eat while in the City in which they recommended this place.  I was overly disappointed when coming here.  Service and everything was fine, but the sauce on the pizza was filled with entirely too many seasonings.  It reminded me of a marinara sauce made by someone who doesn't know what they are doing, I really didn't like it. Also- they are known here for this "signature" burnt cheese crust.  I can't understand for the life of me what makes it that special.  It tastes exactly like you would imagine, like burnt cheese.  I wouldn't waste my time coming here if you are visiting- stick with Lou Malnatis.

It's the CRUST!!!! and all the stuff on top of it. I love this place. I always take out of town visitors here. Pick your toppings, and go for it. The downside is for some reason here I always go for that extra slice that puts me over the edge of fullness. So good!
Was told to come here from a friend while visiting Chicago! wow this pizza is amazing!!!!!!!! Def go here if you want REAL Chicago style deep dish pizza

I currently live in NY but I'm not a thin crust die hard-- I actually prefer deep dish. More sauce, more cheese, even more bread, what's not to like?? But I was somewhat disappointed with Pequod's, which was recommended by multiple Chicago-resident friends. The fact is, I didn't think it was a great deep dish pizza, let alone a destination deep dish pizza. We ordered a cheesy garlic bread as an appetizer which I wholeheartedly preferred to the pizza. It was warm, melty, and garlicky, and suuuper cheesy. The pizza we ordered (which I also think is ridiculous that each topping is about an additional $2.00) was impressive in its presentation, but not as flavorful, and more bread than anything else, although the edges were crispy with crisp almost-burnt cheese. I thought it would be saucier and have a sort of doughy inner that kind of melded with the tomato sauce, with a crisp bottom, but I was sadly disappointed. The pizza does take a while to come out. Highly recommend getting an appetizer or two to hold you over. And definitely throw out your expectations of getting a nutritious, healthy meal if you're coming here. I felt my arteries clog just sitting in the place with all the scent and grease this place accumulated over the years.

On a recent visit to Chicago we were directed to Pequod's by a local rather than to more popular spots. We were not disappointed, the pizza was delicious and they have a great selection of beer as well.

I had my FIRST Chicago deep dish pizza here after my Chicago-resident friend had recommended it. The staff was friendly and accommodating to our large party. We ordered several pies and tried them with different types of toppings. Everything was delicious and I finally gained some insight into people's love for deep dish pizza.

I didn't enjoy the food here. Too much grease. I felt ill that evening through the next day and normally my stomach agrees with everything.  My friends love it. I didn't. Nice management and maybe I'm just an odd bird.
Best pizza in Chicago.  I make sure to bring all out of town guests here when they visit.

Chicago is the land of deep-dish pizza. And I can't stand it. The only time I would ever get deep-dish was when I had a friend in from out of town. Ever since I discovered the deliciousness that is Pequod's, it's not just the only pizza place I take friends too, it's where I like to go whenever I'm in the mood for a really good pizza pie. It's not deep dish. It's deep-pan pizza so, while the pizza is two inches thick, most of that is crust instead of normal deep dish sludge. And the caramelized crust is amazeballs.  I was surprised how divey it felt when I first walked in but I like that they let their food speak for itself. The cheesy garlic bread is a solid starter, and they typically have pretty good drink specials. I've actually never had to wait too long to get seated, but I've also usually been able to avoid prime dinner time. The one time I had to wait at all, I was able to grab a drink at the bar next door while I waited for my buzzer, so no harm no foul.

I dislike most of the pizza in Chicago. I never seek it out and rarely enjoy it. The style is so, so hard to get right and most places aren't consistent at all. It makes pizza reviews rather ephemeral. Pequod's is my favorite of them all.

We are from Miami and wanted to go to where the locals have deep dish pizza. Luckily one of our uber drivers suggested Pequods and let me tell you it was SPECTACULAR. People say it's more of a pan pizza, but to me it felt like a deep dish. Anyway way better then Giordano's which is where all the tourists go to. You can get decent deep dish pizza where the tourists tend to stay at but if you are willing to take a 15 mins uber drive from downtown to Pequods it will not disappoint!

First off: I think deep dish pizza is sort of like a very large hot pocket at best and a tomato soup in a soggy bread bowl at worst. SO, I'm a little biased because I'm not the biggest fan of deep dish.  That being said, I thought that the amount of food was fantastic. The portion size is fairly good, though it's not exactly "cheap eats" for 2. My boyfriend was disappointed in what he got for the cost, but he also couldn't stop comparing it to regular pizza in NY.  Pequod's felt different to me than Giordano's, and I appreciated the decor and the zombie Moby Dick theme, so for that alone, I think this place is solid.  I'm a huge fan of sauce, so I actually loved that there was a lot of it, and that's my favorite part about deep dish. The pan style pizza here is served in the pan, and the service was good. The crust is nice and burnt, just the way we all like it. It's not a ton of cheese but still plenty for you to feel like you're going to have a heart attack. I think it would've been awesome for a late night snack but unfortunately, we had too many meals planned to take any home or go back. I look forward to trying this place again next time around.

Came in a bit after midnight right after the Cubbies took game 1 of the NLCS - surprised that we did not have a wait. We were immediately seated and placed our order shortly thereafter. While it does take a bit of time to get your order out (I think anticipation makes the wait seem longer than it actually is) it was absolutely worth the wait! Can't wait to get back to Chicago soon and this will definitely be a place I would head back to everytime for deep dish.
Love their deep dish - if carmelized cheese and crust is your thing you'll love pequod's.

Over 3,000 reviews and over 1000 pictures - is this a tourist attraction or has this place been getting reviews since the beginning of yelp? As someone who has not tried chicago deep dish ever before, I was kind of disappointed. Was going to put 2 stars but since the description for "Meh, I've experienced better" doesn't apply to me since I've never had deep dish, decided to give it an "A-OK" rating. Don't get me wrong - i LOVE pizza, and I LOVE crust, but if all deep dish pizza is like the ones at Pequod's, then I may just be a thin crust fan. First of all, the caramelized crust just tasted like crispy crackers, and the crust in its entirety tasted like flavored croutons - super crunchy and not the stretchy, flavorful soft crust that I was expecting. Biting into a pizza I usually expect a chewy and yeasty texture to crust, but here the crust was more like...toast.  The toppings were good, they were pretty generous on the meat, and the cheese was wonderfully stringy and generous. Environment is amazing for watching sports (we came on the day that the Cubs won! haha this place is better for late night) and drinking beer, but if all deep dish has disappointing crust like this then maybe I'm just not a fan of deep dish pizza in general :(  Will try other deep dish places to compare!
Order the deep dish sausage pizza. They have other things on the menu, but if this is not part of your order, then don't even go here. It is sooooo good and nobody in chicago does it like them!!

Best deep dish I've had during my visit in Chicago! I def prefer it over Giordano's. The crust is crispy on the rim and bottom which makes a big difference for me. You have the option of toppings and size. The personal pizza was more than enough to fill my appetite! The bartender was super friendly, the vibe and atmosphere was chill and enjoyable. Def felt the Chicago spirit here. Sit at the bar for the ultimate experience!

After all the hype - pretty disappointing.  Been hearing about this place for years, I was expecting to be blown away - like my first bite of Lou's. The in-restaurant experience may be better but the take-home show was quite awful as far as the crust goes.  We had these lovely toppings....mushrooms, onions,  huge hunks of sausage - but when we got it home (a 5 minute drive)  it was just a pile of tasty ingredients displayed a top a warmish sponge.
A friend of mine introduced me to the spot. Good pizza place! I absolutely loveeee deep dish pizza, but I prefer their thin crust over their deep dish.
2 hr wait, then another 2 hr wait for food. Overhyped but still better than Giordano's by a long shot

Great food but staffs attention to a health code issue was just embarrassing. A vent covered in condensation dropped into our food & drinks. We stood up on top of the booth 3x to wipe it dry ourselves.

The pizza at Pequods was excellent. I enjoyed it so much. The Deep Dish I had was half pepperoni and sausgage and half pepperoni, sausage, olives and peppers! I reallly enjoyed it (Extra L for emphasis). The Deep Dish was more of a Pan Pizza which had a thick crust. For my first time having true Chicago Deep Dish pizza it was pretty good. Next time Im in Chicago Id like to have the Deep Dish slice that has the toppings in the center and bottom as opposed to the top. Back to Pequods though. The pizza was crunchy and the cheese was perfectly burned along the edges. I thought that it was great. The service was pretty good. The pizza did take a while to arrive, but Im starting to learn that pizza making is a bit of a slow art form. So overall this was great pizza. The toppings were tasty and the pepperoni was really good. Can't wait to get back to the Windy City to have some more. 5 Stars

I've heard from two sources now that this on of the best pizza places in Chicago. So me and my mom went and checked it out, we both not only disappointed but didn't like the ingredients. Sauce was off, cheese was off or maybe too much, ingredients were off, weren't great tasting and just didn't fit w/ the cheese and the sauce. So if you're from Chicago (tisk tisk... ), out of town, not only the typical popular chain restaurant Chicago pizza places, but if you want the low down from someone who's had great pizza places in multiple cities, you need to check out Coalfire, little bit east of Wrigley Field / East Lakeview, and Jim n' Petes, W. 'burbs / Melrose Park (hopefully they didn't change it). It's a also a pain to get to, not really close to public transportation and it's a little bit of a drive out there when there's better pizza downtown.

Why do people love this place?  After waiting WAY too long for our thin crust sausage pizza, something dry and with meatballs (I think) was delivered to our table. Is this what they use as sausage? This place was just gross on all levels: terrible food, an overmatched staff, not the best/cleanest digs, etc. The only thing it has going for it is that it is open late and is in a great location. Otherwise, this is probably the worse pizza I've ever had. Avoid--especially in a pizza town such as Chicago.
Hands down my favorite pizza in Chicago. It's a pan pizza with the mozzarella caramelized on the outside to form a crust. The pepperoni is good and crispy at the edges.
I love Pequod's pizza. It's totally unique in the world of pizza. The signature browned edge is great. I feel like I don't go there often enough.

I know people that love this more than anything. I personally do not enjoy this pizza. It lacks taste to me in addition to the burnt taste that accompanies the caramelized crust. Service when dining in was good, as was the lively enjoyable atmosphere.
Simply not all it's cracked up to be, dirty interior, pushy wait staff..... Hey Food Network, best pizza in Chicago; me thinks NOT.  This pizza is just okay.

It's not Chicago without pizza! I always thought Chicago was known for their deep dish pizza, but based of off every Lyft drivers I had, pan pizza is the new hype!  Pequod is located outside of downtown Chicago, so I made it a mission to try it during my short stay! The pizza price would be based off of number of toppings.  As suggested by our waitress, we got a medium for a party of three. We were worried that 8 slices were three was not enough, but after eating, we were glad we listened.  As shown in my pictures, the pizza has a lot of breading. A lot of reviews complained stating it's not deep dish, which is true. The menu clearly says pan- hence all the breading.  My only complaint is that it does take 25-30 minutes to make each pizza, so be prepared to wait!

I love Pequods. But I have a few reasons for not giving 5 stars, even though I want to. I am a vegan so I was DELIGHTED to find that I could eat their deep dish pizza. The crust is one of my favorites and the sauce is so flavorful that it makes me salivate like crazy. That is all I can comment on since I usually just get a completely plain pizza, no cheese. I could add veggies I suppose. The price is okay, deep dish is usually more $$. I wish they offered vegan cheese! Also, be prepared to wait a good 40 minutes or more. It is worth it. OH and there are two levels, it is quite a cosy place.

It's okay. The place is consistently packed with people coming & going and the pizza IS good, but it lacks when you compare it to some of the other pizza places on the south side (Nick & Vitos, Milano's, Russo's, Fox's, Beggar's, Giordano's). Because of this, I feel it is overpriced for what it is. I didn't like the northside yuppie crowd so much, but the service was pretty good despite it being constantly busy which was surprising! Kuddos to the servers for putting up with all that madness! In conclusion it's not a bad place, but it's also not someplace I would go out of my way for.

This place came recommended by a lot of locals so to avoid naming another restaurant we went to Pequods instead of the other. It is in up town Lincoln Park area so a bit out of the city. I've never been one for pizza but have only recently taken a liking to thin crust (actually my coworkers believe I love pizza now). I had to get ready for this mentally as it was not a pizza at all. It was tasty. I don't understand the hype of deep dish but that's just me.  Keep in mind wait time for your actual pizza is about 45min so you'll need a light appetizer. Very busy. Tvs available to watch sports games.

I'm not a big fan of deep dish, but I liked this spot! You can get individual sized pizza and they have lots of different toppings. Also loved the vibe of the place and they had lots of craft beer on draft to choose from! If you are having a hard time picking a deep dish Chicago style spot, this is the place to go!

Pequod's pizza is my husband's favorite deep dish in the city and of course I had to check it out! I went on a Wednesday night and two people on a date can get seated in 20 minutes or less! The restaurant is actually larger than it appears on the outside and they have lots of tables and booths for groups or just couples. What I did not realize was the pizza crust is burnt, which is apparently their thing. It doesn't have a burnt taste, but it is flavorful and the sauce is more runny than chunky tomato. Pequod's definitely has more of a unique neighborhood-local vibe that you don't find with most other deep dishes places in Chicago which seem more chain-y. I found the pizza to be a little greasier than expected with a deep dish and expect another 20 minute wait time for the deep dish. We ordered a large between the two of us and only at 1-2 slices. Large is LARGE and filling at Pequod's. I ended up feeling sick after eating it tho but that may have just been my own fault. I gave this a four star because of the grease and the small drink list.
The BEST deep dish pizza in Chicago...the country!  I've been getting pizza from Pequods for over 20 years and it never disappoints.

Not sure what the whole fuss is about this place... The deep dish is just okay. Their thin slice pizza is really bad, so bad that I'd rather buy a whole Little Caesar's for that $5.  Last time I came here, I waited 45 min for just a slice of cheese pizza. When it came it looked like it had been cooked a while ago just warmed up. Yes, I got there late in the evening, but still - consistency is key!  The salad my sister ordered had an expired, smelly salad dressing. Overall experience did not match the rating here. Don't think I'll be going there again! Just next door for some drinks at The Drinkingbird. :)

Hit up Pequod's Pizzeria on a busy Friday evening to finally see if the hype lives up.  I definitely recommend signing up for Priority Seating because it works, our party only waited 15 minutes.  After snaking up and through the building, we were seated on the top floor and quickly ordered some brews.  We then ordered 3 appetizers: zucchini chips ($5), mozzarella sticks ($7) and a full caesar salad ($9).  I'm impressed with the zucchini chips because they appear house-made but the order consisted of a measly 8 small pieces with dip.  Mozzarella sticks were standard and the caesar salad was a bit too plain but both were better servings than the zucchini chips. The main dish was the classic, large pan pizza with 5 toppings and one premium (taking the base $19 all the way to $39!!!, each topping is $3 and premium is $5, I mean damn!! way too inflated for non-meat options): garlic, tomato, mushroom, onion and meatballs.  Ok definitely do no more than 3 toppings and a meat because otherwise the pie is a mess.  Our pizza was served with an explosion of toppings but of unequal quantity and distribution.  Plus the topics were so crudely chopped that it became annoying grabbing a piece of onion or tomato and grabbing the whole slice.  Even with fork and knife, the toppings are too big.   The crust was good but was too thick, the pizza was almost 70% crust.  The sauce and cheese could not save the pizza from being mostly dough-tasting and the toppings didn't stick or integrate.  When the meatballs were hit, they were a nice addition with good taste and texture.  Yes the crispy cheese crust was amazing but there was so little of it, not as satisfying. Hate to say it but my pizza was almost bland, due to dough amount and few (attached) toppings, my fiancé even attempted to salt her slice.  I see Pequod's potential but my lack of enthusiasm is partially based on my crazy order and abundance of toppings.  Still, the amount of dough in each bite is enough to want to cut the slice in half, horizontally.   The environment is crazy hectic and wait staff is average so they keep my static.  The prices were a bit killer but it's definitely the reputation.  No worries, I'll be back and will make more careful considerations.

Of course I had to stop by a deep dish pizza joint when in Chicago! We came around 10pm on a Fri night and waited around 20min. Our server told us that it would take around 45 min for the pizza to cook but ours came out in about 30min. We got a small 10" pizza with Italian beef, onion, and spinach. This was the perfect size for two people because it gave each of us two huge pieces that really made us so full!! I mean, unbuckle your belt full.. I loved the crispy crust and red sauce. The cheese was super gooey that when we took our first bite, it was all stringy! All in all, it was a great deep dish pizza. It didn't blow my mind but it left me feeling satisfied!

I thought it was quite good! Prepare to wait because it will be a while. From the moment we put our names in, to when we left it was about 2 1/2 hours. But that is to be expected from one of the best deep dish places in Chicago (so stop complaining, people). The only downside I thought was there was much more bread than cheese and toppings. But it was still tasty nevertheless! I highly recommend it.

We got pizza to-go, and it was fantastic.  There really isn't a place to stand and wait, so make sure that you are not 20 minutes early like I was. Pizza was fantastic, and the staff was really on top if taking care of me the entire time I was there.  Offering me water while I wait, and checking on my pizza every couple of minutes.  I'm pretty sure that my pizza was in my hands less than a minute from leaving the oven. Overall it was a fantastic experience.

I'm not the biggest fan of deep dish pizza however this place seems to pull at my heart strings.  Keep in mind, this is not your normal deep dish.  The caramelized crust is awesome and we always go with the meatball topping.   The sauce tastes similar to homemade red sauce.  You should definitely give this a try.

We checked out 4 deep dish pizza places during our visit to Chicago for the weekend... Peqoud's, Giordano's,  and Lou Malnati's...  i can honestly say that Peqoud's had the best crust out of all of them... it definitely separated from the rest. The pizza was really good... but the only reason ibdidnt five them 5 stars was because if the appetizers and the presentation of the appetizers. My wife and i got the Jalapeño poppers... wow, such a small serving and just thrown into a plate with the dipping sauce. Embarrassing.
This pizza is great for both locals and out of towners looking to dig in to some Chicago style deep dish pizza! This is one of the best pizza spots in Chicago!

How is this place so popular??  Its just an ordinary sports bar.  The thin crust pizza is very meh, totally bland.  Didn't like it.  No atmosphere.  I guess the deep dish must be amazing, I'll admit I didn't try it.  The poppers were really good, the salads taste like Olive Garden. (in a boring way)

The location is great, near the Webster Theaters.  Our favorite pre-movie restaurant Filippo's had surprisingly closed.  "Okay, Pequod's seems to be popular, we'll go there."  We both thought the pizza was nuthin' special, in fact, a notch or two below ordinary.  And it took a long time to arrive.  What's all the fuss about?  We ordered thin crust, maybe deep dish is the way to go.  But I will not return to try it.

I love a good crust so I was super excited to try deep dish in Chicago.  Pequod's is away from the center of Chicago but it was still packed. Luckily, we had made "reservations" (not real reservations, just cuts your wait time down). We were still seated right away, but were told the pizza would take 45 minutes. Bummer.  We started with an order of wings which were nothing special.  There's a few sizes you can choose from and you can pay for additional toppings. I chose spinach and fresh garlic. 45 minutes later our pizzas came out piping hot in a cast iron skillet allowing for a crispy, thick crust.  Pequod's had more of a sports bar feel, which I did not expect.  Overall a solid spot for deep dish.

Landed in Chicago and this was the first stop I made at 11PM on a Friday night. There were three of us and we were seated promptly without a reservation. It was quite packed however, and we were brought upstairs for additional seating. Definitely a divey vibe with the dim lighting and neon signs. We went ahead and just ordered a medium pan pizza with pepperoni, sausage, and mushrooms. This is probably just common sense but don't come hungry because obviously deep dish will take a while to bake and we were dying of hunger waiting for that pie to come out. When it finally arrived at our table, it was glorious. The cheese, the sauce, the MEAT (sausage was so good!!) , the crust all came together to become a symphonic meal. I'm a deep dish noob, so I was taken aback by just how monstrous it was. I was barely able to finish my two slices of pizza, which is pretty shameful for me. Basically, the first piece was heaven, the second piece was a little less enjoyable because I was already strangely full and the crust wasn't as crispy. I was also surprised by the sauce to dough ratio because I had this preconception that Chicago deep dish would be very saucey. I was wrong. Not too mad about it because it clearly works for this pie. I probably wouldn't frequent this place if I lived in Chicago, but I'm very glad I got to try it while I was there!

While in Chicago, we were on the hunt for the best deep dish. We only had a chance to try two, so I can't compare Pequod's to all the other deep dishes of Chicago. With so many different places at our disposal, we went with Pequod's because of the solid reviews. Although it wasn't our favorite of the trip, we still thought it was good!  The small (10") was more than enough food for two. It's cool that you can do half toppings here, we loaded it up with veggie toppings for me and meat for the meat eater. I couldn't really taste the cheesy crust, and to be honest prefer Lou Malnati's crust a bit more.  We came at an obscure time and there was no wait. It's a bit of a trek, but it's worth checking out if you're like us and want to check out the best of Chicago.
This was pretty good. I can see why people like the carmelized crust, but I'm a big fan of the flaky crust pizza.  I was glad that the wait was not too long and that we were seated within 20 minutes.
The best pizza in the city! The service was lackluster on our second visit but the pizza is fantastic
Pequod's Pizza is my favorite place for PAN pizza. It is so delicious and worth the wait every time. You won't regret a visit to Pequod's!

I'm not a fan of bready deep dish pizza, and Pequod's serves bready deep dish pizza. I imagine if you like bready deep dish, you would like Pequod's. I don't like bready deep dish.  The place itself felt divey. Seems like it'd be a nice neighborhood spot for a few drinks. The toppings were good. That breadiness though...
Great deep dish. Really really good thin crust (I was surprised). The only knock is they get too busy so it's best to order at odd hours. It's definitely on my Chicago Pizza Mount Rushmore.

I'm a ny pizza snob and I still loved this place.   Great service, good beer and incredible deep dish pizza with fresh toppings.    Loved it.   For two people just get the small pie.  It's more than enough.
This will be my shortest yelp review ever...BEST DEEP DISH IN CHICAGO - by a long shot.
Wonderful service but I'm simply not a fan of Chicago style pizza. The crust is great, however. And they are generous with their toppings. Sauce was very delicious but so much bread...
