So when my sister suggested Pequod's I was ready to go. I heard the wait was pretty long, but we went at 5 and we had no wait. Our party of 5 was put in a pretty tiny half-circle booth, that was my main complaint, we barely had any elbow room. However, this place is pretty good. The crust is the best part in my opinion, it's basically coated with this baked, crispy, caramelized cheese, which I adore. The sauce was really good as well, though I think slightly more bland than some of the Chicago-style competitors. Overall, I really enjoyed this place. The service was great, the pizza was great, though I'm torn over whether it gets best Chicago-style for me. You have to give it a try though, if not for the crust alone!

Ordered their Pan pizza.  Crust was dense and had zero taste and was dry like aged bread.  Overall, totally subpar experience.  Ordered as a delivery, and it came 25 mins late.  No apologies offered, and person at store hung up on me when I asked if it would close to 30 mins late. Pass.

This is quite arguably one of my top 2 BEST pizza places I've ever had in my life and I LOVE New York pizza.  I'm not a thin vs thick crust guy; I just love good pizza.  I've had the chain pizza places in Chicago and although Peq's isn't as deep, that's the beauty of it! You don't get too much bread, or cheese, or with little pepperoni... Peq's is just the perfect balance between bread, cheese, reeeeally love sauce, & pepperoni. & this is why I love this pizza! Plus, you don't get full off 1 slice, I had 3 bc I love to eat and didn't want to eat more because I didn't want to be that hog. Could've easily had 4 comfortably. I'm from Cali and Cali has no good pizza. So when I travel, I try the landmark foods and this is by far the best pizza I've had in Chicago, hands down - in my top 2 pizzas EVER.

The deep dish crust is spongy. It is like eating toasted English muffin with toppings on top. Their thin crust is more decent. Ultimately, I don't recommend it nor would I serve it for my guests. Lou Malnatis is still #1 for me.

I don't get deep dish pizza. We waited over 2 hours on a Saturday to get some pizza from Pequod's. The space is cozy, but has 2 floors. Our waitress was friendly enough, and our appetizer of jalapeno poppers came out quickly enough, but we had to wait another 45 minutes for our pizza. (a wait we already knew about).  The pizza itself was a deep pool of tomato sauce, cheese, and toppings. Basically impossible to eat with your hands, which led me to use a fork and knife. It was pretty tasty, but not really much of a pizza. And honestly, I prefer the chain deep dish pizza, Uno's, because the crust is much more buttery. It was good, but definitely not worth waiting close to 3 hours.

We have been to many pizza places in Chicago. This is by far the best of the best. It's the crispy, cheesy crust that makes this pizza so unique. Every time we visit, we order a large to go, and freeze when we get home. Heats up very well.

First time and we were seated fairly quickly and got some cheesy bread to start.  Then we waited over an hour for one pizza to arrive the table.  The waitress was not attentive and we had to draw her to the table to get drink refills over the long wait.  Don't know if they were short staffed in the kitchen, but the wait too long.

I've been hearing about Peqoud's for a while now and finally decided to give it a shot. I ordered a sausage and pepperoni pan pizza and a side of mozzarella sticks for delivery. I called at 11am, as soon as they opened, and was told it would take 1 hour 15 minutes. It ended up being 2 hours before the pizza arrived, which was extremely frustrating as the estimated time they gave me was totally off. Already hangry by the time it finally arrived, I was praying it was worth the wait. The mozzarella sticks weren't cooked very well and were pretty bland. The pizza itself was very good and unlike some other pizza places, they didn't skimp on the toppings. There were plenty of huge pieces of sausage and pepperoni and I was sufficiently full after 2 pieces. Overall the pizza was delicious, but not delicious enough to justify the wait. Maybe I'll try dining in sometime in the future, but I'm not in a rush anytime soon.
The past two times I've ordered here, the pizza has tasted stale/not fresh. The quality of their pizzas and customer service has definitely hit rock bottom.

I'm embarrassed that I have recommended this place for so long. The staff is beyond incompetent-there are no words for this level of "service". I've worked in this industry for many years, I've hosted, I've run food, I've served, I've managed. I understand the other side of dining out and this was just a total let down. The wait, long. I understand that. I recommend this place to my boyfriends father who was excited to try deep dish which Chicagoans don't actually eat, but I always made an exception for Pequods. I used to love this place. 2.5 hrs later and multiple times of them telling our party "10 more minutes" I was absolutely finished and over this place. 1 six top, 2 four tops and 1 three top got seated before our party of 3; all of which arrived AFTER us and it's incredible that the hosts were not phased by this. "Maybe they called ahead", really? Yeah. Maybe they all called ahead and decided to show up 2 hours before the quote time just to hang out. F*cking doubtful. Maybe if I hadn't worked in this industry so long I'd believe you, nice try. But I don't buy it babe. Is the pizza good, yes. Would I ever go through this again? F*CK NO. Screw this place.

Bland pizza with a "specialty" of burnt crust. When I made pizzas, we tossed any that got burned. Now it's nostalgic? I'm sure Pequod stacks up well against Gino's East and Giordanos, but that's not saying much. Probably stacks up favorably to a Tombstone Pizza, too, but that doesn't make it good enough to put in my mouth when there are so many, better pizza options out there. Sure, I eat three meals a day but I'd still like to enjoy the eating experience each time. Why waste one here? Pass on Pequod's and you can thank me later.

Was recommended this place by a local. Came here and was quoted a 1.5 hour wait and directed to a neighborhood bar while we waited. The bar was fine ( nothing to write home about) but we waited over 3 hours for a table...that's twice the quoted wait time!! Then after being very stern with the hostess and manager was seated and waited over another hour for our food. Although the server was nice the overall experience was terrible and definitely not worth the 4 hour wait...to sum it up...Go somewhere else!!!!

Pizza has a very thick crust to it but without any flavor at all. Tasted like a thick hard slab of dough. Wings were good but order was very small for the price. Waitress was annoying. I don't need to eat pizza here again unless I'm trying to throw away carbs and prevent myself from tasting anything. Was hoping this would be what people cracked it up to be but it was really a waste of time into another area of town and we left confused and dissatisfied.

I recently went on a trip to Chicago and wanted to try some good deep dish pizza. All I can say is that I'm so glad that this was the first place the I tried. It was soooooooo good. I thought the crust was going to be heavy and greasy, but it wasn't and the toppings were delicious. The pizza was so good that I even thought of giving up sunny southern Californian weather to live in Chicago and eat pizza.

Best Chicago style pizza I ever had, but I'm not a local, so my experience is quite limited.  Staff was friendly and attentive and the pizza was outstanding!  I don't think they do reservations, but you can call ahead and try your luck.

Hands down the best for thicker crust pizza.  Make no mistake, this IS NOT deep dish.  It's pan pizza with a perfectly caramelized cheese melted on the crust.  Great toppings and sauce as well.  My fave in the city.  Lines can get crazy so call ahead and order take out.

Hard to believe that I've been to Pequod's as much as I have and never bothered to write a review until now.  Let me start by saying I like this place so much that we held our rehearsal dinner here.  They have a back room upstairs that you can rent out that holds about 50 people, and I want to say they charged $40 per person for all you can eat and drink (including draft beer and I think house wine).  That would have been around May 2013, so not sure how pricing is now. I've had most if not all of the "famous" places around Chicago, and nothing will ever beat Pequod's for me.  I can't even tell you how many friends over the years I've turned on to this place.  Some are local and have since made it their staple place, and some are distant and now make this a priority stop when passing through Chicago.  I'll specifically never understand how anyone can like Lou Malnati's "wheel of sausage" pizza better than this. Regarding the pizza, the crust is amazing.  I know that it may not be "traditional" deep dish, but it's thick as hell and impossible to eat more than two slices, so it's deep dish to me.  When I eat the crust on most deep dish, it seems like I'm just eating a lot of cooked bread.  Pequod's caramelizes the crust, and most lovers would agree it's the highlight.  The sauce is also delicious, as well as the toppings.  My personal favorite pie is pepperoni, Canadian bacon, & giardiniera.  If you like spicy, the giardiniera is absolutely delicious (most of my non-Chicago friends don't even know that's a thing). Word to the wise, if you go at a time when most places are crowded, be prepared to wait a while to be seated, and to receive your food if you order deep dish (since it takes longer obviously).  This is Chicago after all, and any good restaurant is slammed when you'd expect it to be.  However, you can call ahead to make reservations, and last time I was there they accommodated a party of 14 for us on a Saturday night no problem, but I did call weeks in advance.  Also, a trick is that if you know what you want to order, you can place your order while you wait, so that once you are seated, your food comes out much faster than if they take your order at that point. Regarding the service, we've had some wait staff that was better/worse than others.  It's never been amazing and never been terrible, so we've never really thought much about it.  It's never gotten in the way of the goal, which is devouring as much of their pizza as possible before face planting.

It was my first visit to Chicago and my first time trying deep dish pizza. My bf had tried the big name deep dish pizza places so I suggested we try Pequods, a place he hadn't been before.  Waiting for the pizza felt like forever because we were both so hungry we didn't have the energy to talk about anything except when the food would be out. Luckily we had came before the rush so it only took about 15-20 minutes which is standard btw.  The pizza was amazing. They cook the crust with cheese so it's like a crispy cheese crust. Just imagine when you melt cheese in a frying pan and it turns that golden brown. Imagine a piece of that on the crust. Every bite is just the right amount of oozing cheese, pepperoni, sauce and crust.  To make it better, the pizza wasn't as oily as some pizzas can be so you don't even feel guilty as you eat your second slice of deep dish and eye your third slice. :) My bf and I shared a small which was more than enough.

this place has gone down hill quickly, incompetent order takers, delivery guys, and a manager named Kevin who ABSOLUTELY fails when it comes to satisfying a customer. Done,never order again after being a loyal 10 year customer.  Malnatti's here we come.

Pequod's the only pizza place you have to dine at when in Chicago. Your biggest regret as a tourist for the week/end is not being able to drop everything at home and move to Chicago to be closer to Pequod's.  Start off with a full order of wings - trust me, the half order is not going to be enough for even a party of 2. Both the bbq and buffalo wings were delicious - I personally liked the bbq more because the buffalo sauce was slightly too tangy :p You know the food is good when it gets painful to write a review because you wish you could be enjoying the food while writing about it. Pequod's is now thousands of miles away from me and who knows when my next visit to Chicago would be. So sad.  The pan pizza. is. out. of. this. world. The crust has this savory, caramelized texture - the center of it is soft and chewy and not overwhelmed with tomato sauce like other deep dish pizza restaurants. The cheese is amazing and you'll want extra amounts of it. I LOVE CHEESE. The toppings are so fresh. I am dying thinking about it. [We ordered spaghetti as well - please pass on it, it wasn't that great. Save more room for pizzzzza.] Toppings you must get:  -Sausage -Pepperoni -Bacon -Fresh Basil  -Fresh Garlic Okay, I'm dead.  (Crystal's soul is now finishing this review) Please save me by express shipping me a Pequod's pizza. I'm not greedy, I can resurrect with even one slice!!! One slice of your pizza RIGHT NOW is all it'll take to save this girl's life!!!

Pequod's serves up the quintessential Chicago deep dish experience. It's a fairly small restaurant in a residential neighborhood across the street from a movie theater. We got extremely lucky as there was practically no wait on a Sunday night. Our server was great, super friendly and willing to accommodate changes to our order.  The pizza took about an hour to get ready, so definitely order some appetizers. Their cheesy garlic bread dipped in marinara is delicious and extremely hot, so give yourself a minute or two before you devour it. I highly recommend the wings as well. I personally prefer the barbecue wings over the buffalo, which has a nice kick if that's what you're feeling.  As for the pizza, there's no doubt about the "deep dish" part. It's thicker than the ones served at Lou's. One slice can count as two slices of a normal pizzas. You get to pick your own toppings. We ordered a large and I'd say it would easily feed 5 hungry adults.  Overall I was very happy with the experience and would come back!

Awesome pizza! Lousy service. It took 20 minutes just for drinks on Thursday early evening then never came back to our table again except for delivering the check. Desert would've been nice after dinner if offered. Lost customer.

Do I need to add a review to the 3,000+ review Pequoid's has. No, no, not even a little bit, but I will, because, like putting a flower in your hair in San Francisco, stuffing your face full of deep dish pizza as a visitor in Chicago only seems customary. To say that this was my 6th meal in a row of deep dish pizza would not be an exaggeration for I had had Giordano's pizza & the exorbitant amount of leftovers.  Ignoring my stomach and the inevitable onset of lactose intolerance, I went to meet a friend from Iceland at Pequod's because he felt similarly about deep dish pizza as a visitor. Even on a Tuesday, the wait was well over 30+ minutes during dinner time although it could have been correlated to a sports game that was playing that day. Local friends we were with had a light pre dinner snack of sushi next door- pregaming for pizza like troopers they are. Finally, bliss in sitting down at a table! But wait, pizzas are running 40-50 minutes. No worries, there is beer & cider. It feels really natural waiting for food, so I didn't mind a bit, but for those who get hangry, take take time into consideration.  It's a really casual vibe- TV with the game on, bar stools, chill waiters with witty jokes- the works. The pizza compared to Giordano's was better. The thing that stands out is the crust, which is really crispy and delicious. We had a vegetarian at the table, so we had half a veggie pizza and the other with sausage. One apple cider and one slice in, it was game over for me. Others managed to eat two.  This is apparently the place to come to for deep dish, so I am satisfied. This is the last slice of deep dish pizza I vow to have in Chicago, so it holds a special place in my heart. But, not so much my stomach.

This review is for a recent visit on 7/8/16 at 12:30am. The restaurant was quite busy for a late Thursday / early Friday but the service definitely met expectations. Our waitress was extremely friendly and assertive while taking our orders. She seemed exhausted since it was near closing, but her customer service wasn't interfered by her exhaustion. As always, the food came out to be delicious and just as expected. The appetizer sampler is a must have for anyone that wants to try a variety of items. To top it off, our deep dish pizza did a great job of satisfying our cravings. Will be returning soon!
The pizza was great and salad wasn't bad for what I expected.  They said the pan pizza would take 50 mins.., but probably just wanted us to order apps. It came out in less than 30.

Pequods - this is what Chicago natives will tell you when they ask if you ever had a good Deep dish, I mean really deep dish pizza before. Having lived and worked in many different cities before I have had pizzas, normal and the exceptionally thin crusted ones as well. But not the deep dish pizza where you need to navigate through this deep dish pizza with a knife and a fork. Yes this is deep dish, not possible to do it with your bare hands, well yes you can but it will be a mess! The deep dish pizza is good but it makes you bloated after a second piece. Apart from Pequods there is also Giordano's in Central Chicago near to the Willis Tower. Nice but you have to wait for your order, about 20-25 minutes for the deep dish pizza to arrive. Try it! It's an experience.

Worse service I have ever experienced in my life! NEVER coming back here me and my boyfriend got seated within 1 hour and 30 minutes when we first of called in and she said we would get seated right away and then we get there and they tell us something different. We had to complain and asked to speak to a manager right when we said we want to speak to a manager the host (which was a guy I don't remember the name) got scared and goes ok I'll get you seated right now. He had people go in that we're after us and goes to show you he isn't playing it right. Our waitress literally only took our order and Never came back to check up on us we were confused on who our waitress was. The pizza also took another hour. Just HORRIBLE I rather go to Lou mantis and not have a bad experience with better pizza. They definitely need a whole new management of how they run the system because I honestly never such bad experience.

Yes, the wait can be insanely long, between getting seated and then the pizza actually arriving. But basically any deep dish pizza takes awhile (45 mins at least) so that's to be expected. I guess if you're used to "regular" pizza cook time, this would be a bit of a shock. So...don't come here if you're in a hurry. They bought the bar next door and you can get 10% off your Pequod's order with your bar receipt, so there's a perfect place to wait to be seated. Take advantage! The pizza itself is delicious. I love the carmelized crust; definitely sets Pequod's apart from the other Chicago pizza places. It's a small place that has a friendly, neighborhood feel to it, even though it's insanely popular, and I enjoy that vibe. A visit here is a must for any deep dish fan!

Not really sure what the excitement is about. First time I had it we got the thin crust (1st mistake) and it was not even close to good. The second time I had it we ordered 2 of the pan pizzas - they were good but there is way too much crust and way too much sauce with very little toppings. The sauce helped the pizza not taste too dry, but I've still had better. Not worth the wait.

Excellent example of Chicago deep dish. Decent zucchini fries too. Great beer selection. Fun servers. If I have a complaint it is that it feels Like it takes forever to get that pie you were dying for a half hour ago.

After a full day of drinking, walking, shopping, and doing touristy things, I was delirious by the time we arrived here for dinner so I can't accurately comment on anything prior to the food, but hey that's all that matters. From what I -do- remember, ambiance was nice (I felt cozy, and cozy is always a good thing for me), service was very friendly. The only poopoo was that our appetizer was forgotten until after our pizza came, but it was comp'd so I can't say shat.  Will not beat a dead horse and rave about how DELICIOUSSS the pie was (burnt. crust. ohmygahd), except to say that pizza is forever ruined for me. Perhaps I'm biased because this is probably the only real pizza I've had, but for now I truly mean it. Would find any excuse to visit Chicago just so I can come back.
While the pizza is average, the service & management are deplorable.  If you're looking for Chicago deep dish - choose Lou Malnati's.

Wow, what a rude order taker! First I ask, do you deliver to Lake Point Tower? No, we don't! (all her responses were very snappy) But your delivery zone map looks like it is right by u..... What's your address? 505 N Lake Shore Drive, but you...... What's your phone number? 312- XXX - XXXX What's your name? A...... Hold on... What's your [street?] number? (slowly this time) 5-0-5 N Lake... I already got that!  What's your Suite number? 1XXX (we never call it a suite) K, waddya want? 14 inch pan with sausage mushroom green pepper Anything else? No Cash or charge? Cash.  How much? Whatever she said I don't remember I was so upset.  33 or 34 something Hour to an hour and a half ok Wow it's 5:25 on a Thursday!  90 minutes?  We shall see... Arrived 7:05PM Too cold for our liking.  Why did it take 100 minutes for delivery? We heated it in the oven a bit, but that still didn't help much. Our crust was not ''caramelized'' around the edges, but more like burnt.  The bottom of the crust was soggy.  By the way this is not a stuffed pizza, it is a thick crust pizza.  A stuffed pizza is a pie shell filled with cheese and toppings, covered by another layer of crust, and then sauce put on top.  Compare with Edwardo's. I must also say that the toppings are not evenly distributed, particularly the sausage.  I got one large chunk that I cut up to try to distribute myself on my piece.  And there was a smaller one stuck in the burnt ''caramelized'' section.  Nice hunks of green pepper though, and a few red ones thrown in for I don't know what reason.  Hard to see any mushrooms though. The bites of sausage were quite spicy, but otherwise it tasted pretty bland, and I didn't enjoy the texture (burnt edges and soggy bottom).   Along with a rude employee that is the face of the business by answering the phone, I wonder how this got in that article of the 50 best foods to try in Chicago.  I crossed this off the list, and the author of that article owes me $35.

Pequods pizza is on my top 3 list for deep dish in Chicago. The only thing keeping it from 5 stars to me is the typical wait for a table as well as pizza, which for me has ranged from 1.5-2.5 hours. Understandably deep dish pizza takes a while to make but this is longer than other places I have been. The pizza itself is stupendous and the garlic bread for an appetizer is bomb!

For the last three weeks I have been in Chicago working, during that time I have been on an amateur food tour of the city. This place is the only review I have made, it's absolutely incredible. Best deep dish I have ever had, the Carmelized crust is out of this world. Sauce is homemade and wonderful. Can't wait to come back

Let me start this off with I really love their pizza.  However, I'm really sick of getting crappy service.  I just called to inquire about a reservation (on the yelp page it says they accept reservations) and I dealt with a very snooty hostess (If I describe her attitude in a more realistic way, I don't think yelp would be allowed to post my review). You may have great tasting pizza, but Chicago has a lot of great pizza, and I will NOT put up with rude people, especially when their job is related to customer service. Bad form!

Tried it based on a recommendation, but not impressed. Even placing the order was a hassle...no online option, and the girl who took my call seemed like I was interrupting her at work. Got a 10" pan (deep dish). The ingredients were not evenly dispersed, one piece (it comes cut into 4) had all pepperoni, another almost all sausage.  Couldn't see/taste the Fresh Garlic that was supposed to be added, but maybe it's all on a piece I've not had yet. The crust was OK, but not impressive. Can't recommend it.
Love the spot ,opens late , across the street from regal cinema , great steak sandwich and fries with awesome pasta menu  Would definitely go back again

My first thought on digging in to a sausage and tomato pan pizza was "do I need to order cheese as well?"  I always assumed that was a given on pizza unless you request otherwise.  After some digging around between the sauce and crust I finally found some.  Not nearly enough though, and I couldn't even taste it because the sauce completely drowned it out.  Also, the crust was too thick and chewy for my taste - much different than the traditional Chicago deep dish experience.  All in all, I was disappointed given the amount of calories I just penalized my body with.  All bread and sauce with very little of any other flavor and very messy.  This reminded me of something my mom would try to make when I was a kid (the burnt/carmelized cheese crust adds to that)  - that always fell short of a good pizzeria experience.  I guess everybody has their opinion, but I don't feel at all like this is among the best Chicago has to offer.
Wow! Great pizza! Highly recommend if you are in the Chicago area, it's a bit far to get to from downtown but definately worth an uber ride for this deep dish style pizza.

OVERLOADING THEIR KITCHEN WITH CARRY OUT AT THE EXPENSE OF RESTAURANT CUSTOMERS!  We were quoted 50 minutes for a pizza so we immediately ordered our pizza, an appetizer and a pitcher of pricey beer. After inquiring about our pizza to our waitress after an hour and fifteen minutes passed, she checked on the order and shrugged when returning to our table. Certainly not her fault. Then we asked to see the manager. He took around 10 minutes to arrive at our table. In the meantime, our MEDIUM THIN CRUST pizza arrived. People who arrived after us and were seated received their deep dish well before we did. The manager came to our table and just gave us an uncaring "sorry" which seemed a well rehearsed line.  We weren't looking for a free anything but he tried to say that we must have been told the 50 minute wait when the wait time was just changing????  Sincerity and customer appreciation is definitely missing. They have these kind of waits all the time and can't anticipate the timing just yet?  Goodbye Pequod's. There are plenty of pizza joints just as good if not better in the City.

Came here in the middle of December for what my Chicago friends said is very good deep dish.  Actually their exact words were "this is where Chicagoans go"   Was not expecting this at all. Pizza was very good but it is not deep dish....I know shocking right?  It's a stuffed pie not deep dish, and yes there is a difference. Nevertheless it's still a really interesting take on a classic, one that I wasn't aware of til that fateful winter night.  Go, be happy and enjoy "stuffing" your face.
Pizza is made fresh and is oh so delicious.  Definitely get the deep dish!  Only downfall is the long wait time but that is the price to pay for freshly made pizza.

Not worth the wait at all.  We arrived at 7:30, were seated at 8:45, and weren't served until 10:40. I was fully prepared to wait but quite frankly almost two hours for food is ridiculous. Manager obviously didn't care when we complained and I'm 99% confident that they gave our order to the table across from us and that's why it took so long to be served. And the pizza was lackluster even though I was ravenous by the time it arrived. Overhyped and underwhelming.  Beddia in Philly has one man making pies and they are always slammed b/c of their Bon Apetit review and yet they manage to keep their shit together and consistently deliver. No excuse. Figure it out.

Dined here on a Wednesday evening. Very crowded but I found a spot at the bar. 45min wait for a personal pan but I was in no rush. Had onion rings while I waited which were very good. Pizza was a personal pan with sausage, pepperoni, onions, and green peppers. Pizza was mostly crust but still tasted good. Crust was cooked too hard for my liking. I plan to go back to try the thin crust.

45 minute wait for the table then 1 hour and 15 minute wait for the pizza  but it was well worth it! Cooked to perfection. The burnt edges has amazing flavor. The sausage and pepperoni are fresh. Again definitely worth the wait time.
No pizza I ever ate can match up to the deep dish here. Don't bother trying any other deep dish in Chicago or the world.

**This rating is based on Chicago pizza joints. Pequod's would score a higher rating when compared with pizza in Austin, TX for example. I feel that most every Chicagoan has their favorite when it comes to pizza. For me, growing up, it was Giordano's. While Gio's is still a classic, a few years ago my favorite switched to Lou Malnati's which I only tolerated as a kid funny enough (not all locations are created equal, the Lincoln Park location is one of the best). I've heard rumblings over the past few years that Pequod's was not to be missed. My brother had heard the same and we finally tried them out. The atmosphere has a pretty standard sports bar/pizza place vibe that works. A Euro Cup match was being played while we ate which was nice. Now for the pizzas. First, I would say don't even mess with their thin crust. We tried a slice just to test it out and to me, it was on level with microwavable pizza in terms of flavor and texture. Their pan pizza is definitely an upgrade. We got a large with sausage, mushrooms, and fresh basil. As a whole, I'd say it was good, but no new craving has been created and now I feel the need to go to get my Lou Malnati's on before heading out of town. I will say that their sausage and burnt crust were the two clear highlights and the bottom of their crust was crispy throughout. They were not cheap with toppings either as they piled them on. Also, there was a guy there who I'm guessing is either the owner or the GM and he was really really nice and you could tell he had genuine care for his patrons. They do a solid pan pizza here that is worth checking out. P.S. Always always always avoid ordering a personal pizza at any Chicago deep dish place. It's no where near as good as any medium and above sized pie.

I've been eating great pizza for over 40 years, so I can safely say that I've had most styles and pizzas all around - Chicago, NYC, central IL, Boston, New England, Jersey, Brooklyn, California (), Italy.... And THIS is literally the BEST pan pizza I have ever had. Wow.

Came here on a pizza tour; this was my second time here.   Ambiance: Large and crowded place.  Pizza: We had the sausage pepperoni and it was quite yummy although quite heavy (maybe because we had been at two other pizza places before that). So i suggest you come with an apettie because the slices are quite large.  Staff: We didn't have much contact with the staff so cannot comment. Everyone raves about this place and I suggest you try it at least once.
A little crowded.  A little hot.  But great bar atmosphere, and great chicago style pizza.  Burnt cheesy crust is fantastic.

In a disappointing search to find deep dish Chicago style pizza I was blessed by the pizza gods to make it the Pequod's on my last night in town. The pizza was everything I could have hoped for. If I would have found this place earlier there's a chance I would've eaten every meal here for the whole week.

Probably a favorite for deep dish. Crust is the best--crusty, thick, and very flavorful. Good idea to get a salad while you wait...even if you call ahead (unless you specify pick-up and pay in advance but let them know you'll eat in the restaurant), it will be 40 minutes. But worth the wait.
You can find better deep dish - the burnt crust pizza style doesn't taste very good. I would recommend trying other deep dish
Amazing! Came from my friend's (who is a local) recommendation and truly the best deep dish I have ever had. Coming from California it was also quite affordable for what you get!

If  Michelangelo (Ninja Turtles) could write a review about pizza this would be one of them. Where to begin? I have been going to Pequod's for the past 10 years.  I love two types of pizza Thin Crust and Pan.  This review is based on Pan pizza. Nowhere have I tried a better Pan pizza other than Pequod's. Their Thin crust pizza is not as great as their Pan,  I would say mediocre to any other Mom and Pops shop.  Moving forward with their Pan pizza you can expect a HIT OR A MISS. By this I mean they're not always consistent. I've been going to this place so often that I know when they get their ingredients right on cue. Sometimes, they add too much cheese, other times they overwhelm you with water down sauce. Even so, when they do get it right all I could say is COWABUNGA! The infused  burned cheese with the sweet crunch crust touching that flavorful tomato sauce that makes my friend Leonardo scream WICKED AWESOME! Moving forward, this place can get hectic. Every time I go I always have hours to spare so I don't mind the wait.  Having some beers while waiting is the norm. Appetizers are 7/10 nothing special, but great to kill some time. I rather stick to the pizza and beers. Staff are most of the time attentive. I see how they can become agitated by all the customers, but work with them and they'll work with you. Like I said if you come to this place don't expect to have that perfect pan pizza all the time. I heard from friends that their second location is better than the Chicago location. Can't say for sure. All I can say for this location is that  if they happen to get it right "Bravo" you have finally tried a bite of heaven my friend.

Okay, I am generally just not a fan of deep dish pizza but after checking out some reviews, it sounded like this needed to be a must do. It was pretty tasty! Great ratio of cheese/sauce/dough -- even for that doughy deep dish, haha. Going off hours (e.g. the bar on Saturday afternoon) may be your best bet to avoid the line.

I've had just about every Chicago deep dish (I was born and raised in Chicago, so it's pretty hard not to try them all) I have to say, this was probably my favorite of them all. I loved the caramelized cheese on the edge of the crust, good flavor on the sausage, fresh toppings and plenty of cheese. The service was good, and although the place was extremely busy, we really didn't have to wait long for a table.  (had time for a beer at the bar)] Definitely a recommend, and in my opinion it's among the best in Chicago.

First time having pizza in Chicago and my friend suggested here over all the places in downtown where i was staying. There was a wait for parties of 2+ but we were seated right away at a 2 top. Place isn't too big and is kind of dark like a pub. They said about an hour for the pizza so we ordered wings in the meantime. They were actually really good and I'm picky with wings. They were big and crispy and not too spicy or saucy. The pizza didn't really take an hour i don't think. Im not  huge sauce fan so I'm glad i tried this pizza rather than the 'traditional Chicago style deep dish' that has all the sauce on the top. It wasn't too heavy and doughy. Could've had a tad more cheese but the caramelized crust totally made up for it. The bill wasn't too bad for a medium pie, wings and two drinks, but we did only got one topping. Came to $40. Only thing that could've been better was the service. I mean our waitress was training someone and it  was busy so she was dealing with a lot. I just could've used a refill :)

BEST PIZZA I HAVE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE (I've eaten many pizzas in my day). Seriously, this is the Chicago-style experience everyone should have. The ONLY downfall to this place is that you may literally wait more than an hour to sit down, as it is SO busy and a little crammed inside because of that. Call-ahead seating is available though... So I DEFINITELY recommend this place! YUM!
I'm not really a fan of deep dish pizza but this was pretty good. I think the super crunchy crust makes it better.

Best Pizza in Chicago. We recommend eating a late  lunch and then walking to Wrigleyville for some baseball or shopping, the walk shows off the great qualities of Chicago Neighborhoods. Takes just under an hour. Do the Deep Dish with sausage and then go from there!
Got thin crust here, it was decent for late night drunk food but nothing special. Great service though!

For one i do not like pizza. Theyre pizza is nothing fabulous. Staff isnt that great. Cesaer salad was average and a bit warm. Garlic cheese bread i could do with out. They have good marinara sauce for the mozz sticks that are good. I love their ginger ale pop though. Never want to come here again. Place was really cute and nice though. Set up a bit odd. They have a bathroom thats coed and then a girl n guys bathroom. They have a bar as well. Downstairs n upstairs seating with tvs. Place is kinda big.all of our plates though were cracked.
This is the best pizza in Chicago. I had pepperoni pan pizza, LOVED IT.

After craving this pizza joint what seemed like forever, I finally had the chance to order for delivery. The deep dish pie primarily consists of bread, which took forever to chew and swallow. However, the caramelized crust was on point, and it's probably the best darn crust I've had in my life.

I had one opportunity to try deep dish pizza. there were several places I could have chose from, but I picked here. I had to wait 30 minutes to be seated, and then another 40 minutes for my pizza. Waiting for your food here is like a quest. Its not easy, and there are times you want to quit. But patience is rewarded with their damn good pizzas. I ordered a medium with pepperoni and sausage. It was just enough for two hungry people, and we were definitely full afterwards.  Service is not good, but its not bad either. Our waitress attended to us within a reasonable time, considering it was a full house.  The crust gets alot of attention here, but I think the best part is the combination of everything. The main player in this pizza is the bread. Usually a hunk of bread that thick would be dry and disappointing. Here, the pizza is fluffy and moist. The toppings burst with flavor. I still dont know whether I like the pepperoni or the sausage more. The cheese was just enough to be gooey but not overwhelming. They could have added a little more sauce, but I think I preferred it on the less saucy side. the caramel crust was cooked just right, but its not mind blowing as some people make it. Overall, it was an excellent meal. Not too salty, not too greasy, and not too saucy (which gives me heartburn). considering this pizza was neither of these things is quite an accomplishment.
Love the original Pequod's in Morton Grove better, but the Clybourn location is good, too.  Salads are generic, but there's nothing quite like the pizza in the well used pan!

Second favorite pizza in the city (Lou's is #1) but is very close to the best.  The downfall for me is that there aren't many peaquods and its a haul from the south loop.  Their crust is amazing and I'm a big fan of their sauce.  Prices are extremely reasonable.

Best. Pizza. In. Chicago. If you have never been here before, be prepared for the burnt cheese crust. You won't be disappointed. Also check out the weekday lunch special. $5.99 one topping personal pan pizza and a soft drink. Great neighborhood gem.
SO GOOD, pricey though thats the only thing keeping me away.

4 stars for pizza, 0 stars for service. I've ordered delivery several times and today was the first day I visited the restaurant. What a bummer. When out of towners ask for my opinion on "Chicago-style" pizza, I always say Pequods. I'll have to find a new place to recommend from now on. Seriously...the service was just that bad.

I came to meet some friends here that live in Chicago, they suggested this place and wow did it live up to there words. I'm from nyc so we do flat pizza and the last time I was in Chicago I had giodanos and its was not what I thought. But lord this place the pizza was amazing! It just was to good and I loved it.

I've been going to Pequod's for years.  The pizza is AWESOME.  The restaurant is very cool on the inside.  They also have great lunch deals during the week.  Make sure you get the pan pizza with the "caramelized" cheese.

Trust in the crust, not in the service. Pequod's is considered by many (the vivacious LeAnn P among them) to serve one of Chicago's best pizzas, and after a visit this past weekend I can believe the hype. It takes either a very special pie or a very special lady to get me to eat deep dish (as I much prefer thin crust); in this case it was a little bit of both.  Fortunately we came early enough in the evening before great masses crowded the place, so getting a table was no problemo. Knowing that their Chicago-style was legendary (3,000 reviews on Yelp, god damn!), we hastily asked for a 10" pan with pepperoni, sausage, and green peppers.  Pequod's is famous for their burnt cheese crust, which comes out black and delicious (much like Drake). Thirty minutes seems like an eternity when you're craving the 'za, but eventually it arrived and we dug in with little hesitation.  Great sauce, plentiful toppings, and a blackened cheesy pan crust had me singing their praises.  It was incredible, folks.  I'd say my expectations were high and even they got surpassed.  I still feel weird eating pizza with a knife and fork, but when it's as good as Pequod's I could honestly care less. Bread = 4.5 Circuses = 2.5 The 'za was as good as the service was bad.  But in what way? Our server Alex greeted us, got in our pizza order and brought us drinks, after which she pretty much vanished.  When our deep dish finally arrived, a different girl brought it out and sliced it for us, who later also brought us more refreshments......so where did Alex go?  Maybe she quit.  Perhaps a family emergency?  Noooooope!  Turns out, she was just chillin' at the bar, hobnobbing with some locals while enjoying a glass of wine and a slice.  Apparently, her shift had ended.  Areyouf*ckingkiddingme? I had no words.  None to describe how flabbergasted I was that our original waitress totally bailed on us without warning.  A quick "hey, I'm closing out, (new waitress) will be taking over for me", would have sufficed but we didn't even get that much.  When the check came, I wanted to confirm that Alex wouldn't get diddly squat tip-wise for abandoning her customers, but as the server was listed as "CZ01" (whatever the sh*t THAT means), I've really no way of knowing. The men's bathroom had a ton of graffiti in it, but not the cool kind like at Emporium Barcade where it's intentional in an edgy sort of way.  Here, it was a normal, clean-ish bathroom that a bunch of people straight up vandalized. lol It's not that I wouldn't want to return here-- because the pan pie is really, REALLY good --but since everybody and their grandma claims that they're "Chicago's best pizza" I feel obligated to try them all before making a 2nd lap around town. Get here early to avoid the swarm of people, and pray that your server doesn't randomly disappear.

This review is so long over due... I was visiting Chicago with some friends and we just had to try the signature deep dish pizza a few hours prior to our flight. Otherwise, how would the trip be considered complete!? The service was wonderful. I found the waitress to be very welcoming and helpful when it came to deciding what to order. When the pizza came, I was very impressed by the size of the pizza and amount of cheese and topping that sat on top. The pizza was fresh and hot out of the oven. I remember watching in awe with the bubbling cheese and hearing the satisfying sizzling coming from the pan. The waitress sliced the pie and the rest is history. I had left overs at the airport with the intention of bringing this back home to eat but all that was left was crumbs by the time my flight landed back in New York...

Weak flur, the food was excellent but service was pretty poor! Most of the ladies were standing talking and after asking for something twice I just decided to get it myself. The ladies behind the barwere pretty cool though and helped me when my server didnt. It was busy, waited two hours for food and it seems management doesn't have to much concern about customer urgency since both places including the sister restaurant had similar service.

Overall it was ok pizza. Almost a focaccia crust-yummy, but a lot of bread. Loved the crispy cheesy cast iron outer crust. Not what I would consider "deep dish". Reminded me of Jets.....unfortunately.
The best deep dish, hands down! I have tried Giardinos, Gino's, and Lou Malnati's and this is my personal favorite. Be prepared to wait, as this place is very popular.
Awesome pizza!!! My family out of town goes everytime and loves it. The staff is great! Its always very packed and long wait but very worth it. You want great pizza a much visit.
Best deep dish in the city, you'll never go back to lous or giordanos after eating here.
Holy cow! Amazing pizza! I think this is the best in Chicago! The service is bad (I really mean bad) but the food is worth it. I think the secret is in the unwashed pans they use to cook the pizza.

I wouldn't call myself a deep dish connoisseur or anything but I do like myself a good pizza now and again while in town. I ordered a large which was big enough to feed a small army and it was pepperoni and sausage. Sausage tasted kind of gross and like an unflavored meatball, along with the pizza having wayyyy too much sauce. I got a Caesar salad and it was just below average. I did like the cheese crunchies on the crust, but it wasn't worth $43.
I just cruised right in this piece with a friend of mine, and sat down. Our waitress was off the chain, and we definitely dug that. The pizza was so good that I wanted to like marinate in it all day.

First deep dish pie in Chitown. A line outside the door, but I was only one person, so got to quickly get a seat at the bar on a Saturday afternoon. Ordered the Cheesy Garlic Bread appetizer to start ($4ish) since the pizza takes forever to get in. Two large cylindrical slices of bread topped with gooey melted cheese and a strong taste of garlic. Probably not the best idea to order before trying to down an entire deep dish. Main course was a 10" with mushrooms ($13ish). Gobs of marinara sauce soaking thick bready goodness. Very filling pizza though I did not like the chewy burnt crust along the edges (marinara didn't help there). Could barely move after all said and done. Service here is friendly despite the hangry crowds. Great pizza though wouldn't wait forever for it.

I was new in town this past weekend trying to compare NY style to Chicago style. Went to 4 different places, the names everyone mention, and was not impressed. A cashier from the Laguanitas Brewery on W 17th St really recommended this place. The last night I was in town I had to give deep dish another try before knocking it and I have to say this is the absolute best deep dish I could find.

Very mediocre. We were definitely disappointed based on all the stellar reviews of the deep dish pizzas. Our pizza crust tasted okay but nothing great. The dough was a little dry and bland. The wait here is also insane and definitely not worth it.  I probably won't go back as it is not worth the wait for the mediocre deep dish. Personally,  I think Lou Malnati's is better. Maybe it was an off night?  I came here once before but just got a salad. It was good, really big portion but again, nothing i would order again.

Delivery takes approximately 1.5 hrs, I received mine about twenty minutes later. When I called about this, the store person didn't even apologize. The pizza crust is about 1 inch thick, with a good amount of sauce but very little cheese. The crust tasted a bit bland and was way too much when compared to the ingredient proportions. The caramel iced crust at the end was delicious though! Ingredient wise I would give it a 7/10, not enough cheese and only one or two sausages per slice, they did taste fresh. I will probably not order this pizza again.

Loved the pizza here! The burnt cheese edges make the pizza. I'm not a huge fan of a "burnt" taste, but this is more like caramelized. Loved both the sausage pizza (looked homemade) and the cheese. It does take quite a while for them to make it (one hour for us) but we just called ahead and picked it up. So happy we followed the advice of our friend from Chicago!

My husband is obsessed with pizza, so when we were headed to Chicago for our engagement pictures, we had to stop at Pequods. We've tried all the other Chicago pizza places and this was next on our list. We really liked it. The crust is different. I believe it's caramelized. I was told to ask. For extra sauce and I'm so glad we did. Our only issue was the wait - super crowded and you can't make reservations. The appetizers were good too. We ordered the chicken fingers and fried mushrooms. This place is really popular in Chicago so get there early!

Holy Deep Dish, this place is amazing! I'm from out of town, and I've had the usual suspects for "famous" Chicago style pizza. They were good, but nothing like Pequod's. There is something about the crust; it's light and crispy and flavorful. We just did pepperoni and sausage. We were warned not to overdo it. Between the two of us, we got a small pizza (two pieces each), fried zucchini, and a pitcher of beer, and it was perfect. Totally worth the wait.
I love this pizza. It is different from deep dish and thin crust. Very good and well deserved to be on best pizza of Chicago list.

Pequod's is consistently delicious!  When I moved to my condo, it took at least a year and a meeting in the elevator with the delivery driver to learn that Pequod's delivers to my building!  What a pleasant surprise! Delivery is speedy and hot!  The restaurant is a very nice little spot with an upstairs and comfortable seating.  Staff is always pleasant, even during high capacity times and it's always a pleasant experience.
Best pizza in the city!!! Fresh, tasty. Comes out hot right in the pan. Come visit, Especially in the summer. Ambiance is great. Definitely check it out!

Very good pizza if you like caramelized crust (it is a bit different from the normal deep dish). Only reason for the 4 star is because I thought it was too much bread for me compared to more cheese you get and the other deep dish pizzerias

So I have to admit, the waiting for a table and the. The pizza definitely tainted my opinion of this place. I came to Chicago for a conference and had a bit of a reunion with old coworkers, one of which lives in Chicago. She picked this place for us to all have dinner on Sunday of memorial day weekend. The place was packed and there were a lot of us. You can't make a reservation and we ended up waiting close to 2 hours to be seated. We ordered salads and the appetizer sampler to tide us over for when we finally sat down and the had to wait another hour for our pizzas. (For those keeping track, we had to wait 3 hours to eat.)  The crust is as amazing as you've heard. Crunchy, caramelized, crispy. The sauce has a bit of a kick to it, which I didn't love. There could have been a little more cheese. Overall, it was good pizza but I was underwhelmed. That could have been from waiting 3 hours to eat, or it could be that I just like pizza the way they make it at home in NYC. Either way,  you have got to try deep dish when in Chicago. I would recommend this place but don't come with a large group. You will wait forever.

I came here based on word of mouth, having heard about it for so long.  If I was just judging the pizza,  I would give it another star, as it was very good.  The service, not so much. We came in on a weekday afternoon and there were about 4 other tables being served.  We waited about 15 minutes before anyone came over, and then after ordering drinks, about another 15 minutes before they arrived.  This was draft beer, by the way, and the bartender was about... 7 feet away from our table.  This is a very small place, so it really starts to feel purposeful when you are being ignored for that long. We would have liked to order more beer but we never got the chance to.  We placed our food order and the waitress left, at which point I'm assuming she was abducted or went into a coma in the back of the restaurant.  After about 30 minutes of staring into empty beer glasses, our pizza came.  We asked the bus boy to send our waitress back and he nodded, but she never appeared. The pizza was really good, super crispy, melty, and I really like the personal pizza size.  The sauce was also very flavorful.  Two thumbs way up! When we were done eating though, we had to ask the hostess for the check, as the waitress had never come back, and at that point I would have even just wanted a glass of water to wash my meal down with... so I'm not sure if I'll go back.  I'll probably try delivery instead!
My favorite pizza in Chicago. Was great living around the corner. One of the things i've missed the most after moving away...

Came here with my friend for lunch to try another Chicago-style pizza place, since I had tried Lou Malnati's during my visit to Chicago last year. We were seated immediately upon entering. The interior is not huge; the restaurant is deep but not very wide. The atmosphere was very pub/bar like, which I did not expect.  Service was friendly and our waitress was great. She said it would be about a 45-minute wait for deep dish pizza, so we tried to place our order quickly. I think the actual wait time ended up being just a little over thirty minutes though.  I also ordered one slice of thin crust just to try, and added one of the "premium toppings" of Italian beef (apparently also very Chicago) to it. It was a big slice and not bad, but I prefer my thin crust even crunchier (think New York-style pizza, and yes, I realize that I shouldn't be expecting that while in Chicago).  All of the deep dishes start off with just cheese and you customize your pie from that point after picking a size. Each additional topping costs extra, and the cost of each topping depends on the diameter of your pizza. You can also order half-toppings (I think it means it is only put on half of your pizza) and premium toppings.  The deep dish was decent, but not particularly memorable in my opinion. I enjoyed the "caramelized edges" mentioned on the menu, but instead of the crunchy crust I was expecting, it was actually just darkened cheese which they must sprinkle along the pan's edge. I think I prefer a crunchier crust overall, which is why I usually get thin crust during the rare occasions that I eat pizza at all. I'm glad I tried Pequod's and their food is not bad, but I think Lou Malnati's better suits my tastes (just a personal opinion).

I always just get mine to go, so I can't say anything of the service here. However, the pizza is always fantastic! It's also great that they're open so late. Definitely a must try for anyone looking for something new!
One of my fav Chicago deep dish pizza places. Sometimes hard to get a seat as there are long lines but worth it!
Can't beat that crust on the pan pizza! And the sausage is top notch! Try adding garlic for the final kick.
By far the best deep dish pizza in Chicago. This IS THE PLACE to go if a local, tourist please ignore this .

Ordered a large deep dish pizza with spinach, Canadian bacon, half pepperoni, and half mushroom. the pizza was good, but I wouldn't say it blew my mind. I'm also not a huge fan of deep dish. I would advise people to try it for themselves.  The staff seemed tough in appearance which matches the environment of the bar. They were all nice and our server was great.

My mom is in town visiting from Texas. She saw this place on the Travel Network and wanted to give it a try. I'm not a huge deep dish fan but that's what my mom wanted so we got it. I prefer/love Lou Malnati's. This pizza taste like they got a loaf of bread put some toppings over it and stuck it in the oven. The cheese was overdone around the sides (my mom said that's there "thing" which was weird to me but I digress). We ordered delivery and it took about 2 hours to get here, which isn't terrible given how long it takes to make deep dish pizza. The woman who took our order seemed rushed and unpleasant. The sausage was good, therefore maybe I'll go back and try thin crust one day. I told my mom that as a Chicagoan I would be ashamed if someone from out of town tried this and thought this was what deep dish is about.

I know they get great reviews, so I had to try it finally.  Edwardo's is still my favorite.  Not a fan AT ALL of the "burnt pizza" craze.  Cardboard crust just wasn't for me. Didn't help that it was a veryyyy long wait and they messed up the order, when you say that you really hate a certain topping and they put that topping in the pizza, not good!

My friend said that this was his favorite Chicago deep dish. Having been disappointed by both Giordano's and Lou Malnati's, I was eager to try this place.  Our waitress noted that the pizza takes 40 minutes to bake, so we opted to order an appetizer. We got the sampler that came with mozzerella sticks, mushrooms, poppers, and zucchini... all of which were fried and of a similar quality that you would get at Denny's. Luckily we didn't have to spend that much time eating the appetizer because 25 minutes later, our pizza arrived! Wait, I thought it took 40 minutes, but whatever we dug in. We got a pretty standard sausage, mushroom, peppers and basil, They really piled on the toppings and the sausage chunks were huge and looked home made.  The first bite was delicious until I got to the uncooked dough, a nice layer right beneath the cheese and right above the rest of the cooked crust that was still mushy and raw. Well it was in the center of the pizza so maybe it was just that part. 2nd bite, uncooked. 3rd bite, uncooked. 4th bite, uncooked. It was at this point that we asked our waitress to return the pizza to the oven to cook more and she was kind to oblige. 5 minutes later (for a total of 30 minutes oven time), our pizza came back piping hot. But that layer of uncooked dough was still there.  Yes, the caramelized crust (read: burnt cheese) is delicious, but the sauce and the rest of the pizza are nothing to write home about. Sorry Chicago, but for me, Cali deep dish still reigns supreme.

The pizza is good, but you'll wait an hour to be seated (standing on the street outside on Webster) and then get ready to wait for a looong time for your pizza.  We were seated at 6:15.  We knew these pizzas take 50 minutes or so to bake, so as soon as the waiter came to our table we put in our order -- that was at 6:20.  Our pizzas came out -- no joke -- at 8:20.  Two.  Hours.  For a pizza.  No pizza is worth that ridiculous wait.  It's not Peking duck, folks.  By the time the pizza came I was the only one left out of our group of five, because we had a movie to catch and so everyone had to leave.  Worse, I got no apology from the manager or anything.  The waiter acted as if she couldn't have cared less.  All we got was a small discount.  I took those pizzas and dumped them in the trash.  Next time I'm going to Malnati's.  Bye bye Pequod's.

Been coming here for years and despite the lack of parking and the long wait times, we keep coming back because the pizza is just that good!  This place is well run and employees are well trained by the manager who is a fixture here!  He runs a tight ship and leads by being a hands on perfectionist in an environment that could easily be chaotic and unmanageable!  Kudos to him.

I don't get deep dish, or 'stuffed', pizza. And I LOVE pizza. It has all the components that I love - it's carb-y, and cheesy, and messy, and goopy - but the whole thing just never is as satisfying as I'd like it to be. Pequod's gets great reviews, and maybe this is where mine should end: I am not a fan of deep dish. But THAT said, it's claim to fame are charred cheesy edges. These are nice, and different, and give a deep flavour to the edges of each slice.  Based on a recommendation posted to Serious Eats, we got a basic pie with extra sauce, extra cheese. The sauce at Pequod's is great: zesty but not overpowering.  But...yeah. I just didn't enjoy it. It was too "bread"-y, and one-note (gosh, I sound insufferable). Not helping was the caesar salad we got in a bid to offset the pizza; it was just leaves with a gloomy dressing and hard croutons. I think we were both envisioning something a little more, well...special, somehow. Super friendly attentive staff, though! So there's (definitely) that. Yelp note: EXTRA SAUCE PLZ (this I stand by!)
2nd favorite pizza place. Burt's is my number 1 but I still suggest this place to people who aren't from here.
The crust has the consistency of a fluffy biscuit + caramelized, the tomato sauce is light and sweet (not salty) makes for an incredible deep dish pizza, not as cheesy and saucy as the others.

After seeing the restaurant on the travel channel and we were going to be in the Windy City, we needed to stop in and try. It was a Sunday evening and my wife called to see what the wait would be in an hour. They told her no wait. When we arrived, the place was packed and the wait time was 30-60 minutes for 2. This isn't necessarily their fault. You can't predict rushes of customers. Maybe a better way to say it would be there shouldn't be a wait but we can't guarantee anything. This was only the beginning of our wait.  It was suggested that we can also sit at the bar, which is full service. We went upstairs and found 2 seats at the bar. The 2 bartenders were very nice and attentive. They had about 8 beers on tap, all light and hoppy so we stuck with water. We ordered a small Caesar salad to share and 2 individual pan pizzas. About 20 minutes later, the salad arrived. After waiting that long for a salad, it should have arrived in a bowl that had just been woven by master craftsmen. It didn't. It was a small salad, enough for 2 to share if your not very hungry. The dressing was very good. Nice taste of Parmesan.  We waited just under an hour for our 2 personal pizzas. There is no excuse for that kind of wait without letting the customers know so they can chose whether they want to stay or not. We weren't given that option and we had walked for an hour to get here.  The redeeming things were the staff and the pizza. I ordered a personal pan with sausage, pepperoni and garlic. It was delicious. Probably the best pan pizza I have had. We at at Lou Malnati's last time and, in my opinion, this was far superior a pizza. The caramelized crust was awesome. The sausage, our bartender told us, was made just for the restaurant and had a fantastic flavor and consistency. The sauce was a little sweeter than I usually like but with the crust and toppings, it was perfect.  If not for the wait, I would go back again. Maybe try at another time. Pizza gets a 5 star rating. Wait time for pizza gets 1 star. Averages out to 3 stars.

Just... nope, can't eat here again. And it IS the pizza for me. The pizza dough is SO dense and bready so there needs to be a lot more sauce if they're not going change the recipe. That, or quit over-kneading it. As a Chicagoan raised on Lou Malnati's or Giordano's, Pequod's doesn't compare to them. Sorry... =\

There's Pizza and then there's PEQUOD'S PIZZA. It's off the chart and as original as it gets! When you get a craving for it, no other slice will do..Morton Grove location is an old house, pretty cool place.
Great neighborhood pizza joint.  I love their deep dish pizza.  The place gets crowded very quickly so plan accordingly

I could talk about the pizza but it would be a bit of a broken record at this point. I wanted to write a review for the hosts at Pequods.  Shout out to the hosts/hostesses at this place for seemingly always being able to keep their cool and get people seated. I get anxiety just thinking about how hard it must be to manage those wait times/tables etc. Good for you guys - keep killing it.

Ordered pizza for the first time as we like the thinner crust vs the traditional deep dish here in Chgo. Prepared perfectly and tasty. Delivery timing was also great. I highly recommend. Trying Pizanno's soon as a comparison .

My boyfriend and I were in town for spring break and came here for dinner on a Sunday night after seeing a movie. It was a little past 6pm and there was already a good crowd outdoors waiting to be seated. Thankfully as a party of two, we were seated immediately. I had read about Pequod's on a list of top spots for Chicago pizza, but eating here was completely unplanned, which made it all the better. We ordered a small pepperoni and sausage pizza with cheesy garlic bread as an appetizer. We didn't expect the garlic bread to literally be two slices of bread with cheese and garlic on top. We could have done without it, but since it takes an hour for the pizza to be made, it was nice to have something to chew on. My recommendation is to come hungry! A small pizza is more than enough for two in my opinion. The crust was super crispy and the sauce was sweeter than expected but still really great. They were very generous with the toppings. We ate half and took the other half to go and honestly we loved it even more the next morning after heating it up.

Let me start by saying I am NOT a deep dish fan. It is too much for me, but naturally you have to get one because you are in Chicago. Pequod's is what the locals recommended so we came here to see what it was all about. The pizza's crust isn't that dense thick crust that we all think when we think Deep Dish. This crust was thin and crunchy- very much like a cheese crisp. This is the best deep dish I have ever tasted- the cheese to sauce ratio was all on point. I wish I could say this place has made me a deep dish convert- but that would be a lie. But if you like deep dish then this place will most definitely be your go to spot.

I was so impressed with Pequods, but not for typical reasons.  Obviously their pizza is something that everyone raves about-and I agree.  But the service was also fantastic.  I had a group of 20 people going on a Saturday night for my birthday.  A lot of restaurants have an attitude when you have this many people and I sometimes they still make you wait or even lose reservations all together.  Although Pequod's walk-in wait was 2 hours, my reservation was brought right to the front and seated right away.  Within minutes our waitress was taking orders and accommodating my party.  She was so friendly and made us feel welcome despite how busy and crowded the restaurant was.  This is so rare and so appreciated!  Since then, I have been back and will continue to dine there.

Got a large pan pizza, half pepperoni, half mushrooms and green peppers. It's appropriately filled up 4 people, and compared to the other major pizza spots around town it was actually a little bit cheaper(large pizza w/2 toppings $24.65). The first bites were actually pretty amazing; the cheese by then was still very gooey and, being a pan pizza, the crust was crisp but also incredibly fluffy. It's not like the buttercrust at Lou's where you have something of a more pot-pie consistency, this is straight up large pan pizza. Also, was a little skeptical about the caramelized cheese crust at first, but after trying it I'm a fan. Not as incredibly amazing as most people say it is(I mean, at that point you can't really even taste that it's cheese), but the texture is great and I think I'd prefer it to other deep dish pizzas in that regard(after all, you're still getting plenty of the thicky doughy goodness on the base of the pizza...no need to have more on the sides). The pepperoni were nothing special, and would opt for the sausage next time. One dangerous downside...after initially amazing first few slices, once it cools down a little bit you actually realize how much of it is actually dough compared to filling. Whereas with say giordano's you really have a ton of sauce and toppings and the pizza dough is maybe 1/3 the width of the entire pizza, here it's the opposite; the dough actually accounts for like 75% of the height. Once it cools down this becomes very apparent, as you notice the thin layer of cheese and toppings compared to the dough. That said it's all super fluffy so it doesn't feel as if there is that ratio upon eating it, but it does take its toll after a while. So final deep dish verdict? Actually a fan, and would say this hits the right price point too. Only major cons are that I didn't get the sausage(not their fault), and that there is a lot of (albeit very fluffy) dough which makes the ratio seem a bit off.

I am a fan.  If you're looking to change up the normal Chicago deep dish routine, Pequod's is the place to go.  I ordered a deep dish pizza with sausage, green peppers, onions, and mushrooms.  Let me tell ya... it was tastey.  The crush is nice and thick, a little less crunchy than Lou's and definitely more pizza for each slice.  The best part about it was that it all looked like one big, happy pizza.  All the ingredients had great proportion and I will definitely come back!

I love Pequod's. It's one of the first stops on my taste of Chicago tour when I have friends or family visiting. They are always swamped so I make sure to go early or on weekdays to avoid the ensuing (yet justified) madness. I recommend to start with and order of wings before you move on the the sausage/pepperoni pan pizza.  The leftovers from Pequod's are the best! The pan pizza holds up for delivery but just takes a bit of time to show up. Well worth the wait either way..

Bartender was cool, and for my first deep-dish experience, pizza was awesome.  The sauce was a little on the tangy side, which I wasn't a HUGE fan of, but everything else was great.  I got the small sausage & pepperoni and had half a pizza left to give to a homeless guy on my way to the train.  I would've kept it for later, but I felt guilty not sharing. Will return when I'm back in Chicago, but admittedly have not tried Malnati's, Giordano's or others yet.

Been here a few times since friends have wanted to go. Basically, this place is a bar that serves inconsistent pizza. Good for the 20-something crowd who don't mind having to yell their conversations because the whole place is so loud. Service is good. Last time they messed up our order but gave 50% off without having to ask. 2 hour waits for popular times so be sure to contact them 24 hours in advance to get the priority seating which will cut your wait time in half.
My favorite pizza. Case closed. There is nothing else to even discuss other than the fact that you WILL regret it for the rest of your life if you do not come here.

My buddies took me here 8 years ago to try the "caramelized crust" deep dish pizza. I haven't been able to stay away since! The deep dish has that homemade, fresh ingredient taste to it. Hearty yet light enough to make you keep grabbing for more slices. Great, garlicky tomato sauce. Cheese that's not too greasy. Darn... I'm getting hungry just thinking about it! Go here. You will enjoy it I promise.

It has all the feel of a friendly neighborhood restaurant with my favorite deep dish pizza in town. The interior is cozy and warm and the building is multi-story. The signature of the deep dish here is the cheesy, caramelized crust. It looks blackened and burnt, but it tastes delicious! The crust is actually not all that thick or bready despite it being deep dish. The pizza sauce has a nice sweetness to it that's not too overwhelming and the cheese is delicious.  As for toppings, we had Italian sausage and spinach. I would certainly recommend the sausage.
the.best.pizza .ever.  It gets super packed but is well worth the wait. Bring anyone here to show them *true* chicago style pizza!

Definitely do their "priority seating" thing online. Even with that, it took an hour and a half to get a table (we were quoted 30-1 hour) and then you have to wait an hour while your pizza cooks... Other than that everything about this place is amazing. The interior is cute and reminds you of any of the other Chicago pizza joints, and the waitress, while overwhelmed, was still friendly. The sausage pizza was absolutely AMAZING!!!!! I have been a die hard fan of Gino's (despite being told it's a tourist pizza, not the real deal) but I may have to change my allegiance...I had been told this was where true Chicagoans go for their deep dish, and now I totally get why. The pizza was easily some of the best I've ever had.  Overall, come on an off night, cuz they aren't exactly the best with managing reservations. But no matter what the wait or price or whatever, the pizza is worth it.

I have had many, many deep dish pizzas in my time and then I moved to Chicago from the suburbs and heard about the secret known as Pequods. I had to try it for myself. The virdict... one of the best pies in the City. The toppings are fresh and largely cut, the crust is a blackened delicious Joy. This is a must visit restaurant hands down. You must try this out.

I am on vacation in Chicago and went yesterday. What a mistake! My friend/host during this trip called ahead and made a "priority seating" arrangement for our four person party for 7pm. We arrived a bit early and checked in. We were told that our "priority seating" got us a 45 min - 1 hour wait. Uh, ok. So we go outside and wait.  After 1 hour we check back in, only to be told that we have "at least another half hour" to wait. We're disappointed, but we wait. After half an hour, we check back in. Again, we are told that we have "at least another half hour." So the 45 min - 1 hour wait that we were promised turned into a 2 hour minimum wait. Ridiculous. We mulled over our options and decided to stick it out. We finally got seated around 9pm.  After we were seated, three of us ordered beers and we asked the waitress about pizza ordering time (we tried to see if we could pre-order while we were outside, but were told they don't do that after 5pm on weekends). She told us that the pizza would take up to an hour and 25 minutes to arrive. Good grief. After several minutes, the waitress brings me my Blue Moon. But a lot of time goes by and my two friends' beers are nowhere to be seen. We flag down the waitress and it turns out she lost their order, so she has to retake it.  Finally, the pizza arrives. I got a personal pizza with ground beef, mushrooms, and garlic. Just FYI, some people will tell you the pan crust is deep dish, but it is not. The ground beef was under seasoned (actually, the pizza as a whole was, come to think of it) and there's not enough cheese on it. I had to keep adding parmesan and oregano.  All in all, horrible experience. Spent nearly 4 hours on eating mediocre pizza. I will never come back and I'm going to make sure to tell other visiting friends to stay away!
The pizza was very average. I was told it was amazing. There was nothing amazing about average pizza. Lou's pizza 4ever.

I wanted to kick off my first trip to Chitown right with a deep dish pizza. I was originally going to go to Lou Malnati's but my well-traveled friends steered me to Pequod's which is apparently where the real Chicagans go. My group of 4 waited an hour to be seated at 8pm on a Thursday. It took close to another hour before we actually got our deep dish pie.  Caesar salad (9) - Pretty basic. It was pricey considering the salad came with nothing but what tasted like packaged croutons and one lone cherry tomato. Large w/ italian beef, mushrooms, onions (30) - Chicago is know for its italian beef sandwich so I figured may as well hit 2 birds with 1 stone and get it on my pie. The pizza came piping hot and the cheese were perfectly gooey. Pequod's is known for the burnt cheese that coats the edge of the pie and that was probably my favorite part. I'm usually not big on crust and unfortunately Pequod's wasn't an exception. I like my crust to be crispier but theirs is on the doughy, airy side. Was it delicious? Hell yes.  Would I wait 2 hours again? Doubtful. Should you go if it's your first deep dish experience in Chicago? Definitely.
Deep dish, burnt crust.  Yummy and crunchy.  Light, short pizza dough, almost like pastry.
Mediocre  pie . Tonight has an hour wait, maybe 3 dozen people waiting outside and 13 (13!) Booths with No one  seated at them.  Room for about 65.... fail.

Maybe because I'm not a local and don't know what it means to have a Chicago pizza but this place was just okay for me. In one week I tried 3 pizza places and this was 3rd on my list. Pizza was fine, but didn't live up to the hype.

Pequod's is my favorite pizza in town.  They are the only place I enjoy that does multiple types - pan, stuffed, tossed - and they are all amazing to me to in their own way.  Its a fun place to watch the game, and they have good service.  Only issue is when you are seated downstairs at a two top and the bar gets to crowded if feels like you are being elbowed or someone might splash their drink on your pizza.  If you can sit upstairs, this is a great experience.

Well, I found my favorite pizza in Chicago. This place is awesome. It is in a pretty low key spot on Clybourn just past Webster, slightly busy street, parking is not very easy on the street. If you come past 6pm any night, expect a long wait, we happened to get here right before the evening rush and did not have to wait, and if you're coming in on a weekend, there is usually a very long line outside, but it's worth the wait! We sat upstairs, it's a very cool/ fun vibe all over. There are a few TV's around, but nothing too overwhelming and everyone that works here is really nice.  We started with a house salad, big enough to share, and then we went to the pizza... We ordered the Medium pan pizza, we each only ate one slice it was so delicious and filling. You choose your own toppings, they don't have any set pizzas on the menu, and the pizza was divine. The crust is sweet, buttery and savory in one heavenly bite, along with the sauce and toppings, it's just amazing.  I will for sure be back! :)

Pequod's is my favorite deep dish spot in Chicago. The pizzas are famous for having a brunt cheese crust, which sets it apart from most other spots in the city. It's open till really late (2AM), so it's the perfect spot to end the night, though the portions are enormous.

This was the first time I had proper pan pizza -- and I loved it! Usually I'm a thin crust type of girl and of course once in a while I  crave my Lou and my Gino's, but pan pizza was never that appealing to me. BF's craving led us to this place, and I immediately loved the ambiance. We were seated upstairs and our order was taken fairly quickly.  We started with the combo appetizer and I immediate fell in love with the mozzarella sticks and mushroom poppers. They were hot, crispy and tasted fresh.  For the pizza, it took them about 30-40mins to get it to us. We had sausage and pepperoni with 1/2 mushroom and 1/2 peppers. They did not skimp on the toppings.
