I order from here often once or twice a week it's either big or a small order and Im always indecisive depending on what I'm ordering because I always get a big order for my office but I call during the day and I must say I'm absolutely always satisfied and impressed with the phone girl named (Natalie) she is so efficient and fast and knows what I want and talks to fast it's amazing (sometimes I could be a pain asking a lot of questions to help me figure out how much pizza I need) I usually never leave reviews but I order from here often and I wanted to show some love so she doesn't get unnoticed she's doing a great job her customer service is awesome, as far as pizza it's a amazing I recommend the deep dish over the thin crust I am generally not a fan of deep dish, but this pizza is a MUST! I love pequods

We love the pizza by the slice. Nice, crispy thin crust, with fresh toppings.  Great for the family so everyone can get the exact topping they want on their piece. Can be very crowded on weekend evenings!

This is the place we take out-of-town family and friends when they want "Chicago" pizza. This is the best pan pizza in town. Their sauce is bomb and they have an excellent variety of toppings to choose from. If you like the classics - pepperoni, sausage, spinach, mushrooms, onions, etc. they'll have it and they are always fresh and delicious. If you are feeling adventurous I recommend trying a version of a Hawaiian pizza with jalapeños, Canadian bacon (and/or bacon) and pineapple. Their "secret" is the caramelized cheese around the crust. I could seriously eat pizza from here every day of my life (if I also had the time to work it all off every day).

Best deep dish pizza ever! Nothing compares, especially when you dine-in (rather than carry-out). I don't think they have very good apps or a salad, and the thin isn't very good either, but they still get 5 stars because the deep dish is incredible. They really should improve the quality of their other offerings

We often go to Pequod's with another couple prior to going to see a movie at the Webster 11 across the street.  This is one of our favorite pies in the city. The Good: The pizza.  Both the deep dish and the thin crust are exemplary.  The other item we really enjoy are the Jalapeno Poppers; they are filled with cheddar cheese instead of the typical cream cheese and it makes for a very delicious appetizer.  I would encourage anyone to try the sampler as well.  This place also has some great beer selections; I'm personally a big fan of the Half Acre Lead Feather. The Bad: Occasionally they will overcook the pizza, usually the pan.  A couple times I've had mine come out with a burnt bottom, which doesn't ruin the meal but is rather disappointing. Also, if you order a Pan Pizza it will take over an hour... not necessarily a bad thing but definitely something to keep in mind. The Ugly: Make sure you call ahead for seating, the host stand is a hot nightmare.  Everything is done old school with pen and paper and everything is very disorganized.  My wife and I once had to eat at the bar because we had been told we had an hour and a half wait after having waited for an hour and a half already (I think the host got his sheets of paper out of order and was seating people who had just showed up while we continued to wait).  I understand it's not easy to deal with a restaurant when it is as small as Pequod's and gets as busy as Pequod's does, but the people at the host stand are often overwhelmed and nowhere near up to the task. That said, this place is a Chicago staple for a reason, and a definite must-eat for anyone trying to sample the city's best pizza.
Their thick crust is quite bready, which is nice compared to the overly cheesy ones. The cheese gets slightly burnt on the crust, and i consider this the best part!!

Came in here for lunch. Had there lunch special which is a personal pizza, salad and drink for $5-6 bucks. When I came on a Friday afternoon, place was busy. Sat at the bar with some coworkers so we didn't have to wait as long. The guy at the bar was really friendly and helped us with our order. I'm from SoCal and pizza is def my favorite thing to eat so Chicago style was a must to get when in town. Thought pizza was excellent. It reminded me of what Chicago style pizza is about. This place does get crowded and service can run a little on the slow side so be prepared. Overall good experience.
I was looking forward to this pizza after all of its positive reviews. So incredibly disappointed. The pizza was all dough and literally zero cheese. Its safe to say ill never eat here again.

Hey Yelpers, So I've ordered from Pequod's before and my pizza was delicious!! I wasn't in the mood for pizza so I decided to get the mostaccioli with basil pesto sauce; that was the worst decision I could have made. I knew something was off from the color of my dish to the greasy-buttery looking noodles...Ugh ick. With a whole lot of hesitation I decided to dig in and take a bite, well that was the 2nd worst decision I made for the day...I'm 0 for 2 here folks!! That mess was so nasty I damn near gagged and puked, I even had a co-worker try it and well she too had the same response. I'm a pesto kind of girl and this dish was utterly disappointing, so glad I had an opportunity to waste $12 today!! The delivery guy was great at least and super nice!! Sincerely,  I can not believe they actually thought I would eat this crap

Very disappointed with the pizza. From the way other yelpers describe it I went in thinking this would be the pinnacle of chicago style deep dish. Sadly what i recieved after an hour wait was equivalent to a greasy crouton with a thin flavorless layer of tomato sauce and an even thinner layer of cheese. If i had been blindfolded and fed this, I'd assume it was an overcooked breadstick. Honestly I've had better pizza from Domino's. If this is what chicago style pizza is really like, I wasn't missing out on much.

Pequod's is Chicago's best pizza. That's it. I've grown up in Chicago my entire life and have had the best thin, pan and deep dish all over the city. When it comes to pan pizza, Pequod's is the place. The crust is caramelized and crunchy, the pizza has just the right amount of cheese and sauce. A lot of places either put too much sauce or too much cheese, but the ratio is perfection here. The pepperoni gets a crisp on the edges, too.  Even when the place was packed, the wait wasn't too long -- 30 minutes. There are so many seats here, with two bars and two floors of seating, you won't be waiting too long (at least from my experience).
I visited here after seeing this place on the Food Network.  It is so delicious!  So much food - I can still taste the delicious crispy crust!!  Can't wait to go back!

Hands down my family's absolute favorite pizza spot.  Top it off with amazing service. Booked a table for my daughter to celebrate her 13th birthday with friends. Our server was so helpful as was the manager and other staff. I always over order to bring some home for the next day. We will continue coming back.
I love this place for what it's not: it's not deep dish   Chicago and it's not gross cracker crust Chicago. It can be hard to get in but it's worth it.
Pizza so delicious, you can overlook their awful pick up process. Seriously, it's that good.

Literally the rudest people ever work here. Grey haired man at the door a jerk from the moment we walked on. Empty tables not being sat while people are waiting an hour and a half. Don't waste your time.
came here for dinner on a weekend, thankfully we didn't have to wait too long. We were sat upstairs in a huge comfy booth and the pizza was absolutely delicious
Went for the 1st time this past weekend and the pizza was amazing. Was about a hour wait but expected with it being a Saturday night.

Qtr slice, half a slice, whole slice ay!!! Yeahhh (Gucci mane voice). Seriously the best pizza in chicago. Deep dish is slap your momma good. I usually go with the classic. Great thing is if you call ahead they can put your name on the list and start your pizza. It's worth the wait and they have alcohol. Nice little movie and dinner spot. Pepperoni and sausage is Brackin!!! Eat up its delicious and yummy. Really great for Netflix and food coma.

Amazing pizza, even worth bearing its sports bar bro ambiance. It wasn't quite as heavy as other Chicago deep dish I've had, which was refreshing. The crust is what made it different. We arrived at 6:15 on a Saturday night and waited an hour and fifteen minutes for pizza, which was noted on a sign before we ordered. Of course this varies, but plan accordingly if you are on a schedule. Ordering an appetizer, which arrived in about fifteen minutes, helped!
Can't go wrong with Pequod's, always worth the wait. The only place I go for pizza when I get to pick of course.

We had a going away party on a Saturday. Thankfully, they allow you to put in a table request the day before via their site, which was great for our party of 10. (This is not a reservation. Just gives you priority seating.) You still have to come in a little earlier to wait, they will give you a pager which works near the bar at the Drinking Bird.  We ordered 3 large pizzas for 10 people and still had a few slices leftover. Pizza wise, it was okay...I wasn't drawn to it. there wasn't any flavor that stood out. it was just very thick pan pizza (not a layered pizza). I still like Lou Malnati's style pizza more and may prefer Giordano's over this.   Service was fine and they also allowed us to split the check with many credit cards.

This is my favorite pizza joint. I can't say anything bad about this place. Everything is sooo perfect!! I never eat sausage but this sausage pizza is soooooo amazing. Even if we waited 1hr for a table, and then another 1 1/2 hr for the food. It was all worth it. It used to be a 6 stars in my eyes, now it's only a 5. Hopefully they will go back to being a 6. :-)

One of the best pizzas of my life.  It's like a Ferrari of pizzas.  You can tell that they put in a lot of work and amazing ingredients to perfect their recipe. But to cover the whole experience.  This place is awesome.  It has two bars.  One upstairs and one downstairs along with seating for eating in both.  It is like a dive bar, that happens to serve some of the best pizza in the world.  Let's just say if I lived within walking distance, I would be here far too often! :) Drinks were good too.  They have blue moon on tap and make cocktails.  Oh, and the sausage pizza is what we had and it is a must because I think they make their own sausage because it was mike mama's meat balls on there. If you live in Chicago or within 50 miles of this place and haven't tried it then you are missing out.  There is a reason why it was voted top 10 pizzas in America.

Pequods is a good as pizza gets. Plus this location is open late, late, late...perfect to hit after the bars in Lincoln Park.  The deep dish is excellent. Great Chicago-style done right. Sauce is rich, tomato-y and tasty. The thin crust is also the bomb. Love the pepperoni.  Expect to have to wait for a table - especially late at night when everybody else has closed their kitchen. But, trust me, it will be worth the wait.
Best Deep Dish Pizza in the world. Period.

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago. Best part is the crust. Most after midnight pizza places are horrendous, this place has amazing deep dish pizza. I've ordered after 1am before and the quality is on point. I am kind of bummed I don't live in Chicago to order a pie right now!
one of the best deep dish places in town.  and theyre open late!

The pizza is really good, and they are a Hawks bar, so there is Blackhawks swag everywhere which is nice. Is it worth waiting outside in line for? No, probably not. But if you happen to drive by and there's no line, you should totally check this place out.
I was actually impressed with their pizza. I may even like it better than lou malnatis. The staffs were really friendly too.

Maybe it's the crust... Maybe it's the insides of pure gooey heaven maybe it's that I can put whatever the fuck I want inside (haha) what am I describing here?!  A GOOD DAMN PIZZA  I love deepdish. I know Giordano's is supposed to be the best or even Lou mal- but I really never like their deepdish the way I love Pequod's. They are good until you come here. And than a little light in your head turns on. And you realized you were settling for less!  They have Chicago beer and Chicago pizza. And they keep this city girl happy :)
Since I was a kid this is my fav pizza place in the city over Lous for sure! Always willing to accommodate us and so great to their guests!
I recommend this place! :) It's my boyfriend's favorite and he's always so thrilled when I order it as a surprise.

This is some great Chicago deep-dish pizza. The choice of toppings is fantastic, and the portion sizes very generous for a great price. We were a group of six in for some lunchtime pizza, and I was amazed at the amount of food we got in two pizzas. We couldn't finish everything, but taking away was no problem. The place is fairly small and very busy, so we did have to queue for some time outside, but it was worth the wait. Just keep this in mind if you're planning to visit, especially in a large group.

I went to Pequod's for the first time about a month ago. The pizza was not for me but people love it. The cheese to bread ratio is very uneven. There is so much bread and it is kind of dry. The one thing i did like was they make great homemade ranch. If you like a very "bready" pizza then this is the place for you.

I have my reservations about Pequods, but I do have to admit their caramelized crust on their pan pizza is something I dream about.  Went down to Pequod's with a few friends a couple Saturdays ago around 5pm. We were hoping to make it a quick visit to get back home for a football game, but were told about an hour and a half wait. By the time we actually got seated it was 7:30pm, and then you need to wait about another hour for your pan pizza to cook. We got a thin crust and a pan, both were great. I still think I prefer Lou Malnati's more bready crust edges on the deep dish, but our group was split half and half on that one. Thin crust was excellent, plenty of food for four of us with a medium thin and pan.  Overall, don't know that the five hour trip is worth the pizza when there are places like Lou's around.

Simply delicious.  Come early!  At peak hours it is still worth the wait though.  Definitely try the deep dish pizza, the crust is full of flavor and the ingredients taste hot and fresh.  One of the places that I always bring out-of-towners to enjoy Chicago pizza and some beers and they always love it here.

We got here on a Saturday night around 6-7 PM. There was about an hour or so wait. Meanwhile, we luckily got a spot at the bar and enjoyed some beers and the Blackhawks game.  Finally, it was time to eat. We got the deep dish pizza with caramelized crust. Pizza was pretty delicious, but the crust is what made it unique. I've pretty much had the best of the best when it comes to deep dish, but this place is right up there. It's hard to be blown away when you've had the best, but there was definitely no denying that the pizza and experience is worth the trip.
This is my go to deep dish pizza place in the city.  The burnt crusty edges and flavorful sausage make this my favorite.  LOVE.

I have no idea what took me so long to find this place, I walk past it every day. First things first, no reservations....sort of. You can call and get your name on their list as if you walked in on time. Friday's and Saturday's are crazy. There is a very small bar on the first floor, but if you need to wait, I would suggest going up to the second floor bar. The food is great, the crust on their deep dish is unreal, but overall a little to bready for me. If you are from the area just get the regular pizza, its crazy good. Pricing is fair, they tell you your pizza will take an hour but it almost never does.

This place has the best deep dish pizza in Chicago! I tell everyone to go try this place and they all get hooked. Don't let the look of the crust fool you. It's one of the best parts of the pizza. Nice 2 level place and good service. Parking can be a little bit of an issue, but well worth it. Blackhawks bar as well with lots of craft beers, etc.
Pequod's is a great alternative to Lou Manalti's. The crusted cheese was great. I loved the atmosphere. Would definitely come back!
We just threw a surprise party and this place pulled it off perfectly. Such a great experience and of course, the pizza is incredible.
THE BEST PAN PIZZA IN CHICAGO!!! (or deep dish if you think it's deep dish, but really it's pan) Caramelized cheese crust is all i need to say.
I just have to say best deep dish in Chicago  1.Pequods  2. Lou Malnati's 3. Gino's East.
One of the best pizzas I've had.The service is awesome the ambiance is great.Definately in my top 3.!

This pizza is nothing short of amazing! My friend and I were shopping in the area and decided to stop in for an early dinner one night.  Luckily, because it was around 4PM we were seated right away.  My friend had been there before so she recommended the deep dish and the fried zucchini.  We ended up getting 1 personal deep dish pizza, 1 personal thin crust pizza and fried zucchini for an appetizer.  The service was quick-- even when the restaurant started to get very busy around 5PM.  The fried zucchini was very good and held us over until the deep dish pizza was done!  When the pizza did come out it was cooked to perfection.  It's important to note that the deep dish takes significantly longer to cook so make sure to time it right when you order. I'll definitely be back.  If you don't want to have to wait I would recommend making a reservation, or calling for take-out as the restaurant itself is not very big and there is always a line by the door.

yes, the burnt-cheese-on-crust is great. everything else is pants. the sauce is too sweet. the crust is too bread-y and too thick. there wasn't much cheese. the place is pretty dirty. i'd rather order an extra-crispy thin crust at Lou's. no, it doesn't replicate the burnt-cheese, but everything else is orders of magnitude better.

Been here a few times and love the place. This offers something a little different to Lou's. The atmosphere, the drinks and the sports bar feeling. This place can fill up quickly on weekends and get a little noisy but its worth the wait. I'm torn between Lou and Pequod's as to my favorite all time Pizza. However, I do love the rustic pans, caramelized base and crust.  Service is with a smile. This place is dang cheap and services great food
The pizza is bomb. Theres something about sausages on chicago pizzas... its way better than the sausages on pizza in california. They have alcoholic root beer here. I was a happy camper.
I love this place. Now that Door Dash will deliver it to my house ( I moved out of their normal delivery zone), I eat it 2-3 times a month. Mmmmmmmm. Caramelized cheese.

We called in the morning to request priority seating for a table for 2 at 7pm. We arrived promptly at 7 and were told to return in 20 minutes to get a pager. 20 minutes later, we picked up our pager and were told the wait would be around 1 hr. We came back 1 hour later and were told that there would be "soon", despite the fact that several parties behind us (without prior reservations) had already been seated at that time. 20 minutes later, we were told that there were still several parties ahead of us and it would be 30 MORE minutes, though I saw many parties behind us had already been seated in the interim. We finally gave up around 9:15pm (more than 2 hours after our reservation) and went somewhere else. It seems that this place is COMPLETELY DISORGANIZED and for the quality of their pizza, it's definitely NOT worth the 2+ hour wait. OVERRATED! Don't want to imagine what the wait time would be if we hadn't called ahead to put our names on the priority seating list...

SO much bread. And I love bread, but this was beyond excessive. I should add that we got our deep dish to go, so maybe it would have been better at the restaurant. Pequods has good sauce but lou malnatis deep dish is way better. This was like 2 inches of foam consistency bread under an average amount of sauce, cheese, and toppings. :/

Although the cheese slices were completely bland and the crust was super soggy for being a thin crust, this review was is solely on the deep dish and service. I've tried deep dish all around the city : giodanos, Lou M, UNOs, etc.. This is by far the best deep dish my husband and I have ever had. This was our second attempt to try this place out. The first time was too long of a wait. We went early the second time around and were seated right away. We order both, a full deep dish and thin slices while we waited. The slices were horrible, so we couldn't figure out why this place was so packed all the time and quite honestly, were not too excited to get our pizza... But boy  were we wrong. We ordered just pepperoni and it was amazing. The taste of the pepperoni, the right amount of cheese, sauce wasn't chunky, and the crust was to die for. Also the waitress was very nice. Definitely a come again place!

I've been to Pequod's in Morton Grove,  the individual stuffed pizza is the best! buttery crust.  The individual size is just enough for one person.  The wait service  is good.  And i love the old-fashioned divvy bar.  Good beer selection, sometimes  you have to wait, but worth it.
A marvelous member of the Deep Dish family - Pequod's makes a very fresh, rich pizza with the most amazing toasted-black-cheese crust. Love it every single time!
Pequods is my favorite deep dish pizza place in the city! I recommend it to all visitors and consider it the finest comfort food around. Does it get better than carmelized crust? I think not.
A GREAT Pizza! The carmelized crust tastes sooo good!

I stopped in for lunch and with this being my 1st time I sorted thru the reviews to help me make my decision. I opted for the $ 4.95 lunch special that included a personal pan pizza and a soda. I had a sausage pizza which was highly recommended and added pepperoni with extra cheese. The additional toppings were extra. It came out in about 30 minutes and I was impressed with the sausage"s flavor, pepperoni was meh, extra cheese was also a good choice as always. The crust was very crispy around the edges and caramelized cheese set it the f off.
Best deep dish in Chicago! Only slightly more amazing than lou's, because of the bubbly crispy cheese crust.
Contrary to what outsiders think of Chicagoans we rarely eat deep dish pizza but if we do its Pequods
Best deep dish in the city! Expect to have a bit of a wait but it is definitely worth it. You do need to also be in the mood for it because man is it filling.

As a Chicagoan, I'm embarrassed to admit that I just had my very first Pequod's experience last weekend. I can't believe I've been missing out on this much goodness for this long!  Pequod's is a jam-packed pizza place, and for good reason! Their pizza is the ooey-gooeyist of all the Chicago style pizzas. Their famous carmelized crust is just as good as everyone says it will be, and their tomato sauce is hearty and flavorful!  If you come to this location in the City, be prepared to wait! They do not take reservations but do have a priority list, which cuts down the wait time. We came in on a Sunday evening and waited about 40 minutes for a table, and again about 45 minutes for the pizza to come out. While the atmosphere is definitely divey, and while the place is jam-packed, it's worth it to experience the greatest of the Chicago deep dish options.

Angela was our server and she was magical. I mean.. This pizza is superb but our service was awesome and it's because of Angela (upstairs, not to be confused with Angela downstairs). Much love for the good vibes

I have criss-crossed this great nation, sampling the local varieties. I lived for a year in Italy. I eat pizza a lot.  This is my favorite pizza. This is not "Chicago-style Pizza", though it is Pizza from Chicago. This is the Cadillac of Pizzas. It takes a super long time to cook and the lines at Pequod's are always horrendous, so it is not the pizza that I eat most often. But it is the pizza that I dream about most often.  (side note, italian pizza is really great, and may be the "original" or whatever, but the spirit of America is progress, and Pequod's is progress)
Too busy and the pizza is barely worth the wait if eating in, but yes it's the deep dish pizza place typically known to be a true Chicagoan's favorite due to its crust.

Pequod's is truly one of the best pizza's ever. The butter crust with the carmelized cheese to the edge is amazing. Every place else wishes they were Pequod's. Only downside is the location is small. But they make up for it with great pizza.

If I had to eat just one thing for the rest of my life, this place would probably be the one - love love love this pizza joint to death!  It is JAF x 100 - hot peppers and basil all day man on my deep dish.  I love my friend Aamer for introducing this to me, so happy that he is the white guy in a brown guys body for letting me know about this gem of a place.  And whoever says this place is OK or it's not as good as lous or giordanos can really go back to their moms basement and eat tombstone pizza.

Pequod's has excellent pizza with the caramelized crust. A big fan of the pizza. They do need to work on training their staff when you dine in the restaurant. We ordered a large Chicago Style Pizza with Onions, Pepperoni and Mushrooms.  After having salad and waiting 45 minutes our pizza arrived with Onions, Sausage and Mushrooms. We told the server and she confirmed the ticket was given correctly but the kitchen screwed it up. (not sure how).  We told her we would just go ahead and eat it instead of waiting. (I don't particularly like sausage on pizza)  We got our bill and nothing was taken off. Could have just taken off our drinks (2 ice teas) or the salad perhaps but even the $3 for the meat would have been fine. Or even an offer of a free dessert - We would have declined. I e-mailed Pequod's and didn't name our server (didn't want to get her in trouble) but just let them know this was not my expectation when their kitchen makes a mistake.  I received no reply. I love the Pizza but think this place needs some training on making their customers seem valued.

Pequods is the bomb. Their deep dish is one of the best the city has to offer-the burnt cheesy crust makes it, and the tomato sauce---yummmm! Family loves pepperoni/sausage combo. Thin crust is also good if that's what you're in the mood for but the deep dish at Pequods is what's up. Haven't tried anything else so I can't review any other food items.

I come from time to time with the fam when we're in need of a Chicago pizza fix. One of the better pie's you can find around the city. Almost to good. Had to stop my daughter from eating to fast as she stopped half threw her slice to cough a gigantic ball of melted cheese. Swished it down with some pink lemonade and no stopping.

I hit up Lou's and Pequod's on my recent trip to Chicago and I have to admit Pequod's wins. It was a much more satisfying pizza that was still tasty on the flight home the next day. We ordered a sausage and giardiniera on our pie and they were fantastic. Quick comparison, Lou's has a thinner style crust that is formed into an pan and is really crispy and a thick layer of fresh cheese and a hearty very fresh tasting sauce, not very greasy even with the buttered crust. Pequod's on the other hand is a thicker crust formed into the pan that is amazingly flavorful and juicy, The cheese is dripping off the edge of the pie and is much more of your decadent style pizza cheese. The house made sausage is not as fully loaded across the pie as Lou's does but it is everywhere and it is very tasty and you can tell it is made fresh. The sauce is not as hearty as Lou's but is more flavorful (in my opinion). The giardiniera was this awesomely spicy little Italian pepper that really provided a great kick of spicy to the pizza. Think more long hots flavor than jalapeno. Finally, I think the caramelized crust wins over the buttered crust hands down. It is an awesome layer of crispy deliciousness!.  It was worth trying both since it was my first time there but on my next visit it is Pequod's or bust.  Side note: call ahead and get your name on the list. They don't do reservations but you can call on your way over because this place is packed and even after your wait it takes 35 minutes for your pies to cook. But that is the nature of the deep dish pies.

This thing smelled so freakin good when we picked it up. We delightfully inhaled the smells during the car ride to our eating spot. To be honest, the first bite was kind of disappointing. It was decent, but no where near as good as it smelled. What happened??? The crust was kind of dry -- maybe intentional? The sauce was not as plentiful as it needed to be with that kind of crust. And the sausage was super bland. It looked like it was made by hand, which I love, but the taste was non-existent. Sad, so very sad.

The pizza is amazing and the wait was worth it.  The only problem is when the hype is so high you expect greatness.  I would've like the caramelization of the crust would've been done on all of the crust, not just the top.  The bottom layer was a little to thick and was inconsistent with the top layer.  But nonetheless it's definitely a worthy Chicago style pizza.
Best deep dish in Chicago! Once you order it's a bit of a wait to receive your food but it's definitely worth it! They make their pizza fresh and cook the crust to the perfect level of crisp.

Hands down, unequivocally the best deep dish pizza period. There is no equal, I have eaten and eat a lot of pizza and nothing on this planet compares to a Pequod's pepperoni deep dish pizza. The caramelized cheese is amazing!!!  Fun to eat inside, the place has character. You may wait a bit for your freshly made, delicious caramelized crust pizza, but it is worth every second.  Great tasting bubbly fountain soda awaits to refresh your palate.
My favorite Chicago Pan Pizza! Yum! Crust melts in your mouth. Fresh delicious toppings and cold beer!

Pretty darn good deep dish pizza ... Not greasy & you don't feel heavy afterwards . I would have to say it's much much better than Edwardo's, Lou, giordano, Gino east, etc.! If you want deep dish, this is the place. The don't take Rez but if u call & tell them u want to come , they will move u to the top of the list when u arrive . Not sure how that works especially if everyone shows up at the same time ... The place is small so I would recommend eating off hours and aim to get a seat at the bar. We found one within 10 mins and gave up our spot for a 2 hour wait!

This place has great pizza, but the service is literally the worst I have ever experienced!  We waited over an hour and NEVER were seated!  Jimmy, the a**hole host, just kept seating people out of order, giving preference to his friends first!  He claimed these were people that called ahead for priority seating, but according to the giant sign on the wall, that cuts your waiting time in half. People on that list waited 15 minutes and got seated, while our party of 4 had to wait over 3 times that long!  Also, they had several tables waiting to be cleared for 15-20 minutes plus while they just sat around, not doing anything!  Seriously the worst experience ever. We left after over an hour of waiting and will never be back!

Stop acting like a misguided tourist by going to those "other" pizza places. THIS IS CHICAGO DEEP DISH! But in all seriousness you will not regret it! The pizza is a perfect ratio of cheese, sauce, and that sweet sweet caramelized crust. The rest of the menu beyond the pizza is rather average, but let's be honest if you're ordering something other than pizza you're doing it wrong.
fun atmosphere and amazing deep dish pizza, my personal favorite is the pepperoni deep dish. The crust is mouth watering! Definitely recommend going here if you are craving delicious deep dish pizza

Hmmm... where do I start? Basically if I ask you what your favorite deep dish pizza is and you give me a different answer other than PEQUODS, I'll either assume you've never tried Pequods and/or you're from out of town... or that you have bad taste.  Loads of cheese and sauce and they don't skimp out on toppings. THAT CARMELIZED CRUUUUUST. Their wait times are anywhere from an hour to more. But can you blame them?? It's deep dish pizza made by the Pizza Gods. I always bring my out of town guests to eat Pequods and I've never heard them say anything like "Hmmm, I've had better." or "It's just ok." Their eyes light up as they take that first bite and tell me things like "HOLY F*** THAT'S GOOD!" or "Don't talk to me for the next 30 minutes as I stuff my face with goodness." (Now that I think about it, I really hope they're all being sincere.) I can't remember if I've ever had bad service there, but I think personally the pizza itself trumps and cancels out anything negative, so 5 stars!

3 hour wait...3 hours!  I thought to myself, there is no way any pizza is worth waiting this long for! We were a group of 7 and killed time at a nearby bar to snack on tacos. When it was our time we headed to the restaurant and took our seats upstairs in a booth under a large tv. The waitress took our orders and we were eating cheesy, bready appetizers within 15 minutes. I tried not to gorge so I could save my real appetite for this infamous pizza. I managed to eat half a appetizer and finally 45 minutes later our pepperoni and sausage pizza arrived. It was freakin amazing. I cherished every bite and wished my stomach was bigger to hold more of this saintly pizza. Others at the table ordered double sausage which was comical because when it arrived we could barely see the crust...there was soooo much sausage! Everyone who ate it said it was too much so don't bother getting a double order, they hook it up plenty without needing that.  I left smiling and think this is the best pizza I've ever had in Chicago. It's also very reasonably priced compared to other places. 3 hours is steep though so I'd attempt to go at a down time or order to go.

Pequot's makes me want to go back to Chicago!!!! When I visited Chicago we asked every uber/lyft/local from Chicago where the best deep dish pizza was and everyone geared us toward Lou Malnati's or Giordano's Pizzeria. So we tired all of them and hands down Pequot's was the best deep dish in Chicago!!!! loved it!

Pequod's has my favorite chicago style pizza. Their crust is perfection. It's buttery and light without being soggy which I often find to be a problem with some deep dish pizzas. The servers are great and friendly. On one occasion I did run into a host that seemed to be a bit of a ditz but besides that, the service is good.

If you want a true Pequods's experience you have to go to the original in Morton Grove. That place has the best pizza in the Chicagoland area and nothing comes close. Obviously this location is similar but I have had a few bad experiences, one being the 'za had literally no crust, that makes it 3 stars. Regardless of that I will still always and forever pick Quod's over Lou's everyday and twice on Sundays.

I've only tried deep dish pizza twice (NorCal and LA) prior to Pequods. I normally prefer thin crust pizza, but Pequods definitely had me thinking twice! The restaurant looks small but tucked on the side is a staircase for additional seating upstairs. We came at an off time (around 3:30pm) and were seated immediately. By around 5pm, the place was completely packed with a wait to be seated.  Appetizer Combo ($9.95): Deep fried zucchini, jalapeno poppers, mozzarella sticks, and mushrooms! 2 sauces accompany the plate of deep fried goodness: ranch and the most perfect cocktail sauce. I enjoyed all but the jalapeno poppers which had a tad too much cheese. Perfect appetizer to share. Medium Pan Pizza ($15.50): Toppings range from $1.45-$3.50 each for add on. We added sausage & pepperoni to our beautiful 6 slice deep dish pizza. I absolutely LOVE crust on a pizza and Pequods delivered. Crispy cheese crust on the edges and perfectly cooked crust on the bottom of the pizza. CRUST HEAVEN. I can't stop thinking about it. Pequods is out of the city for those who visit Chicago but it's worth the trip.

Sometimes this place has wait times of 2 hours, because it's so good. Your best bet is pickup, which takes about 45 minutes, or even delivery, which can take up to 90 minutes. Either way, you'll be getting some of the best pizza anywhere. Chicago people joke that the best pizza in the city is always "my neighborhood."  Peqoud's is a great neighbor to have.
I like Peqouds deep dish. Yum. So filling. So satisfying. Reasonable.  Decent beer and drink list/menu. Not fancy nor pretentious. Causal.
great food, inviting atmosphere, great staff... sure bet for your money.

Delicious pizza, terrible wait.  So the pizza is 4-stars, but the service is 2-stars. I put in a request online for priority seating about 4 days early and never got any sort of email confirmation so I called the day of to confirm. The girl who answered wasn't all that friendly and begrudgingly added me to the list. It was packed when we walked in and I was told about an hour wait. Well...we waited 2 hours. Now I understand the priority seating is not a reservation, but it's supposed to cut the wait time in half. You can't tell me a normal wait time was 4 hours! It's an understatement to say the host seemed overwhelmed, so I'm not sure the priority seating list was really happening.  Once we were seated the service continued to be slow, and the waitress didn't seem to move all that quickly. At about 9:30 the pizza finally arrived and everything was right in the world again. I was so excited about the caramelized cheese on the crust and I'm happy to report it did not disappoint! YUM! Despite the delicious crust, I'll be sticking to my old buddy Lou Malnati in the future - shorter waits and they let you put in your pizza order before you get a table. I will only be revisiting Pequod's for take out.

A few visitors from out of town, who have never had the pleasure of eating deep dish, visited Chicago and was excited to try deep dish pizza at Giordanos or Ginos East. Umm...no, I will have to veto this. You know nothing, friends. Girlfriend and I took them to Pequods instead. I have been to Pequods several times now and left with a bellyful of delicious pizza. The ingredients are fresh and flavorful and the crust, as you may have heard, is caramalized cheesy goodness. We got the sausage, onions, and bell peppers (for me and the others who know how to eat pizza) and the veggie (for those who dont understand pizza). That is the only way to get pizza - sausage, onions, bell pepers, and maybe garlic. Other ingredients are just wrong. The only slight criticism I have is that the pizza is a bit doughy, even for deep dish.  But the sauce, over abundance of cheese, and the fresh ingredients make up for it.

Really crowded place with decent pizza. The crust is a little weird for me. It tastes almost like it has burnt cheese on it? Definitely not bad, just different. My favorite is still Lou's. It's worth a try though. I would recommend eating in over delivery. You can really taste a difference!

I have been here a number of times.  The pizza is good.  We went to see Star Wars across the street.  This restaurant is what PRINTING  money looks like.  2600 yelp reviews.  The place is a filthy dump.  The waitstaff really hustles.  I will probably be back. Happy 2016

Two words: Underwhelming. Disappointing. But this review is solely for the "thin-crust" pizza. I feel like I'm the only Chicagoan (or visitor of any kind) who has something bad to say but I have to say it for anyone who, like me, actually don't like thick pizzas. Sorry, Chicago, but I love me some NY-style pizza. It's the real thing. :P I was with friends who wanted to try the place and thought I'd have a great experience like the many other patrons. However, I guess my first mistake was getting the thin-crust, which is not what they're known for. As I am not a fan of other pizzas, I thought this would be my best bet. For the three of us, the pizzas took 45 minutes. As soon as my pizza arrived, I was disappointed. It was not thin-crust at all. The outer edge where you hold it was really very cushiony, and the rest was just normal thickness. I knew I wouldn't find NY-style but Pequod's definition of thin-crust is way off. But that wasn't really what bothered me. The flavor was just not there. There was nothing about the crust that tasted good (my friends who got pan pizzas said their crust was amazing, so I was envious!). It was really just like plain white bread. The cheese literally sat on the pizza in one sad, rubbery clump, not integrated with any of the vegetables I had selected (they tasted fine but were completely unseasoned). I could only stomach two slices as I was hungry before I just felt like I was eating cheap white bread with plasticy/fake white cheese. Honestly, I've had way better pizzas at Giordanos if you want to talk hyped-up places. Even Blaze Pizza, a franchise, turned out better. Not to mention Dimo's in Wrigleyville which has fantastic pizza. And, crust aside, they win when it comes solely to flavor. My friends were happy with their pan pizzas, though. But if you only like NY-style pizza as I do, don't go even if your friends are raving about it. Let them experience it without you unless you're willing to go for the pan pizza (like I said, I can't speak to it, but I hear it's good and my friends who tried mine agreed it was pretty lame). It's totally not worth the wait and money.

Was able to try this and Lou Malnati's while in Chicago and this place is #1 for deep dish in my book. The service was great and the atmosphere was fun. The crust is the specialty here, they pile layers and layers of cheese on the side of the pan, making a cheesy, burnt crust that made it so crunchy and flavorful. And the fact that we were able to choose the toppings was what got me super excited. After a night of drinking, nothing was more satisfying than this, and of course, we had to order more drinks.. We literally piled it high with mounds of toppings! We got mushrooms, jalapenos, fresh garlic, sausage, Italian beef, and hot giardiniera. The giardiniera and Italian beef is definitely a must-get. Can't wait to come back!

There's nothing like having deep dish on A cold winter day right after picking out a Christmas tree at a local tree lot. That's my favorite memory of Pequods because it was my first experience at delicious deep dish!  Now over a year later it has become one of my MANY favorite pizza stops in Chicago. I also highly recommend their jalapeño poppers... I don't like jalapeños and still ogle over them!  Service is normal, sometimes great, sometimes average!

Really loved this place. Delicious pizza. Good drink menu and good prices. Wait time for food was a bit long (hour) but well worth it. Waitress was super nice and attentive as well...unfortunately don't recall her name. Will be back again if I'm in the area! And recommend to others

great pizza! im not really a pan pizza kinda guy but this pizza made me a believer. if you plan to go to this wonderful stablishment i highly suggest you go with time and a will to wait for 1 hour because it gets busy in there. service is good and the brews are better. definitely going back for more !

I've always like Pequod's.  It tastes like adult pizza to me - darker flavors and not all sweet.  The carmelized crust is yummy.  The lunch special is a great deal, but they won't cook your pre-order anymore.  Not sure why - if people not showing up for their orders is a problem they could just ask for pre-payment and I'd be happy too since you have to wait 25 minutes otherwise (they should tell you that).

Pizza was pretty good. Quite saucy, which I like, but my husband does not. Anchorage's Moose's Tooth is our hometown fave and way better. Our complaint was with the wait. We were on our way to O'Hare for a 4:30 flight when we got to the restaurant at 12:25. The sign at the desk said the pizzas were a 60 minute wait. We were seated and ordered immediately. Sixty minutes later, our server said she had checked and pizza should be out in 10 min, but it took another 20+ minutes. More than an hour twenty for good/not great pizza. We scarfed down a piece and took the rest in a togo box.

I have been a fan of this place for over 10 years!  The crispy garlicky crust is the absolute best.  Only warning..you WILL have to wait to get a table most nights AND then you will have to wait for your pizza to be made.  So sit down and order right away to get the pizza's in the oven.  Well worth the wait in my opinion however.

I've been a loyal fan of Lou's deep dish my whole life... Until I tried this place.  Holy crap.  AMAZING. It was super crowded and we waited almost an hour for our table, but it was well worth it. The burnt cheesie crust is like nothing I've ever tasted before.  I never thought pizza could be a life changing experience, but here we are.

When you enter the store, there is a large sign that essentially says that reservations aren't really reservations, but bump you up to front of waitlist when you arrive (I'm paraphrasing). Unfortunately, they don't do a good job of communicating this prior to getting there.  My party as well as three others (including a bachelor party that was forced to find other food) experienced this.    We received a text message the morning of the "reservation" asking us to confirm the time and amount of people, but nowhere in that message did it convey the variable nature of the time. Normally, not a problem, but if you have a larger party on a tighter schedule (ie bachelor party, or family with small kids), then waiting until 9:30 for an 8:00 PM "reservation" is less than ideal.     Would suggest management improve the pre-reservation communication, both on the website as well as the text messages. In terms of the food, overall quality was decent.   For apps, we ordered the pizza bread, assorted appetizer platter, and pequod salad.  Filled you up, but nothing to write home about in terms of taste. We ordered a thin crust cheese for the kids.   As a native New Yorker, I found the crust a little soggy, and the cheese a little excessive.  Sauce was excellent though.  Kids liked it, so that's all that matters. We also ordered a pan pizza with spinach/garlic as well as green pepper/onion.  It had a nice caramelized crust (highly addictive).  The dough was thick with a generous layer of sauce.  The veggies needed some extra salt, but overall taste was pretty good.  One medium slice was enough to fill me up, and I have a fairly big appetite. In summary, the pizza was pretty good (order the pan pizza over anything else), but I wouldn't wait 90 minutes for it....
Great pizza that's doing its own thing. Rises above your typical Chicago pizza joints without doing anything fancy.

You food (pizza) was rancid! Reliving this experience has given me nightmares but I consider it my duty to warn my fellow Chicagoans of your putrid offerings. Don't order from this establishment if value your stomach! Pass it along!
Catie was rude wanted us to order food all we wanted was a stuff pizza but we will never come back again!!!! Thanks for your business! !!

I don't normally eat pan pizza but this was delicious! The bread and crust was amazing. The bread just melts in your mouth good.  We ordered sausages with extra sauce pan pizza for 3 people. It was plenty!!! We had 3 slices left over. I guess from what the waitress was explaining to me. This is not not considered deep dish but pan pizza. They don't take reservations. So if you have a large party or if if you don't want to wait to long call in and have your name put down the list. Once you arrive with all your part you'll get seat first before all the people who just should up with calling in first. It's weird, but it's not like a reservation where you'll get seated right away. We called in but still has to wait 1 hour to be seated.  I don't know if I'd go back but it was delicious!! And I don't  normally like pan or deep dish pizza. It was something I had to try while in Chicago.  So, go checking out!

There are certain milestones when it comes to becoming a "real Chicagoan" and not just a glossy-eyed transplant from Cleveland. For me, changing the alliance of deep dish establishments was one of them. I had heard about Pequod's from people at work, but I stuck to Pizzeria Due and Giordono's as my go-to places. Until I tried the glorious caramelized buttered crust of Pequod's that is...then it was game over! Is the wait horrible most time? Yes. Is it kind of a pricy option? Yeah. But is it worth it? Heck yes!  If you're dining in, the restaurant is small, poorly lit, has horrible parking, and no where to wait...but the bar next door is pretty chill. But Pequod's delivery range is pretty big so it's easy to skip the hassle, stay in sweatpants, and have it dropped off right at your doorstep. This is THE deep dish to get in Chicago, end of the debate.

Wow!  If you're like me and not a fan of traditional Chicago Deep Dish this is a variant you might want to try.  I personally see this as more of a pan style pizza than a deep dish due to the fluffier thicker crust.  Aside from the great sauce and structure of the pizza the biggest draw is the caramelized cheese ring around the perimeter of the pizza.  It has to be tasted to be understood.  At first your brain wants to think: "Crap, you burned my f'n pizza!" However it's by design.   Originally founded by Burt Katz of Gulivers and Burt's Place fame this place has to be tried.  Periods was sold by Burt many years ago but the pizza is still his design.  If you want a table get there at 5 or 5:30 or be prepared to wait over an hour especially on weekends.

Was super excited to try this place after hearing so much. We ordered take out and the lady who took our order was great. We got home and I was super excited to dive in to the pizza. I cut myself a slice to find that this wasn't deep dish. This was an inch tall cornbread dough with some sauce and cheese on top. The carmalized crust was burnt cheese that didn't make the whole circumference of the pizza. I was disappointed. I prefer Lou malnatis or giordanos.

As a native South Sider we all have our pizza shop loyalties, but every so often you have to stray and find out if all he talk is just that or if you've found another place to add to the rotation. I'll start by telling you this place gets packed and there's almost no way around it, be prepared to get drinks at the bar and average an hour plus wait during peak times, also if you're not aware pan pizza will take anywhere from 45-130 depending on how busy it is, factor that into your plans. Now for the pizza, it was amazing, ordered sausage, pep, and peppers with extra sauce.  Caramelized crust was spot on, cooked perfectly and dos not disappoint in any factor, crust, cheese or toppings.  With a great tap list of craft and many TVs for the games it will be added to my list of highly rated Chicago pizza joints.

A local recommended this place.  I was a little disappointed.  I did not like the salad.  The pizza was not traditional Chicago deep dish, in my opinion, but more common pan pizza ala the chain restaurants like Pizza Hut, with a very thick crust.  I did like the carmelized crust, but the crust did not support the pizza well.  It got very soggy. I also think the sauce was lacking something...probably salt, and I am not a big salty food eater, but it was very bland.  Given how far this place was from downtown, I wouldn't go there again when visiting Chicago.

Pequod's is a Chicago staple, no doubt, however, nothing is worth the terrible experience we had the last time we dined (or didn't dine) there.  Our family timed our trip to Pequod's extremely conservatively arriving at 5:00 knowing we had a 7:10 movie to see. We had already taken advantage of their priority seating service. Upon arriving we were told we could sit immediately, and as we proceeded to the table --- oh no. Just kidding.--- they decided to give our table to another family who needed a high chair, so then we continued to wait. We got seated at 5:10 and ordered two thin crust pizzas immediately due to the 60 minute wait time on pizzas they advertised at the front desk. We put in beverage orders and waited quite a while for them to come to the table, but seeing as how crowded the restaurant was, that didn't bother us.  60 minutes in to our wait time- waitress is no where to be found, table next to us had decided to leave because they had been waiting longer than they deemed appropriate for their food.  70 minutes into our wait time- still no food. Waitress arrives and alerted us it would take 10 more minutes.  We start our stop watch  80 minutes into our wait time- "just a little longer guys." Stressed our waitress.  At 6:55 pm our waitress comes by with to-go boxes, knowing we had a movie to catch, and said we still needed to wait on the pizza. At that point, we paid for our drinks, and in a last minute attempt to eat dinner opted for potbellys sandwiches next door.  We know this wasn't the waitress' fault. She already lost two tables that night and I felt for her.  Dear Pequod's,  Chicago is known for their pizza. I can think of several places that we could have gone and had a delicious pizza. If you want to stay competitive, I would suggest another way of functioning, because making people wait 1:45 minutes for a pizza is absurd. On top of that, we were sat right by the door, and your crowd control needs attention as well. I had the elbows of patrons on my chair as I'm trying to sit and converse with my family. I am extremely disappointed in my experience at your restaurant, and would feel terrible if I recommended this experience to anyone.

Called ahead on a Sunday and was able to get a table for 5 without a long wait; I was happy about that and I recommend calling ahead. Once we sat down we ordered 5 beers and 2 pizzas immediately, knowing that it was going to take awhile. After 2 hours we never got our pizzas and had to leave in order to make it to a movie on time. We left $40 for the beers. It looked like ordering carry out was the way to go.

Maybe I just don't get it. I've had deep dish many times, and not always in Chicago. I've had better. The wait wasn't as bad as everyone said it would be, even for a Saturday night. 10 minutes at most

I love pizza and have been a Chicagoan all my life. Naturally, I was excited to try Pequod's pan pizza after hearing so much about it and reading the reviews. Unfortunately I was greatly disappointed. I had the pan pizza with sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green peppers. The overall flavor was BLAND. I found myself using the salt, pepper, and red pepper shakers more than at other restaurant I've visited.  I agree that the caramelized cheese crust was good, but not worth the trip or the money I spent on the entire pizza. Additionally, the bread was too hard and flavorless. With all the great reviews, I'm left wondering if I missed something. Am I the only one with this experience? I don't understand all the accolades.

As a New Yorker I have a very specific idea of pizza. However, whenever I want deep dish style of "pizza", I go to Chicago to find the best pie. I've had Giordanos and Ginos but I absolutely prefer the way the Pequod's cooks theirs. The crust is dark and caramelized and the whole pie is cooked so well. The sauce is tasty and the base crust is the right crunch. The service is great and the waiters are personable, despite being so busy.

Best pizza in Chicago, hands down.  I wish they would expand or move since the wait time is usually really long and sometimes even pickup takes hours since they are backed up.   There's a gym across the street that you can work out at while you wait... you'll need it since you will want everything on the menu.  Twice.

My take on my recent Wednesday evening experience here is mixed The Good: The option to be able to call ahead and put your name on the list for a table is helpful  A few decent appetizer options to select from (fried zucchini was good) Reasonably priced menu items The restaurant is easy to find, and the surrounding neighborhood has plenty of free street parking  Their infamous pan pizza was a 8/10 for me as far as taste The bad:  Hosts spent too much time talking with each other instead of welcoming customers into the restaurant (not efficient) Waitress was almost non existent. She rarely came by, and when we needed her, she was hard to flag down The personal cutting knife they brought me had paper and pieces of food on it (gross).  So overall I would say the food is good, but the service and cleanliness is questionable.
they sat a party of 3 before us even though we saw that party walk in and request their buzzer... even though we were there 1st... need to keep their buzzers functioning.

If you're deciding on where to get pizza, THIS IS THE PLACE! Ive had everything from the thin crust pizza for an appetizer to party sized three appetizers and their famous pan pizza for dinner. Being a picky person I've never had a complaint. Although I'm out of their delivery area I still pick up all the time. The wait is worth it, after all it takes some time to bake such an amazing pizza, wouldn't expect anything less.
Fernald location is the only one I've been to. Fresh ingredients and crispy crust...I dream of this pizza.

the caramelized crust is awesome, that's the highlight of our experience. it feels like a family style restaurant, a relaxing place to take our friends who are from out of town to, instead of going to the chain pizza restaurants the deep dish has a really thick crust instead of having a lot of cheese, which is not really to our liking...i like Lou Manalti's better because of the mouth watering cheese instead of just all the bread, other than that, the two premium toppings are both excellent, would recommend to try them out

One of my favorites in the city for sit down real pizza in the pan type of place. Love the food, hate the wait. This is beyond good pizza and a rare take on a crust. You need to try it to understand. You should give this at least one try and you will be hooked - pepperoni is the best! Like Gino's East but better! Great service but can be very long wait for a table - call ahead to check on wait time no reservations accepted on some nights. Forget a game night service will lack. Parking is tough, they have a location in Morton Grove which is even a longer wait but easier parking.

Caramelized crust won me over.   sauce is very good and not too much.  for any deep dish pizza noob, please note that deep dish does take longer to make (40-45 mins) so please be prepared for that. another useful tip for deep dish, if you order it to go or delivery, as them NOT to cut it for you. the crust will stay cripsy longer if you dont cut it and cut it yourself at home. during the wait we would just drink and have an app or two.  that should suffice . as for time to go, place gets packed during the weekends so if you go on a weekend.  8-830pm would be ideal.  for weekdays it's should be fine during normal dinner/supper times.
The best Chicago-style pizza I've had yet.. this is where I bring my visitors from out of town!

My Chicago tour included three different pizzerias in hopes of discovering the best: Lou Malnati's, Giordano's, and Pequod's. My favorite by far? Pequod's! Each takes a little while to get from ordering to eating, making calling in ahead when possible a wise decision. But flavor? Ohhhh man. Technically a pan pizza I'm told, Pequod's is just dumped with everything the way I want it. It looks a tad like a dive bar walking in, which probably has to do with the time of its founding. By the way, I kind of also like that there's only one location - it gives it more of an authentic, non-chained feel. Even if the service was, well, a little bit distant. Can't win in everything, and in this situation I didn't particularly care, probably due to the dive bar feel. The best part? The pizza, obvi! The lunch special is somewhere around the $5-6 dollar mark (sorry, I forget), including a soft drink, which I didn't very much care for but gratefully accepted, a lemonade. The bread is thick and delicious, a slightly caramelized crust, and flavorful cheese and toppings hold the rest of it together. I threw on their sausages and mushrooms for an incredible delight. When I move to Chicago, I know this will be my to-go spot for sure.

When I was in Chicago I felt like it was only right that I try a deep dish. I asked around and seriously every single person I asked told me about this place. And I am so glad I took their advice. I came on an early afternoon for lunch and we were seated fairly quickly. But by the time we had left the place was packed and there was a line of people waiting to get in. The location I went to had two levels decent size plenty of space not to crowded.  I went with a their classic deep dish with sausage, peppers, onions, mushrooms and garlic. I do have to say it does take a little bit of time for the pizza to come out, a tad bit longer than I had expected considering the place wasn't that busy when we had place our order. But when it came out it was looking lovely. I can not speak highly enough about this pizza.  It wasn't a typical deep dish I was expecting it was almost a cross between a deep and a new york style. Super crispy crust and not too deep of a pizza. The crust is actually burnt cheese !! which tasted amazing. But yeah I loved how it wasn't that 8 inch deep deep dish I feel anyone not from Chicago would imagine. I was actually able to have more than one slice. The pizza was delicious and everything was cook perfectly. Definitely understand why so many people pointed me in this direction. Probably the best deep dish in Chicago.
Carmelized crusts.  Nuff said. Be prepared to wait. If you get a booth and order some beers, the 45 min wait doesn't seem that bad, and the closeness of the group makes every night a fun outing.
It was good, but not quite what I was expecting for a authentic DD Chicago pizza. Didn't pack as much flavor as I was hoping for.  The crispy and cheesy crust was awesome though.

I am an avid pizza lover and I must admit I was a little disappointed.  The dough to sauce ratio was too high.  I felt like i was eating all cheese and dough.  Maybe its because i ordered take out.  I will give it another try and eat in house.
My 2nd time to Chicago in 2 months and my 2nd time ordering from here.  My friends that live here are now in love with this place... As am I!!
This isn't pizza, sorry Chicagoans. But for the casserole that this is, there's none better. Incredibly flavorful, delicious, perfectly cooked pie with great ingredients.

Really, a forty minute wait to sit down for pizza?  Must be some really good pizza. And the eight of us waited outside, in the cold winter.  Argh.  Everyone insisted on waiting.  Fine.  We are all already there. Lemme tell you something.  This place is a grower, not a shower.  We walked through a lot, to get seated on the top floor, at the very back.  Took us bears and pandas maybe ten or fifteen minutes to get through it all. The waitress?  Got our complicated order just right.  She totally earned that $60 tip.  How was the pizza, you ask?  Some of our group came from New York.  They were inspired to start a business based on the pizza they had here. Idk how feasible it would be to order from here and then deliver it to Manhattan or Brooklyn, and have it piping hot. I'm still in the group that says "Its just pizza, and no, if you think it's better than sex...you're not doing IT right." A suggestion for better business and flow: Give a menu to people waiting outside.  Especially during winter. You can even have them/us order and pay while outside.  We will do it.  Why?  Because we are already hungry.  And you'll have faster table turnover, so you can seat even more people in a night. And it gives us a reason not to leave before we even get to enter.

I ordered through Postmates, and called Peaquods because I had a question regarding my order, the young lady on the phone was so rude and hung up on me. I called my Postmates driver and had him call, he said she was extremely rude to him as well and didn't let him even finish speaking before she hung up. I called and spoke with the manager, she would not give me her name or the young lady who hung up on both of us. I cant understand how a company can be in business when the first point of contact is rude, abrupt and hangs up on customers. I ve never encountered a business that would not reveal the name of who you are currently speaking with. There are too many good pizza shops to encounter that type of service. Would be interested in hearing if others out there have encountered this type of service.

I came alone and was seated promptly at a high two-top table. I'm glad they have a lot of small booths and tables. the iced tea tasted really sweet and definitely not freshly brewed. On the contrary, they do have a rotating Three Floyd's beer on tap, so props for that.  To start, I ordered a half Pequod's salad. I enjoyed it as it had a lot of different ingredients like pepperoni, mushrooms, cheese, and onions. The Italian dressing came in a plastic container, like I was taking it to go. The dressing was good, but not thrilling. At 5:30 on a Friday night, it was already 50 minutes for a personal pizza. I ordered a pizza with sausage and mushrooms and added spinach to half. When it arrived it wasn't cut, so there was no picking this pizza up! The caramelized crust was very good, maybe not as good as Burt's crust was. The sausage was phenomenal, great seasoning, nice sized pieces. The spinach was whole leaves, not a chopped up mix like at Gino's East or Lou Malnati's. I coulde taste it, but was glad it didn't overwhelm the rest of the pizza. Also, the pizza tasted really saucy. I like a lot of sauce, but it was to the point where I could barely taste the cheese. The service was...interesting. I had one server through the time that I placed my order. Then, I never saw her again. Another server took care of me the rest of the way. I had to ask if she was my server now and she said yes. I just expected to get some kind of explanation as to why there was a switch. Also, there isn't much space to walk, especially downstairs. I feel for the servers as they have to navigate through some really tight spaces. It was a good experience and I'd enjoy having the pizza again.
The first time I went, the crust tasted amazing! The second time I went the pizza was ok! I personally think the pizza needs more sauce! This place is open until around 2am and is casual.

When I came to Chicago, I met up with a friend and asked her if we could get some good ole Chicago pizza.  I knew about Giordanno's and Lou Malnati's, but she suggested Pequods, which I never heard of.  Well turns out it was a great choice, and favored by the locals! She said the line might be long, but we got seated pretty quick on a Fri night at 7.  No more than like 20 minutes.  Once we sat down, there were a lot of beers and then the pizza came out.  My god.  It was delicious.  It had that burnt crust taste and all that delicious sauce and fillings.  Next time I get deep dish in Chicago, this will be my first stop.

went with a friend cause he said the pizza was amazing. I thought he might be exaggerating cause he doesn't eat pizza as much as I do but it definitely was as good as he claimed. and it was a late Sunday night and they were still open while many other places in the area were already closed. definitely coming here more often.
The best pizza in Chicago. The crust is mouth watering and pictures do not do it justice. A must eat and will be back soon.

Living in New Hampshire now, there is not much food wise we miss more than great Chicago pizza..   Pequod is a banner example of all that is truly superb about pizza. So glad we had time to stop in and enjoy. We'll be back the next time we come home!!!!
The pizza here is just as good as the place in Morton Grove, which is to say maybe the best Chicago style pizza ever.  Still, I like the original location better.  I'm not sure why.

Hands down, this is the BEST PIZZZA IN CHICAGO. Don't let anyone tell you different. I always bring out of town guests here to have a true pizza experience that can't be found anywhere else. The pizzas are well worth the wait, and the crust is a sure fire winner.

The best. As a south sider, to give that distinction to a north side joint, and for pan pizza is a big deal.  But it's the best in the City of Chicago.  You won't find anything close.  Lou Malnati's has a crust that can be compared, but it surely doesn't top Pequods, not by a long shot.  I literally go out of my way to stop in here, and we try to visit only once in a while to preserve the sense of novelty and make it a treat.

Went recently for lunch.  Bonus--on-street parking which we didn't have to pay for!!  Only a short wait for a table.  We got the large pizza--big mistake for two people!  It was huge, but absolutely delicious!!  We also got house salads before the pizza--they were about average.  The service was terrific, even during lunchtime.  There is always someone waiting on you--it's not like you have to find YOUR server.  You always feel taken care of, even when it's busy.  We agreed we will return!!  Loved it!

Hands down, my favorite deep dish in the city. Their wait time can be a bit annoying, but that caramelized crust is worth the wait! I always try to take out-of-town guests here because it just epitomizes Chicago.
4.5. Loved the sauce and the sausage. Good pepperoni too. A small was enough to be comfortably full. Could have eaten another slice but would have hated myself.

Ordered a small pan pizza and it was delicious. I have to say the place isn't the most consistent in terms of taste. My first experience left me disappointed, but with another go at it I was pleasantly surprised at how good it tasted. I was disappointed with the portion size because me and my lady-friend were still feeling hungry. We were fooled into thinkng the pizza was "good for 1-2 people." Aside from consistency and portion size, the staff were friendly and not intrusive, the prices were fair, and crust was great

Visiting from Dallas, TX.  Everyone says Chicago is known for their deep dish pizza so I have to try some from a local place...& so I have. Got delivery to my hotel, driver said they're not allowed to come to the rooms so I had to go downstairs (I'm calling BS on this one cuz one of the perks of delivery is that you don't have to go anywhere, duh, AND because I delivered pizza in college and that's what we told people when we didn't know our way around a building or were worried about our parking spot...but whatever he was friendly no biggie).  I got a personal pan pizza with Italian sausage and it was very good but constructed in the strangest way--Cheese on bottom, flat and round Italian sausage the diameter of the entire pizza on the second layer, and tomato sauce and Parmesan on top. This seemed a little backward to me, and the huge singular piece of Italian sausage is something I've never seen or heard of, but maybe that's how y'all do it here, IDK.  Garlic cheese bread was super yummy.  Overall great pizza. Wondering if the pizza is really supposed to be prepared upside down though haha.
This is where Chicago locals go for deep dish, best crust in town for sure.
Ordered a deep dish pizza for takeout. It tasted great, but half the crust was missing. Isn't that what you're known for? I'm a little disappointed.

Quite a long waiting time but well worth it when we got inside. 4 of us shared 2 small pizzas and some jalapeño poppers and just that was enough to fill us up and still send ourselves home with left overs. The food was delicious and our server was so friendly and accommodating

Good pizza, love the burnt cheese crust but 90% of the pizza is bread as you will see if some of the customer pictures...it would be perfect if the fixed the ratio to be 50% bread, 25% cheese, and 25% sauce. Overall not bad but my favorite Chicago deep dish remains to be Lou Malnati's. Oh and don't sleep on the chocolate chip cookie. One of the best cookies I've had!

I have been dying to try Pequods, and I finally did.  First of all, I prefer thin crust but everyone said I would love this deep dish.  Yes, it is probably the better of the deep dishes I have had but I was really disappointed in their sauce.  The sauce was super bland and lacked seasoning and spice which kind of ruined the whole pizza for me because it wasn't very flavorful.  I did really enjoy the caramelized crust; it was the best part

I had heard a lot of great things about this pizza. My wife and I decided to try them. We order 3 pizzas from here when we had a family gathering. I have to say, I do not understand what the big deal is. We did not like the deep dish pizza, and the thin crust was good, but not something that would have me coming back! Also, not to be nit picky, but even the boxes had dried on pizza sauce on them when we picked up. I do not think I will be visiting them again. Not horrible but definitely would rather go to other places.
amazing caramelized crust on their deep dish. Should be the new 'Chicago' staple. I now bring out of town guests here instead of the Lou's, because it's just better. it is.

Im not from Chicago, but I travel there often and always make sure to try a new pizza place every time Im in town... Ill go ahead and say it, Pequod's is the best pizza I have ever had.  Pequod's is #1 for me and Lou Malnati's is #2

I've had Chicago pizza from many places and I feel like a pizza snob (Very high standards for pizza) in a way. I am not originally from Chicago (Kentucky originally) but lived there for many years and moved away. My favorite place was Petes on Western near Grace. My girlfriend, who is originally from New Hampshire, has never been to Chicago or had authentic Chicago pizza. Well, we decided to make a 7 hour trip from Kentucky to Chicago just for pizza. Absolutely no regrets at all.  Service was great, food was fresh and hot, and staff was friendly and welcoming. I didn't expect anything else. Needless to say, we are fans of Pequod's and will be coming back. Next visit will be after we move. Such a great place and cannot express how happy we both will be moving back to Chicago. Thanks for a great night, Pequod's.

THE BEST deep dish in Chicago. Skip the chain restaurants and come here. Get there early though and you can wait up to 2.5-3 hours to eat (unlike the chain places, they don't let you preorder your pizza).

im personally giving it a 3 star because I love crust and that's just not the style of their pizza. TOTALLY GREAT PIZZA though, but if you like crust, like me, this probably isn't your jam. my bf LOVED it. and like I said, great pizza! their crust is crunchy and carmalized, so if that sounds good to you, you should go! PLUS its a blackhawks bar!

Pequod's has been my favorite Chicago pizza for quite some time, but tonight's visit was exceptional thanks to our server. Halfway through our meal my mom and I actually both said how much we liked her - she was personable, kind, and cheerful which goes a long way. On top of that, she bought us our dinner for no reason other than to spread some smiles! I will ABSOLUTELY be paying this forward and hope I can brighten someone else's day the way she brightened ours. Thank you, Romi!
I love Pequots so much!  Best Pizza in Chicago hands down.  The crust is so good and the ingredients are so fresh!
Man that burned cheese is good. I gotta get back in there!
Not much else to say other than best deep dish in Chicago! This is where I take friends and family visiting Chicago to get pizza. Can't beat that caramelized crust!

Best deep dish "Chicago style" pizza in the world. Friendly staff, service is good, pizza takes 45min+ to cook, so make sure you have time. Really well priced bc You only need 1 slice, maybe 2 if your a heavy eater. Highly recommend!!

Excellent pizza.  But.. Yes, there's  a but.. When we were there last, My husband saw & killed a cockroach in the men's bathroom. He complained to the manager & we simply stormed out of there. Same day, while waiting for a table... I had to use the restroom (which was messy). And while I was walking towards the restroom, I  took a quick glimpse of the kitchen.  I hate to say, it was pretty messy.  We will go back once they clean up their restaurant. It's my pet peeve. I will NOT eat at a messy restaurant, with a messy kitchen and restrooms.

Get involved, that's about all that I need to say about this place!  I had heard for weeks how great their pizza was.  I was told it was a deep dish sort of a dough, bread, sauce, garlic, seasoning, creation.  Umm, count me in! I went on a Friday night, carry out.  I came home, devoured basically the whole large pizza, felt imeediately ill because I ate too much, and wanted to eat more 7-minutes later.  I loved it! I think in person would be better, but overall I need more of Pequods in my life.

May be good pizza just don't plan on having a party of more than 15 people no room in this tight neighborly joint. The service was slow the food was ok and the count was off! Tried to charge for 23 people when only 19 people in our party! 1 whom was 18 , we never got got asked if everybody arrived in party and count. When we asked them to view camera for count the lady manager said she was calling the cops for interrupting her! My friends came over to buy my son a shot for his birthday and must have got counted in group. When she attempted to show her bill that she paid the manager said enough your ganging up on me! They need organization and proper arrangements for counting! We came all the way from Indiana and ordered platinum package! I even left cake because I was so upset!

Similar to Lou Malanati's in thickness (quite thick) and cheesiness (same amount as a typical thin crust pizza), Pequod's deep dish is one of Chicago's best. The burnt, cheesy ring around the top is absolutely delicious. High quality ingredients. Great classic feeling wood-paneled interior if you eat in, but no issues with delivery. Becoming one of the most popular "non-touristy" deep dish joints in Chicago. And rightfully so. Highly recommend!
Best deep dish pizza in Chicago...nuff said.

First things First.  Pequods is NOT deep dish pizza.  Its PAN style  Says it right on their website...http://pequodspizza.com/chicago/about/   Pequods does a lot of things good.  Their Marinara sauce is unreal, sausage is well seasoned, and the almighty crust cannot be messed with.   The problem for me with Pequods is that I have to eat the part before the crust in order to get to it..supposedly its frowned upon to order pequods, cut out the center of the pie for everyone else and just eat the crust.  I never really understood pan.  Its 75 percent bread and 25 percent cheese/sauce.  I want the exact opposite when eating Deep Dish.   My favorite DEEP DISH is still Giordanos.  Pan is whack
