Overall interesting place but fell short of my Chicago pizza expectations

This pizza is ok.  Miserable delivery.  Our pizza was over a half our late...so it was cold.  And our sausage pizza   was delivered as 1/2 sausage and 1/2 cheese .  Seeing as it was already 1/2 hour late, we did not bother to return it.  So basically we were over charged.
I used to live around the corner and remember the mural! Looking forward to visiting shin when I'm in town! Miss the caramelized cheese on the crust. No one does it like Pequods!

Simply the best. There's just not much else to say about Pequods. Coming from the south side of Chicago, I find it very difficult to get a delicious za basically anywhere north of 87th. But....Pequods is the exception. I've been here many a time and it never disappoints.  Basically stick to pizza and beers here. They don't take reservations really so plan accordingly. It gets crowded if there is a big game on, but trust me it's worth the wait. Personal favs=mushroom+sausage and the pepperoni+pepperoncini. But really, come to think of it, their veggie is killer too!  IN SHORT, ALL ZA HERE IS OUT OF THIS WORLD! If you have not been to Pequods yet, I highly suggest you get there ASAP for good food and good times.
have to say, as a visitor my expectation is too high. We ordered a medium size pan pizza with italian beef , extra cheese, another half with mushroom and onion. Nothing outstanding.....

If you're not into the really saucy stuffed pies like at Giordanos and Pizzeria Uno/Duo, this is a great deep dish pizza! The dough is fluffy and tasty, and the toppings are excellent! The appetizers were normal run of the mill fried bar foods, and the drinks were standard. Overall the atmosphere is solid and the place appears to be able to accommodate decent large groups.

As a first timer to Chicago, I had to try the deep dish pizza since it's one of the must have foods if you are a visitor to Chicago.  Deep dish means your crust will be extra thick.  I had it with mushrooms, you can add as many toppings as you want, at a price, I didn't want to overload my pizza and wanted something simple.  The cheese was good and the crust was very tasty.  You can get something small, it will suffice for two people.  I also had the soup of the day, which was tomato bisque, very flavorful.  The waiter explained everything to us and was helpful. The place is more like a sports bar with good food.
Probably the best deep dish I have had in chicago. I didn't care much for the peaquod salad, but man that pizza was amazing

It seems like this spot used some quality ingredients, as the toppings were delicious. The burnt cheese crust is as great as everyone says it is, but I have some qualms based on my own personal taste. My favorite deep dish will always be Gino's East based on their crust alone. Buttery, dense, never too thick, and slightly sweet from the cornmeal they use. This crust was good, although slightly too thick and fluffy, making it taste like pizza bread rather than pizza. But that's just due to my personal bias, and my bias aside, Pequod's makes a decent pie.

This was probably one of the best deep dish pizza's I have ever had! We called ahead to get priority seating and didn't have to wait long when we arrived. The waitress was upfront and told us it would be about a hour for our pizza. Well worth it though!

I am not a big fan of deep dish, but if you I'm craving it on the rare occasion, I go to Pequod's. It's cheesy, saucy, and the crust is the best I've had for deep dish.  The service was incredibly slow and inattentive once you order, even when it wasn't busy so that takes a star off.  TIP: They have a lunch special on the weekdays that's $5.95 for a personal pizza and a drink. You will be stuffed! I forget the hours unfortunately.

On my visit to Chicago I made it my business to try every single deep dish pizza there is. Pequod's takes the prize. Skip the others - this is the deep dish that you want! My bartender also made my jack and coke pretty strong, so there's another plus.

I'm a pizza lover so my friend suggested his fav spot he raved about the caramelization of the crust which I found out was code for burnt cheese. We walk in and the space can get crowded no different from other popular pizza joints seems like that's standard in Chicago the standing room can get quite crowded....and for an agoraphobe such as myself it took a lot to be there waiting on our table but a spot at the bar gave me some room. So the hostesses (mainly 1 of 3) at the front were kind of not very polite. They kind of stared at us when we walked in and didn't eeh greet us very politely. I did give her the side eye because I was a hostess at Unos and my firsts always were greeted with a welcome and a smile. I actually was going to leave just because of that but decided to stay as we drove all the way here for this pizza. But honestly it really did bug me. Anyhow the wait time is about 50 minutes again standard for Chicago pizza. We ordered the pan pizza with pepperoni sausage and some veggies but it was way too salty. We thought maybe with the meats it was overall yes but my friend assured me that he's had this pizza before and it has never tasted like this. It wasn't bad just too salty for my taste. Anyhow the service at the bar was great and our server was awesome.

So after I wrote my first review, the owner contacted me privately and apologized and asked what he could do to. I responded to that message and he never replied. So it makes me feel like he was being insincere. I definitely will not be returning.

Went in a week night. It's small store front but large on the inside. It wasn't crowded when arrived but it gradually picked up the pace. Overall the pan pizza was good. The service was basic. The lightening was dim. The noise volume was loud. They reserve the booths for parties of 3 or more. This is where they lost a star. Honestly it should be first come first serve.

Good deep dish overall. I was definitely a fan of the caramelized crust and the cheese and toppings were combined perfectly. The vibe was great, it felt like a laid back sports bar and the service was prompt and friendly. One thing I liked was the fact that the deep dish pizza I ordered was a great size for the price where at Lou Malnati's a "large" pizza was expensive and could only feed 2 or 3 people at most. I will come back for sure if I'm in the area

My favorite deep dish in Chicago yet! Pequod's signature crust has crispy cheese spilling over onto the pan, and it's delicious. Lots of topping choices as well. I would recommend getting a small pizza, or multiple small pizzas if you have more people, because the crust is the best part. Salads are also good, and a nice way to spend your time while waiting for the pizza (they're huge). It's more or less a sports bar, but with a very warm, casual atmosphere (and great food, of course). Great service, though of course the deep dish takes a while. There's usually a wait to get in, so plan ahead. You can order your deep dish while you wait if there are no tables, which is definitely a good option--less time waiting for your food once you get a spot. Additional note: I bought a tshirt here and I love it!

I have to say this place was a total disappointment.   We called ahead at about 5 on a Saturday night to see what the wait was.  They told me 45 minutes but that they would put my name down so we were already in line.  When we got there, 20 minutes later, I was told it would be another 45 minutes.   Stupidly, we agreed to wait the extra 20 minutes.   When we were finally seated, our server told us the wait would be an hour for pizza.   So we put our order in immediately since now they kind of had us stuck at 630  on a Saturday night.  After waiting an hour and a half, my party agreed we would just leave.  Since we hadn't seen our server in half an hour, we walked down to the hostess station.  They managed to catch my dad and tried to charge him for a pizza we didn't  even get.  I spoke with the manager after this since they were essentially trying to trick my dad into paying for something we didn't even receive.  After speaking with him and explaining our disappointing evening, he tried to make it right.   He told us he would get us a pizza right away.  I asked why it took us trying to leave to get our pizza.  He tried to make it right by comping our appetizer and  drinks and sent us home with a pizza.  That is the only reason I gave 2 stars.  The pizza was not very good and the service was awful.   The manager tried to make it up to us, but that was after our evening was already ruined.  Would never go back.
WOW!  The caramelized crust on their deep dish is unbeatable!  Great microbrew selection.

Great Chicago deep dish. It's fun atmosphere, your typical Chicago pizza joint. Lots of wood, stuff about sports, booths, etc. The waitstaff is incredibly nice. My friend lost her phone into the abyss of a crack in between the wall and a booth and they were very nice to fish it out for her. We ordered mozzarella sticks and a salad (in our poor attempt to have something healthy), which were good. We also did a couple slices of the thin crust (because none of us had ever tried it before). We ordered 2 deep dishes, and since there was 6 of us, we had plenty to take home. The sausage is incredible on the pizza and all the veggies are fresh and crisp, even after being in the oven. It's a must if you are visiting the city.

You can't beat their deep dish. My favorite deep dish pizza for sure. When my manfriend lived in Chicago, I would beg to go to this place!  It's always packed, so you order your pizza, and then when it's ready, they seat you. It's somewhat chaotic sometimes, but grab a beer and relax! :-) Even though you don't get seated till the pizza is done, it's always piping hot!

Decent.  Deep dish just doesn't seem to do it for me like thin crust does.  Way too much dough.  Was hoping there'd be a little less. I ordered the personal pizza with sausage and meatballs.  I did like how the cheese was burned into the crust.  The wait was a little longer than I would have liked...Someone came in after us, was seated after us, ordered a larger pizza, and got his first.  Overall decent but nothing blew me away.

Tiny spot crammed with patrons.  They take reservations but will not let you order pizza ahead... no way!... and make you wait one hour at your table for your pizza.  We ordered a deep dish which was more like bit of dark sauce, covered by a dash of cheese over a thick, floury, dense, taste-like-nothing dough...  Their thin crust may be better, if they put more cheese on it... will not be going back.  Loud environment.  The waiters and the owner were very friendly but the pizza--- we did not like.

This review is tough to write because, from a taste standpoint, Pequod's HAD been a pizza that I'd enjoyed twice in past experiences after trying it for the first time a year or so ago. After my most recent experience, however, I will not be returning as a customer - unless there happens to be a change in management. On a Saturday evening (4:45pm), I phoned in an order of two pizzas (one thin crust and one deep dish) for our family. I was informed my wait would be approximately 50-60 minutes. I showed up at the restaurant at 5:40pm after 55 minutes and was informed that my pizzas still needed about 10-15 minutes. On a busy Saturday night, I thought this was reasonable and appreciated them letting me know (vs. just saying it would be "a couple more minutes"). After 20 additional minutes had passed, I asked about the status of my order and was told the takeout server would be back shortly. When she returned, I was told that they just put one of my pizzas IN the oven - 80 minutes after I placed the order. After waiting another 10 minutes, the manager came out with both pizzas. Upon expressing my frustration for their clear delay in placing part of the order, and the fact that the first pizza of mine had been sitting there for 20+ minutes, he offered me $15 off a future order, and said my delay was "typical" for them. Given the experience to that point, I should have checked the pizzas on the spot, but upon returning home and opening the box, the pan pizza that had been sitting for 30+ minutes (by that time) had completely collapsed in the box, leaving a smeared mess of toppings and sauce and a thoroughly soggy box. The thin crust pizza that had been forgotten was burned considerably on the crust (past the normal "carmelization" of Pequod's crusts).  I really was looking for a simple mea culpa from the manager. Everyone makes mistakes; but he continually expressed that my experience (even the pizza waiting on top of the oven for 20+ minutes) was typical for them and offered no recourse on my current order. If this is the "typical" Pequod's experience, count me out. I can think of 4-5 other spots (Art of Pizza, Lou Malnati's, Jet's, Bricks) on the north side of the city that serve a more consistent pizza and, most importantly, take accountability if they happen to make a mistake.
Worst delivered pizza I've ever seen and eaten. It was a disgusting explosion of pizza in a box. See pics

When a friend of mine mentioned Pequod's as her favorite deep dish in Chicago, my curiosity was definitely piqued. I'm here all night, folks. Eating at Pequod's is a great experience.  The place is just an unassuming bar with a good amount of TVs to just hang out and wait for a delicious pizza to be brought to your table, served right in the pan, no less. Not gonna lie, I miss early 90's Pizza Hut so bad. The service is attentive; two of us at the table were having coffee for lunch (it was a long night) and they kept the pot filled for basically just the two of us.   So onto the pizza.  We got a sausage/mushroom/spinach pizza and a meatball/peppers pizza.  You got big hunky pieces of topping with a yummy sauce and a nice crisp crust to go with it.  Our two pies varied pretty greatly in crust thickness, but either way, both were great.   The biggest negative, however, is that they fall into the trap of soggy veges.  If you have too many veges in your pie, it's just leaving a ton of moisture on there leaving everything a slippery mess and even worse when reheating it.  There are definitely a couple different things they could do to avoid this, like chopping them into smaller pieces, ensuring that they're on the top to let moisture escape, using a salad spinner after chopping, etc. We had some leftovers and because of said sogginess a lot of that cheese just oozed off, which is unfortunate.  Also, the crust got pretty saturated too, so even with a pizza stone, the dough was still pretty soggy. So yeah, for now I would say avoid having too many veges on your pie and avoid taking it home.  It's just not a very good experience. However, despite all of that, I might like this better than the big three...

The first thing I think of when someone says Chicago is PIZZA! My all time favorite food :)   So when my friends recommend pizza places I get excited to try them all. Pequods was 1st on my list. My favorite ingredient in a pizza is the sauce. The Saudi is what makes or breaks the pizza. & Pequods hit the spot. The pizza was absolutely delicious.  I would have given the pizzeria 5 stars but the staff needs to be friendlier.

Came here with my cousins, brother and sis-in-law on a chilly Saturday night.  After about 90 minutes and a cocktail at The Drinkingbird next door, we were seated at a rather tight table for our group of 6 -- but we made it work.  We started with an order of Pequods Salad and Cheesy Garlic Bread to shared.  Then, shared a large veggie pan pizza and a large meat pan pizza and washed them down with some pitchers of Blue Moon.   Everything was delicious and our waitress was extremely sweet and patient.  Atmosphere was loud and fun -- overall great night for some Chicago pie.

Maybe my review wanes due to my lack of deep-dish love, but I'm a pizza person through and through, so, really.... it's just a personal observation that this 'za doesn't stack up. (Punny.) I mean, it was okay. The crust was significant, the sauce aplenty (and/or too much), the cheese portioned just right and toppings so-so. But. I don't know. I didn't leave thinking, "HolymotherofpizzaGOD that was awesome! I gotta go back! NOW." In fact, I don't know if I'd ever go back... if I'm looking for stuffed or deep dish, which I never really am, I'd go elsewhere...  Plus, the service was that of a Little Cesars. In fact, Little Cesars is probably more attentive and nice than our lackluster server.  Meh, A-okay, whatever. Go and judge for yourself.

This is just an update on the take-and-bake option. I recently had a negative experience with a very dry crust. Not sure if this was a one-off (hope it was) but given my glowing review I don't want to steer anyone in the wrong direction with the take-and-bake option. Dine in if at all possible.

One of the top places to get Chicago-style pizza in Chicago.  For me the only hard question is whether Pequods is merely "one of the top," or is "the best."  The ring of carmelized cheese and the crunch crust are both trademarks and in my view they are both excellent touches.  My only complaint is that the bottom crust is sufficiently thick that there's a slightly higher ratio of bread to toppings on this pie than there is in some of Pequod's competitors.  For some people this last factor is not a complaint at all, and in any event Pequod's is in the very top tier.

Oh yeah, if you like pizza and love deep dish  pizza, then this is your spot.  Old hang out environment, they have seats downstairs with a bar and seats upstairs with a bar.  The crust is very tasty and is brushed with butter that then caramelizes when baked.  The only complaint I have is that the bottom crust was somewhat uneven in texture.  Do not know if this was usual or just a little extra crust folded over and a little bit more chewy than the other parts of the pizza.  Either way it is wonderful and 5 stars.  Dark upstairs, with posters, a bit better lighting and a very large bar.  Wonderful environment for watching sports or just a small party with friends.
The pan pizza exceeds all requirements to be called and considered a "Chicago" pizza. Excellent food excellent service.
Hands down best deep dish in Chicago. Gets pretty crowded but the staff is super efficient!

I wish I could have negative stars. So disappointed that my friends visiting Chicago had to suffer the disappointment of this place.  In short, service and food were so terrible.  The two pizzas took an hour and a half to get onto our table.  Appetizers took were spaced thirty minutes between each other. If we got her attention, the waitress forgot waters, drinks and extra place settings multiple times. She was nice but just not attentive.. In the span of an hour, they messed up my salad three times? All I asked for was no dairy/gluten and even offered to just take it off myself. They insisted and came back all diff variations of cheese and crouton mixes.. In the end, we cancelled it because people were done eating. Management seemed so exasperated and talked about how they messed up our table right next to us? Above all, the pizza was terrible and bland. As hungry as we were, just couldn't stomach that crust they're famous for. It was foamy and bland. Little chunks of caramelized flavor but not enough to offset the rest. We waited to talk with management, but they were so busy and not to be seen. Currently at protein bar cuz im so hungry.

Placed an order for delivery at 5pm was told the order would be delivered within 90 minutes.  Then within 90 minutes the delivery driver called he was at another address and seem inconvenienced when I provided the correct address.  I Called in was placed on hold fo 15 to 20 and basically was told by a Manager "what would you like me to do". IT WAS A WASTE OF MY TIME TO CALL AND SPEAK TO A MANAGER. After 10 minutes I received another call asking how I would like my order handled.  I was hoping that delivering immediately since it was their mistake would be the course of action.  My food arrived at 745.  I ordered at 5pm to ensure my out of town visitors would be able to eat prior to enjoying a show.  Thankfully I made a salad myself so they only ate that for dinner and now i have a large gross soggy disgusting pizza and stayed behind to wait for the delivery since i was unable to get through and just cancel the order.  NEVER ORDER FROM HERE.  I NEVER WILL. HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE. I don't blame the driver but a Manager should be able resolve the problems and coordinate logistics to ensure proper service.  You lost a customer and since we typically dine in I will now ensure to recommend any other place for dine in or delivery.  THANK YOU TO THE DRIVER WHO WAS POLITE AND APOLOGETIC. I MADE SURE TO TIP HIM AFTER PAYING FULL PRICE FOR THE WORST DELIVERY EXPERIENCE SINCE IT WAS NOT HIS FAULT AND  THE MANAGER DIDN'T CARE ABOUT ME OR MY ORDER I WILL TAKE MY BUSINESS ANYWHERE ELSE.

Holy iron skillet of Chicago-style ecstasy. My part-time Chicagoan amigo  brought me to Peqoud's, guaranteeing the best Chicago style pizza you could find in The Windy City, and boy did Pequod's deliver. I was advised to only eat two slices, as any more would be a fool's venture. Well, I was full after once slice of mile-thick pepperoni and mushroom 'za, had to keep up with the crowd and have a second slice, and then was still so impressed with the quality that I had to have a third. The third was the end of me. I went into straight coma/hibernation/cheese-overdose/cryo sleep after that. But wow, it was worth it.

I still can't figure out how to pronounce the name of the this place properly!! Even though about a dozen Chicagoans said it during my trip, I swear each one said it just a little different. I wish Yelp had 1/2 stars, as I think Pequod's deserves 3.5.  I'm rounding down and not up, because the other Chicago-style pizza place I tried during my Chicago foodie crawl (Lou Malnati's) was a solid 4 stars, and I think edged out Pequod's. After arriving into Chicago from Seattle at around 8pm on a Thursday night in mid-Sept, my foodie crawl weekend was just a subway ride and hotel refresh away!  My friend had already checked into our hotel earlier in the day and in short order, I was ready to get the party started too!  We had carefully crafted our itinerary knowing that we needed to hit up the late night places on Thursday night due to my late arrival.  After some small plates at Avec, our next stop was Pequod's and its late night hours (It was about 12:30am by the time we arrived).   Due to our jam-packed weekend of eatin', my friend and I shared a personal deep-dish pepperoni pizza only.  With a glass of red wine each.  The pizza took a while to come out (each one is made to order), but we were in no hurry-- after all, we were on vacation!!  It gave me some time to look around the small restaurant, (dive-bar chic was the ambiance) which totally reminded me of my college days. Once the pizza actually came out, it appeared to have a burnt crust.  We called over the waitress, who explained to us that it was the specialty of the house-- to put a layer of cheese along the outside of the crust, which burnt and caramelizes as it bakes.  Apparently some people would revolt if they stopped this practice!  For my friend and I, it was just a tad TOO burnt, so maybe we got one that didn't pass quality control... but I would say I wasn't a huge fan though the rest of the pizza was delicious.  For this reason L.M. was my favorite pizza place, though I can totally understand a late-night post-bar hankering for Pequod's-- in fact, in my early-to-mid 20s,  I could have seen myself being a fixture here!

I have no idea why I haven't been here before! This place is great! The deep dish pizza was amazing. They did mess up on my order but they gave me a free small pizza. How great is that? I definitely recommend coming here if you haven't already. The staff was also very nice. I had a overall great experience. =]]

I went here because I've heard nothing but good things, but was extremely disappointed. We ordered delivery, which took 2 hours, I was fine with that even though it seemed excessive to wait that long. It looked like it would taste amazing, but it wasn't flavorful at all. Maybe it was an off night, but I'll never know because I will definitely not be going back to Pequod's.
Really good. I rate the thin tops. I prefer Malnati's barely. This deep is really good and not as touristy. Be prepared for a wait for the pie.

Excellent, excellent pizza. The sausage is to die for. The restaurant is busy and it will take some time for your food. Luckily, they have Goose Island Green Line on tap to help you pass the time. The pizza is very filling, I'd suggest not filling up on Appetizers before hand. They will happily box up leftovers, and proper Chicago pizza  should always be reheated in an oven, not the microwave!  Highly recommended, just try to avoid the busiest times.

Absolutely unforgettable and delicious. I cannot believe I've lived in Chicago for 8 and 1/2 years and never tried It !   The atmosphere is cozy and darker, which is what I prefer. The staff is extremely friendly and PROUD of where they work. Our server was very excited that we were trying the pizza for the first time. We were starving so we also sampled almost every appetizer (mostly the fried stuff!). Lots of tasty dipping sauces :) Everything came out in a timely fashion and our drinks were never empty. It was busy because it was the same weekend as Riot Fest but I don't think we had to wait longer than 20 minutes for our table. We were able to find a spot at the bar and enjoy some strong drinks while we waited. Hands down, it's the best deep dish pizza I've ever had in Chicago.  I like it because the crust is light and fluffy instead of resembling pie crust. I can actually eat more than once piece at Pequods! If you have guests from out of town who want to try deep dish, skip all of the downtown places and go to Pequod's .

Fantastic pie! Had the deep dish with shrooms, green peppers, onions and meatball. It was awesome! I especially loved how the toppings are a top the sauce like a traditional thin is. Makes you really appreciate the toppings more than if they were in the middle with the cheese. and the caramelized crust is delish. It's like they put a thin rim of cheese around the cruse and burn it to a golden brown. Ambiance is nice and divey, server was cute and attentive and the bill wasn't too bad though a little pricey. (Dinner for 3 with 2 drinks each, tax and tip $83.) I'd definitely go back. Haven't had Uno's yet but overall this is the best pizza so far.

I knew before coming here that this pizzeria would steal away my heart. Once I saw all the photos of the burnt cheese edges, I knew this was the place for me. And the moment I bit into my slice of pizza, I was proven correct! I've only been to two other pizza places in Chicago but I'm going to take a leap of faith and say that this is the BEST pizza in Chicago. There is no way it can get better than Pequod's.

I just moved back to Chicago. I've been to Pequod's three times this month, and it needs to stop. The pizza is amazing. My favorite is the ground beef topping. Lunch special is a 7 inch pizza and a drink for $5...can't beat that. But, can't we have a beer instead of pop?

My boyfriend and I made a pact: Go to Pequod's.  Eat pizza.  Get massive food coma.  Feel regret.  Mission accomplished.    Being a native of SoCal and traveling to Chicago with my main squeeze, Chicago pan pizza was all we had in our minds.  Where do I begin?  I immediately liked the dive-y vibe once I stepped through door.   We started off with their popular cheesy garlic bread, which was pretty flipping awesome.  I was surprised how well the bred held up with the cheese; the bread was still crunchy and paired oh-so-well with the melty, chewy cheesy.  It was a textural play in my mouth. Get it! The piece de resistance:  We ordered a LARGE (we were feeling adventurous) pan pizza with pepperoni and basil.   Dark.  Divey ambience. Friendly servers.   Expect a 40-50 min wait for pizza to cook.  Prepare yourself for carb heaven.
oh wow, this pizza is awesome. so delish. cant want to go back. The crust is the bomb and the sauce and ingredients they use are so fresh. go give it a shot, you wont regret it.

The pizza is insane good! I had the pizza and added onions,  mushrooms basil and jalapeño.  Was a interesting mix but actually worked nicely! We also had the jalapeño poppers and those were also great!  The place was a recommendation from our can driver and it was a great suggestion!  Here's a tip if you are traveling: talk to your cab drivers as a lot of them may have some great insights! After chatting with ours,  he used to be a sous chef at Michelin star restaurant and had some great suggestions for us when it came to food.  We weren't disappointed with any of his suggestions!

Got a pan pizza with sausage, mushrooms, and onions (salivating yet?). The personal size was generous and hefty, pretty delicious. Had the deep-fried mushrooms while waiting, which were just okay--probably didn't need them, in hindsight. Great service. Oh, and Pequod's is better than Malnati's. Just sayin'.

Really? Again? We tried it once. We really tried. Mostly bread, burnt(not caramelized) crust. It was a Saturday night, so we gave them a pass and tried again on a weeknight. NOPE. Still black, not brown cheese.

Really three and a half stars. Pizza was good, as Chicago deep-dish goes. Service was just OK, and the appetizers were pretty standard. Ambiance was dark, kind of like a sports bar. Would be a good place to come watch a game, but not necessarily something to go out of your way for.

We went this evening. First time there and the pie was outstanding. Did not disappoint. We had both pan and thin crush and both were excellent.  Among the best I've ever had. So why only 2 stars? The service sucked! And to be specific, out server SUCKED! Don't know her name, only know her as server MZ07. Here are the lowlights. 1) Bitch slapped us for wanting new silverware after our salads. Said they were too busy to roll silverware into napkins and that we should have kept what we had. Really? My gal joked that she would gladly go role her own, and without hesitation or a smile was told that was "not an option". As though we were serious. 2) We waited 80 minutes for our pizza's while other larger tables that came in after us got theirs ahead of us. No apology, no sorry for the delay, nothing. 3) Asked for more water and got attitude when we thought she didn't hear us. 4) Not once did she ask us how our meal was. Not once! I know she was busy, but come on. It's called very basic customer service. 5) My favorite. When I asked for the check and got no acknowledgment, I asked again. All I got was a very stern "I heard you"! One of the least pleasant servers we've ever had. I fully understand that the place was packed and that it's a very challenging job to say the least. That said, as long as you're at it you might as well try to be good at it. Try being just a little pleasant. She might want to consider another line of work. Just sayin'
Best pizza I have had in Chicago. Apparently fly more people from out of town come out to check this place out. Go with with basil and giardinera deep dish pizz.

I called ahead at lunch yesterday for a large pan pizza, and it was nicely packaged and piping hot 40 minutes later.  Staff was friendly.  Parking easy at lunch.  The pizza was quite good.  Not the best ever but flavorful (nice sauce and sausage).  Decent pizza.

Best pizza in Chicago, hands down, especially if you eat at Pequods (so it's hot off the oven). I'm a big fan of the pepperoni deep dish and the thin crust is great too! The lunchtime deal (personal pizza and beer) is a great special even though it's difficult to make it out there during the week. Best advice - make a reservation through the website. It doesn't guarantee that you will get a table exactly at your appointment but at least you will be at the top of the list. Also call your order in ahead of time (deep dish takes an hour to cook).

This review is on pizzas that we ordered for delivery.  I've never had pequod's, but have heard great things about it.  When I ordered around 11:45, I was quoted 1 hour and 20 min. Totally understandable for a Sunday afternoon.  When I called after 1 hour 45 min,  making sure the address was correct, they said the delivery guy was close and it should be there within a few minutes. I called again after 2 and a half hours, and they called the delivery guy again. He was finally at our street, almost a full hour after the quoted time.  Pizza was okay, but not very hot anymore. The deep dish was not as saucy as I would have liked. Thin was better, in my opinion. Maybe it tastes better to eat the pizza in the restaurant, but would not order again for delivery.

Amazing deep dish pizza. If you're looking for authentic deep dish Chicago style pizza this is the place. After trying a few different pizzerias to find that authentic deep dish I have concluded this is the place. New favorite spot for pizzas when in town... Must try!

Ugh, Pequod's. I struggled between giving this place 3 or 4 stars. I'll go with 3.5 stars. I think it's because about a million people raved to me about Pequod's and after pumping myself up and waiting about 2 hours for the pizza, I was left sorely disappointed. Don't get me wrong, it's definitely GOOD pizza. But overrated. I definitely recommend calling ahead and making a "reservation" especially on weekend nights. It's not a real reservation but just a shorter wait time once you get to the restaurant. Regardless we waited about an hour on a Friday night, which was fine and expected. The restaurant itself is rather dingy and way too dark. I came with a group of four girls and we were going to probably eat each other before the pizza came out so we ordered the cheesy garlic bread. It was not very good. The bread wasn't toasted nearly enough. :( It made me sad. We ordered one medium and one large pan pizza because we had the hangers and ended up taking most of the large pizza home (not surprisingly). The sauce and toppings were really good, especially the sausage (huge chunks) and pepperoni. But it couldn't make up for the fact that it was just overwhelmingly plain-tasting crust and not enough sauce/toppings. The burned cheese crust was definitely the best part. And how cheap it was! We ended up paying $10 a head for all that food. Their lunch deal sounds awesome -$5 for a drink and personal pan. I think I'd go back, just never on the weekend.

Amazing, amazing, amazing. I love Chicago deep-dish pizza and I wish LA really had some awesome places to eat it at but we don't sadly. My cousins introduced me to deep dish pizza back when I first visited Illinois in 2006 and ever since then I've always wanted it in LA. This place makes just perfect pizza. Nothing else needs to be said. We sat on the second floor and had great service. I really wish they could send me some pizza right about now cause I'm really craving it. Anyways, ambiance was cool and the only thing I didn't like was the crummy Blackhawks sign when you come down the stairwell (Go Kings)..but I am in their territory so I can't be mad! Also, the painted wizard in the upstairs bathroom just adds more character to the place. I found that extremely cool too! Will be back when I'm in Chicago again.

Best. Pizza. In. Chicago! The sausage and deep dish is a must. I used to think Lou Malnati's was king, but every reign has its end.  Side note: Giordanos is not even top 5 compared to Pequods deep dish. The sauce and carmelized crust at Pequods is beyond this galaxy.  *** lunch special which consists of a personal deep dish and soft drink is only $5! Unreal  GO!
Great weekday deal. The wait is long, but well worth it.

By far the best deep dish in the city! Their malt crust is to die for, and their sauce is flavorful. Some deep dish places skimp on the sauce because they cram so much into 1 slice, but every element is top notch. It's even great as carry out!
Meeh. The pizza is good but not the best. If you're from NY, then this is your spot. Real Chicagoans have multiple places where the pizza is a lot better than this burnt one!

As far as pan pizza goes, I would say Pequods definitely has a leg up on Burt's but it doesn't stand up overly well to the deep dish spots (Ginos, Lou's, Uno) as they just don't put enough cheese or sausage on the pie. The amount of crust can really overwhelm the flavor of anything else-- and even with the caramelized cheese on top, the crust tends to lack flavor.  The biggest plus about Pequods is the generous amount of sauce they put on the pie. Chunky tomatoes with garlic and a hint of oregano, their sauce adds a lot of flavor to the pizza. If they just put some more cheese and toppings, I'd say they warrant four stars.  For price, these guys do it right. For $5 you can get a personal pan pizza at lunch. The personal pan is only $8 at dinner also-- so very reasonable.

I'm not from Chicago, but the city is known for deep dish.  So, even though Pequod's offers thin crust, I did not try it.  When in Rome??  But, I have been to 4 or 5 different pizza places in Chicago and hands down Pequods is the best deep dish.  They start by lining the edges of a cast iron pan with mozerella cheese. This creates a stupid good carmalized crust on the pizza.  The flavors are incredible.  We added italian sausage and it was the best sausage I've ever had on a pizza.  Quality sausage.  The place is packed, especially on weekend evenings, but if you have the time to wait, it is well worth it.  They also have a fantastically cheap lunch special for $4.95.  Includes a 7" deep dish with one topping plus a beer or soda.  Can't beat that with a stick.

We ate here for dinner last night (Sunday). We came early, around 4, after going to museums all day. There were plenty of tables and we were seated right away. Our waitress was very attentive. We ordered a small deep dish pizza with half mushrooms and half sausage and peppers. I had never had deep dish pizza, and usually I prefer thin crust. However, this pizza was very good and better than I had expected! There was a nice crunch to the bottom of the crust that I really liked. I would come here again if I was in the area.

5 star pizza, 1 star service. The pizza is absolutely awesome, that said the service here is down right despicable. Everyone from the hostess to the bartenders, to the servers are just rude and exhibit very little interest in the people that are spending their hard earned money to eat at this establishment. I really hope that they can get it together on the service side of things because the pizza is that good. I would recommend that if you are going to get pizza here order takeout, so you don't have to deal with the people keeping this place running.

Pequod's gets my vote for best Chicago deep dish. The cheese-to-sauce ratio is the golden ratio of pizza, and Pequod's is perfect. While some local deep dish places tend to go lighter on the sauce, Pequod's layers it on (but not excessively). Their sauce is full of seasonings and rich tomato flavor. As important is the crispy burnt cheese crust. Deep dish pizza tends to get a bit soggy, so the cheese crisped around the edges adds a nice crunch. And who doesn't love nearly-burnt cheese on their pizza? The individual (7") size is enough to satisfy two moderate appetites, but if you're hungry, you can probably polish off one solo. And with inexpensive delivery and no delivery minimum, Pequod's makes it easy to do so.

This place is my definitive favorite deep dish pizza in the Chicago area. The caramelized cheese crust around the perimeter makes it. There are not as many locations as a Gino's, Girodanos, etc but the taste and quality are (in my opinion) superior to both.

Let me just say, I love Chicago pizza.  Came here from out of town and this place was highly recommended, so I had to try it. It was definitely good. The crust was the best part of the pizza. It takes about an hour to make, so be prepared. Unfortunately, we came around 6:30 on a Saturday and the wait to be seated was 2 hours!! Wtf. Was it worth waiting a total of 3 hours to finally have a slice? No. But, it was one of those things where we were from out of town, it was highly recommended and we wanted to try some real Chicago pizza. If you go, plan for a wait or don't go hungry!
Not as good as I expected it to be. I've heard people rave about this place but I believe it was too pricey for the quality I ordered pepperoni and sausage thin crust and it was just okay.

Have always been a fan of their thin crust, and they may possibly have the best pepperoni In Chicago. Went in recently there to dine in and try their Deep Dish. I'd give their deep dish a nod above most but still partial to Lou's. Fresh toppings were solid. The garden salad was great as well.

Pizza was good but nothing to go out the way for.  If you never had chicago pizza you will love it but I eat it all time around city and suburbs.  I'm south sider who took the trip north to try it and it was average and not worth trip l.  Dining room is smAll and tables are not comfortable.

Service is whatever, but this deep dish is my new fave. So goooooooooood. I like lots of sauce that is tangy and slightly sweet and this fits the bill. I liked the crispy sort-of burnt cheese on the outside of the crust, just...so satisfying. P.S. Born and raised Chicagoan. Lou's is garbage. Thhhbt.

Friends, DO NOT GO ON A WEEKEND.  We waited a relatively short period for a table, about twenty minutes, which was suprising since the wait can be much longer.  Now don't get me wrong, we love the pizza here, but once the server came by and asked for our order, we were told the wait was going to be an HOUR AND A HALF for any pie and if you wanted deep dish it would be much longer.  When we asked why she said it was the volume of delivery and in-house orders.  So either get your fix on a week day or order delivery before you get hungry.
Good lord is this pizza good. The crust is the definition of perfection. Could eat this for days.

Rather than cast another vote into the "which deep dish is better?" debate, I'll focus here on our experience at Pequod's, which wasn't remotely good. We went early on a Sunday evening--two hours after the Bears game had ended, so that's not even a valid excuse--and ordered two personal pizzas, two beers. That's it--not an especially complicated order. The place was lively, not what I'd call busy, and yet 75 MINUTES LATER our food still hadn't arrived and our inattentive server hadn't bothered to check in with us even a single time. I understand that deep dish takes a while longer to cook than thin crust, but seriously, there is no earthly reason for a pair of 7" pizzas to require that much time. I appreciated the charred cheese and the savory sauce on the pizza that finally arrived, but it hardly made up for the wait or the poor service.

I'm from NYC and I had my fair share of pizza. This is my first time having deep dish pizza. We added pepperoni and mushrooms as toppings, which made the pizza more delicious. The pizza is good, but I definitely prefer thin crust than the thick crust. I recommend trying this place out if you're ever going to Chicago.

I've had giordano's, Lou malnatis, and Gino's east. Nothing is as good as Pequods. Very happily surprised!!!! The other three rely on tourists to keep themselves afloat.... Pequods is just good on it's own. The only place I'll be going for deep dish from now on
I forgot to update this! I went back about a year later and the food was amazingly good. That one dry pie we got must have been an anomaly. So good!

I had to sign up just for this one! After waiting 2 hours for a half peperoni pan pizza, I open it up and it is cooked crisply. The bottom was half black and the peperoni crumbled to little pieces when you touched it (photos below). So once I got a hold of someone, the girl said it is supposed to be black around the edges. I said yeah, well its much more than that! To her credit she said she could give me a credit for next time or get a manger. I asked for a manger because I wanted half my money back, because I know they tried and I thought that would be fair. Well I sat on the phone with the manager, who did not believe me and said just like the girl, it is supposed to be black around the edges and some black spots on the bottom. I'm in Chicago, I think I have a good idea of what a pan pizza is supposed to look like! So, after ten minutes, oh and sending the manager a picture because he did not believe me, he finally said yeah it's over cooked! He continued to say we can send another, I said that's ok, I'm not ordering here again! Pequod's was recommended to me by a friend, not sure if we will be friends after I tried this burnt pizza! I don't know what's worse, that the manager didn't believe me or that they even let this pizza leave the store and get to my house!  I have had a pizza that wasn't right from other pizzeria's and they didn't question it, they took care of it immediately.  Going to keep with the other great pizza joints in Chicago like, LOU MALNATI'S, PIZZANO'S, AND PIECE PIZZA. this pizza went in the garbage, just like the managers customer service!  I hope you can keep them on the phone long enough to send them a picture of your burnt pizza!

This is the best Pizza in Chicago. lou malnati's and uno's pizza has nothing on this pizza. I like thin crust pizza, not into eating a bunch of dough with my pizza with deep dish. But I did try a few bites of the deep and it is by far the best. The thin is even better.  This place is always packed and forget getting a table if you get here late. The best time to come is between 4-6p. Make it another night if you get there any later.

Made a reservation for a large group for lunch on Sunday afternoon. Great service. Were seated immediately. The "half" pastas are really small. So order accordingly. Pizzas took about 50 minutes which was as expected. However, even though it took a while, was worth the wait!

First off, either make a reservation or get here before 6. They fill up real fast. Secondly, GET THE PIZZA! Thirdly, make sure you try it with meatballs. Holy crap, were they great! Having been to Giordanos, UNOs, the best part about Pequods is that there is only one location.

Pizza burnt, not caramelized, took over an hour to get a small deep dish which was black on the bottom and had barely any sauce on it.  Pretty terrible service considering beers cost $6, waitress was awful.

Not at all OMG this is NOT better that Lou Malnati's Pizza at all.   This is like Giordano's or Aurelio's Pizza.   To doughy and was like Ketchup on a cracker with cheese.  Not at all what I expected. Any true Chicagoan knows LOU Malnati's Rock as NUMBER ONE PIZZA. This was very disappointing since a lot of people I know love this place but then again none of them are Chicagoans!

I told my friends I wanted a deep dish pizza when I went to visit them in Chicago and this is where they took me. The first attempt was a Friday night around 9:30, BAD IDEA this place had a line out the door. We stopped by for a late lunch the next day and we had a sort wait to be seated. The pizza is really good and so is the service.

Not great, but not horrible either. Definitely a place where everybody & their brother hangs out. We tried slices of thin, one with mushroom, one pepperoni. These slices were absolutely huge & they don't skimp on the toppings either. It was good, but it lacked flavor for me. There was just so much cheese, there wasn't much of a chance for the dough, sauce & toppings to get through.

The best I have had in chicago. Totally worth the trip and I love that its quite local. The location is a little bit remote, but I don't mind that at all. By far my favorite pizza place in chicago and try to make it there for their awesome lunch special.
The pizza was great. My favorite in Chicago so far! Service was pretty fast, but we were there around 3pm on a Wednesday. I'll definitely be going back. Thanks Peaquod's!
That crust is the stuff of legends, and for good reason.  And delivery until 2AM doesn't hurt either.* *except for my waistline, but it's so worth it

They have thin and thick crust and a range of apps, so there's something for everyone (who's not a vegan or health nut, I'd say). The thick crust was good, probably as good as any I've had. It took a good while to come. The restaurant feels like a local place. It's a bit dark inside. The staff is friendly, although not super attentive.

I'm definitely a fan of this place.  I was originally taken aback when we thought we made a reservation by emailing the restaurant, only to find out upon arrival at the restaurant that the email request was just "taken into consideration."  Some people waited upwards of TWO WHOLE HOURS to be seated.  It's another 40 minutes for your pizza to come out!  Because we had emailed Pequod's and requested an 8 pm seating, we only had to wait an hour.  We were basically bumped up to the "high priority" list of parties to be seated.   Once seated, we didn't know who our server was.  We were at our table for a good ten minutes and no one stopped by so we just grabbed server who was walking by and placed our order.  We had plenty of time to sit outside and look over the menu, so we knew exactly what we wanted once we were in.  We started with the breaded shrooms.  Meh, I've had better breaded mushrooms.  I thought they were going to come out like stuffed mushrooms.  They were more like deep fried mushrooms with a lot of batter.  I ended up pulling the actual mushroom out of the breading and eating it plain instead.   Then the pizza came out. I guess Pequod's pizza can't be technically considered deep dish, but rather pan pizza?  WHO CARES?  IT WAS AMAZING.  The sauce was great, the crust was nice and crispy, plenty of toppings.  On top of all that, our server accidentally put in a medium size order for us when we originally asked for small.  They apologized and only charged us for the small!  I wanted to apologize to the restaurant for not being able to finish our food!  We were leaving Chicago the next day, so we couldn't even take the pizza home.  So sad. I would definitely suggest this place to others.  But would add the caveat, if you want to be seated close to when you want to eat, make sure to email in advance a reservation request!  I don't know that I would wait two hours for Pequod's, much less any restaurant, but I would definitely do an hour wait.

Worst deep dish pizza I have ever had was burnt and way over cooked and took two hours to deliver two blocks. The only reason I'm rating this 3 stars is the thin crust I had was great and will continue to order it.

Worst time estimate ever.  Quoted 50 min for a medium pizza. Was mmire than double the wait. Stood waiting for 50 min extra. Could have cooked 2 other pizzas while I was standing there. I kept being told it would be only 4 min wait. Dont trust their estimates.  Not worth the waste of my time.
World's slowest service. Wait staff ignores you once you request an update on your food an hour after ordering.  I hope this pizza is the best tasting thing on the planet......
Best deep dish in chicago , better than Lou malnati's. Try going during off times (Saturday night is usually a 2 hour wait) or order for pick up.

The deep dish was ok but not worth the 1 1/2 hour wait. Good and flavorful sausage chunks, yummy airy crunchy crust (like Lou Malnati's) but not into the burnt edges, and mediocre sauce that lacks flavor. It is overrated and I still prefer Lou's. Can't say I will be back with a wait like that.

The meatballs were amazing on this pan dish pizza. The crust was extremely buttery and cheesy, however, I do prefer a deep dish pizza as opposed to the pan pizza that they have here, it's just all about preference.   It was a nice change especially as I pigged out on Chicago deep dish pizzas for about 3-4 weekends in a row.  Don't judge!  ;P

Almost speechless at how good this pan pizza is. We love them all but the chunks of sausage were huge making my 'crazy about meat' husband very happy.  Crust melts in your mouth.  Tuesday night was a good time to go compared to weekends where I can imagine this place getting packed.  Service is just fine.

1st let me say that I am a New Yorker, so I consider myself a pizza expert.  I visit Chicago often and when I do, I always enjoy the Deep Dish Pizza.  I heard about Pequod's and wanted to give it a try with some of my local friends who were also waiting to try this place. We started with some Onion rings.  Nothing great.  More frozen then home made.  Then the pizza...  The crust was about the best I have had in Chicago.  The sauce was a dark and thick.  Very tasty. Service was excellent and very friend.  I gave it 3 stars because of the appetizer but if I just ad the pizza, I would give it 4.

Sorry, this is simply the best pizza in Chicago.  Period, end of paragraph.   Don't even try with those other shops.  You can't match the crust, the toppings and the sauce.  Don't try.  Tourists, do yourself a favor and take a 5 minute cab ride to Lincoln Park and get the best pizza in Chicago, ergo, possibly the best pizza in the world!
When you make the best pizza in Chicago, you're going to have an awful wait. So, plan your trips to this top tier pizza joint ahead of time. The caramelized edges of their deep dish is unbeatable.

I didn't like this as much as I anticipated.  I ordered a large cheese deep dish and it certainly wasn't bad but it didn't really tickle my fancy either.  I prefer a denser crust and a brighter/fresher tasting sauce (i.e. still has the bite from fresh tomatoes).  This pie has a very light crust that is more bread-like than crust like and the sauce is a low and slow cooked sauce that is heavy on the oregano.  The kind of sauce that is better suited for pasta than pizza.  Obviously this is just my opinion and it seems that a lot of people really love this stuff so I am in the minority but if you have similar tastes as I do you may be a bit disappointed as well.

Don't believe the hype. After reading and hearing great things about this place, I had to try it on my recent visit to Chicago. We waited almost an hour for a table for 5 and an additional hour for the pizza. Their basic pizza is just cheese, so we added pepperoni, sausage, mushrooms and peppers. The pizza is ALL CRUST! I mean 80% BREAD and a sprinkle of toppings. Their famous caramelized crust is just soft, chewy burnt cheese. The crust was super soft and the sauce had no flavor. I was thoroughly disappointed. IMO, the pizza was NOT a traditional Chicago deep dish. I'll stick to Lou's next time. Service was also super slow and drinks are weak.

Moving cross country from Philly to Seattle,  passing through Chicago and per the previous reviews decided to stop here for deep dish - and it did not disappoint.  Simple pepperoni pie was prefect;  and Italian beef with fresh basil (ordered on a whim) was delicious.  I could not grant the final star, because of the wait staff.  Impersonal,  inattentive,  and  unknowledgeable (about the freshness/quality of ingredients)... overall poor individual job done. If anyone for the establishment is reading,  please note: Iced tea should be more than just brown-colored water.

So far this is the best deepdish I had in town. Everyone talks about the baked cheese on the crust and there's a reason!  The cheese on this was very generous, think giordanos, while the ingredients were fresh. What really caught me was the tomato sauce, they do it right. Good amount of tangy sweet.  The place itself was dimly lit, and we couldn't find great seats, it was pretty crowded. But deep dish, after here, has become a new thing for me!

First off...let me say...as far as deep dish goes?  5 stars...my favorite in Chicago.  Here is why I'm giving it 2 stars, and just as a warning to other potential customers... They have a delivery map online with a quote that says "Our delivery range covers most of north Chicago but if you live near the fringe call and see if we can make it to you, we are accustomed to making reasonable exceptions."   It also states an additional $1.00 delivery charge for that.  No big deal.  I live 2 blocks north of the cutoff.  I was told that they could not deliver there.  She checked with a manager and said "no".  Normally, this wouldn't be a big issue, except it specifically states that if you live "near the fringe"...which I consider 2 blocks to be...they are "accustomed to making reasonable exceptions." It's unfortunate because it takes an additional 30 seconds, which I would easily tip extra for.  They have lost a consistent delivery customer as a result, and has left a bad taste in my mouth for a place I otherwise drooled over.

My brother ordered pizzas from here last Friday during my visit and I really don't think this place is as good as the more legendary pizza places in Chicago.  The thick crust pizza is almost all bread and the toppings and cheese are very lightly used. Its not like this place is any cheaper than the other places.  The crust doesn't have the same great cornmeal taste of Malnatis.  I will say the delivery was on time which is where they are getting some stars from me.  I'm glad I tried it so I can check it it off my list. Id order from Malnatis during my next visit

A disappointing meal.  The food took a really long time to come out (90mins approx)- we were a larger group but the food didn't all come at once so it was surprising that it took so long.  We ordered some starters which seemed to have just come straight out of a frozen packet- not very flavoursome.  I had deep dish pizza with a mix of vegetables. The toppings were good but the base tomato sauce and cheese was not to my liking.  Other people in our party had a mix of deep dish and thin base and seemed to have a similar complaint. Overall it just didn't have a great flavour.  I've heard great things about this place so maybe it was because it wasn't what we were used to pizza wise.  Staff were pleasant and attentive

My cousin recommended that we eat here instead of my customary Chicago deep dish pizzeria, so I found myself at Pequod's for the first time last night. One star deducted for ignoring his 6:30 reservation... we had to wait 20+ minutes for a table. But that was the only black mark. The service was topnotch and very friendly. The appetizers were wonderful, and the pizza was delicious! As some other reviewers have noted, it is not the same as other deep dish varieties. One big difference is the caramelized crust, which I thought was terrific. They also have Goose Island on tap (the GI brewery is just down Clybourne), which goes very well with pizza. We would definitely return!

I stopped by here for the first time a couple days ago after a workout. I had heard a ton of amazing things, but I was especially drawn in by the lunch special. For $4.95 you can get a personal pan pizza with one topping and a fountain soda (no refills)!! If you check in on Yelp, you can get the same deal but with a beer. The pizza took a while to prepare, but hopefully that means the lunch portions are made to order (some places have frozen lunch pizzas). The pizza was delicious and the service was excellent. I'll definitely be back!

Came in at 9pm on a Sunday. Seated right away. Waitress took drink orders right away then disappeared.  Waited a while to give food order.  Appetizers came out relatively quickly. Standard bar fare nothing special. At 10:30 waitress says they lost the ticket and pizza will take 20 minutes.   Offered us a salad, we specified no meat...salad came out with a mountain of pepperoni on it Pizza came out at 11pm didn't leave until midnight after arriving at 9pm.  The only reason it gets three stars is that the waitress did her best to fix it and comped the pizza, and the pizza was delicious.

Okay, born and raised Southsider here so when northsiders told me they had good pizza on the Northside I was skeptical so I tried it. OMG, GREAT PIZZA!!!!! The caramelized crust was to die for. Very tasty, very hard to not walk out of this place stuffed!!!! It's probably a good thing that we live on the extreme opposite end of Chicago from this place, or I'd have it much more. Very good pizza, very good!!!!

FINALLY made it out here - let me preface this by saying I don't normally like deep dish pizza. I know, I know - I'm a Chicago traitor.  I usually find deep dish to be too clunky and heavy, when I get pizza I want to eat four or five slices at least, and you just can't do that when you're eating deep dish.. unless you have the appetite and stomach capacity of a sumo wrestler. We split a medium deep dish pizza topped with sausage, giardiniera, and onions.  While it does take a bit of time to bake (they need time to make that great crispy crust) - the wait is well worth it.  I've never had such a flavorful and well cooked deep dish crust.  The balance of sauce, toppings, and cheese was also on point.  Will definitely be coming back when I'm having substantial pizza cravings. Check out my full review and pictures at  thehungrynoodle.weebly.c…

My boyfriend and I was on a deep dish food adventures in Chcago and we have to say Pequod's Pizzeria have the best deep dish pizza! We got a small pineapple, pepperoni, grounded beef, with extra sauce deep dish pizza. It was def saucy just the way we like it! The ground beef tasted so juicy and fresh.

Only being to Chicago a handful of times, I've always been chasing the best pizzeria in the city. I've done my rounds with the tourist locations like Giordano's, Gino's East and Lou Malnati's. Even though each one was a spectacular deep dish pizza, getting the recommendation for Pequod's from Chicago natives changed everything. The caramelized cheese on the crust and the perfectly executed marinara sauce make this the best damn pizza I have ever eaten. It's amazing.

This review will be about the take out. We had a Chicago style deep dish pizza contest where Pequod's faced Due's deep dish. Completely unanimous opinion that Pequod's should simply be tossed. When I think of deep dish, I envision the typical doughy crust with cheese and toppings then covered in sauce. When our pizza came out, it looked like we didn't even have sauce on it, the little bit we found was just, okay. I went with my favorite combo, peppers, onions, sausage and mushroom, enough toppings to make it interesting but not to overload the pizza. Ours was completely covered, which was fine, but it was somewhat flavorless and simply too much. I will give props to the outer crust, it was delicious the way they caramelized the outside. It was flaky and light which I enjoyed. That being said, the center was completely soggy and falling apart. For take out, this was a bad choice but it might be better at the shop. Overall, there are much better places in the city for deep dish, I'd include Lou's over this one. Due's still stands strong as the best in my mind. As a disclaimer, yes this review was specific to take out. I did eat in once, it was just okay but I wasn't too impressed.

Decent pizzs but the waitress was kinda rude at the end. She threw down our to go items and walked away without saying goodnight. We only saw her to refill our drinks which she did without asking . I couldnt handle to big cups of gingerale lol too much sugar

Meh. Pizza was just ok, nothing special, nothing to rave about. Although we are from Vegas, we wanted to try real Chicago pizza and a lot of people told us about this place. We searched high and low for this place and of course there was a huge wait by the time we got there, but that's ok, we don't mind waiting. When we finally got the pizza, it just didn't taste as fresh as we had hoped, the sauce was basic and it smelled like Pizza Hut  maybe we set our expectations too high or maybe we should have gone here first before trying other pizzas. Not my first choice.

Don't fall for the hype.... A great surprise, my boyfriend and I walked in expecting to wait over an hr for a table but got seated immediately. We were so surprised I even asked the waitress if this was peqouds lolol. So, yay for that.  Now onto the important stuff, the pizza. My boyfriend and I ordered a customized pan pizza and it was disappointing. It was a very average pan pizza, I have had better. Usually I will scarf down pizza but last night I only ate a slice because I was so disappointed I didn't want to bother anymore. So there you have it- not all that great.  Their crust is way too much, the pizza is literally 80% crust 13% tomato and cheese and 7% toppings- I need less crust and more tomatoes, cheese and toppings please  Won't be coming back
Went here last night and the pizza was good but our service was lacking. Could have just been an off night though judging by all the good reviews.

I eat A LOT of pizza.  In my world, there is no such thing as bad pizza.  Hands down, this is the best pizza I have ever put into my body.  And there has been a lot of pizza in this body. I had it 11 hours ago, and I'm considering a trip up there for lunch.

PEQUOD'S HAS THE BEST CHICAGO-STYLE PIZZA IN CHICAGO AND I WILL FIGHT YOU IF YOU DISAGREE Pepperoni + onion + green pepper is the go-to.  Keep it simple, stupid. Side note: their Italian salad dressing is da bomb.  I'm sure it's from a bottle or whatever but screw you, I would drink that shit. Pro-tip: go to the Drinkingbird next door afterwards for some good (and cheap) after-dinner craft cocktails

We came here about two weeks ago after I ran the Chicago Half Marathon. What better way to celebrate running 13.1 miles than by stuffing your face with deep dish pizza!!! We started off with the onion rings. They were huge and very good when dipped in the accompanying barbecue sauce. We ordered the small deep dish pizza with pepperoni and mushrooms. The pepperoni was nicely toasted and tasted great on the pizza. The pizza had just the right amount of cheese and the crust was very good. The top of the crust is slightly burnt and gives a good taste. This was definitely the best deep dish pizza that I have had in a long time. After only two slices I was totally full. The service was decent, even though they were busy. Food Network was there recording people eating in the restaurant for an upcoming episode. I doubt I will get on t.v., but that was still pretty cool. If you want good pizza, look no further than Pequod's.  We will definitely be back.

I've lived in Chicago for 6 years and for some reason had never gone to Pequods. It actually wasn't until recently that I realized how popular this joint was. I'm not a big deep dish fan, but I was excited to try their pan pizza. Off the bat, I really liked the vibe of this place. It had a chill sports bar kind of vibe, with no frills and great beers on tap. I was tempted to have an Oktoberfest on draft, but I didn't want to fill up my stomach with anything other than delicious pizza. We waited about 15 minutes for a table and were seated the second our pager went off. We split a ceasar salad as an appetizer and got a medium pan pizza with mushrooms, spinach, pepperoni, and sausage. I loved it! I loved that the crust wasn't paper thin like a lot of Chicago pizza's, but also wasn't crazy deep dish. We gorged and still had room for leftovers (which I obviously ate for breakfast the next day). Great spot! Little bit of a wait, but definitely worth it.

Awesome pizza joint and closes late (2am)! The caramelized crust is something I've never tried before and it's amazing. Three of us ordered a large (first time having deep dish) since we just got off a 4 hour plane ride from SF, and was starving since we skipped dinner. We overestimated ourselves. We finished half the pizza, and took home the other half, which had to be at least a pound of food! Great food, great value! I think one slice per person is more than enough. I was stuffed.
The cheese baked outside the crust is like a party for my taste buds! The rest of the pizza left a bit to be desired in the flavor department.
Pizza was good, but waited about 45 mins for just an order of a large pizza on a Sunday morning around 10:00 am.

I am quite picky about my pizza, so I don't make this statement lightly: this is the best pizza I have ever eaten. Bacon is not an available topping, but the pizza is so good you won't notice. Eat the pizza. Do it. Do it.

I didn't grow up in this city, I grew up with pizza chains.  Of all the pizza chains that were in my life, there was nothing that could top a pan pizza from Pizza Hut.  Chefs, employees, fans of Pequod's, please don't take offense to this statement....Pequods pizza is a Chicago Style Pizza Hut pan pizza on steroids.  I truly mean that in the highest compliment possible. We got a pan pizza the other night before seeing Ninja Turtles 3d.  Since we obviously weren't getting anchovies on the pizza (hardy har har), we decided on sausage and giardinera.  If you are a meat lover, be sure to go with sausage, as they throw HUGE chunks all up and in that pie.  I also liked how the crust was a little burnt on the sides, but not in a bad way.   I can only write so much about a pizza place, but I will say this place jumped up to one of my favorites in the city, go check it out if you haven't already.
my roommate works there...so far ive had a personal deep dish sausage and pepperoni and so far i can say so far im iimpressed.

I took a very short trip to Chicago and trying deep dish pizza was definitely on my list. I stayed at Hotel Lincoln and researched places online that had the best deep dish pies. With over 1800 reviews on Yelp, Pequod's looked very promising. It was very close to the hotel and my boyfriend and i took an uber to Pequod's. We sat at the bar and ordered a small (10") pan pizza with mushrooms, italian sausage, pepperoni and basil. We waited for quite some time but the pizza was pretty yummy and met my expectations -- although i can't make any comparisons since this is the only place that I've tried in Chicago for deep dish. It was very tasty and i was pretty full after one slice. Overall, I'd say it was a good pizza but I'd be willing to try another spot.

It's our tradition, following a hard weekend at Renegade Craft Fair to hit up Pequod's for delicious pizza. It's always so delicious and worth the wait. This review is mainly about the service received.  We sat down, party of 5, and requested waters right away - it was a long long day. Server comes back, no waters, takes our drink order (including mentioning waters again). Returns with beers, no waters. We ask one more time for water and she hears us as if we had never asked before.  5 waters are then brought to the table and the final one was dumped, ice bucket challenge style on my friends sitting on the end. They were shocked out of their mind.  I never heard her, but others said she said sorry at that time, but it was so much commotion that it didn't come across. She brought over napkins and then that was it. My poor soaking friends took it in great stride. We know accidents happen, we just wish there had been some sort of apology. Some remorse over the fact that they had to sit in the super A.C.'d upper level with a huge puddle at their feet and freeze as we waited for our pizza.  Pizza arrived, delivered by someone one else and she lost control of the scalding pan and it slid on the table right towards my friend who received the brunt of the water. Thankfully the server caught it before it could burn the crap out of my friend, but seriously, the only torture we expect pizza waiting is from our grumbly stomachs, NOT the waitstaff.  Again, TOTALLY get accidents happen. We have all been servers before, I just would have handled that situation so differently. I would have apologized more than once, I would have come back to see if we were comfortable, I would have offered to move us so we didn't have a puddle at our feet, and I would have talked to my manager to see if there was any sort of compensation that could be provided. That's basic customer service. We were all kind of appalled to see that not even the ice tea was comped. Perhaps it's entitlement, but I can't remember the last time I was at a restaurant and a mistake went unacknowledged like that.  Now here was the hardest part. As check was delivered, and again, no apologies were ever made outside of the drop we had to contemplate tip. Some would say none, the service was terrible. Some would say the regular 20%, accidents happen. I kept going back and forth, again being a server... what if this was the worst day of your life and this happened to you.  But again, if it was me that would inspire me to take great care of a table and show them how sorry I was. I wound up tipping 12% .... and we are most likely taking our tradition somewhere else next time.

Okay, admittedly I love pizza. You have to have some pretty crappy pizza for me to write a terrible review. Some might say that I'm a bit of a pizza connoisseur, others might say I'm merely a patron. Nonetheless, Peqoud's is TRUE CHICAGO pizza. I feel like a real Chicago native when I'm in this lovely establishment. It's super divey, but not in a creepy, dusty way. It's simply dark enough and loud enough to feel like you're apart of something bigger than yourself. That thing that is bigger is an overwhelming pizza experience. The crust is perfectly caramelized, and the sauce is a lovely combination of tangy and sweet. I'm just saying, you have to go to this pizza place if you want to feel apart of Chicago. DA BEARS.
Sausage pan pizza is amazing. One of the best deep dish pizzas I have had in Chicago. Highly recommend it. Very busy at some times though, I recommend calling ahead to see if you can reserve a spot.

If I was rating their Pizza, I'd give it 5 stars. Unfortunately, their service really brings the place down. I've went and eaten here a few times, but after being lied to about wait times for tables and food on numerous occasions, only to have the food order screwed up. I really don't care about a long wait (it's a popular place), but just tell me the truth and bring out the food as it was ordered and I won't be upset. Most recently I decided to forego that experience and order delivery. Pizza is still great, but they still manage to screw something up. Most recently I had them repeat the order to me, even then they still manage to forget a salad and an ingredient on the pizza.  As I've said a few times, the pizza is good, but there is A LOT of really good pizza in Chicago. Save yourself the pain of Pequod's and get one of the others.

I usually prefer thin crust to pan pizza but the way the crust is done here is just something else! I guess the pizza crust is caramelized and baked, giving the pan pizza a crispy outer layer. Definitely one of the better pizza places I've tried!

For the life of me.. I cannot understand why or how anyone finds this food enjoyable. Both thin crust and deep dish taste like a trial run homemade pizza - done horribly. The sauce tastes like it's right out of a can, the crust is dry and tasteless, and the cheese came sliding all around the pizza - hardly cooked or sliced properly.  The only reason I gave it a second chance was because they messed up my order the first time - Sent me a deep dish when I ordered thin crust, then gave me a credit instead of refunding the money. Thanks for the credit, but everything I've tried is just.. Bad.

First time having deep dish so perhaps I'm not versed enough to "get it"... there wasn't really any sauce or cheese, mostly just dough.  I thought deep dish would be smothered with cheese like in the pictures.  Oh well....

This place has a fiercely loyal following that consider it the second-coming of "Chicago-Style" pizza. That said, having grown up in Chicago, I can remember the glory days of the great deep-dish restaurants: Uno's, Duo's, Gino's East, and Lou Malanati. In the 1970s, these were temples to the deep-dish style pizza that Chicago has unfortunately become known for. Today, Pequods has become the underground go-to place of a new generation. I ate there last week on the recommendation of someone I trust to know about good food and who has a deep appreciation for this place. Three adults and a 4 year old went to a late lunch on a weekday. The service was a bit slow and awkward. I am not sure if the server was new, inexperienced, snobby, or just lazy nor do I care. First ding to service. We ordered two deep fried appetizers: mushrooms and zucchini. We also order two bowls of soup as appetizers: minestrone type soup and a potato soup. The deep fried zucchini were straight from freezer burn to deep fryer burn and were simply awful. The mushrooms by comparison were also frozen but at least properly cooked. The potato soup was boring and odd. The other soup was actually good. The terrible tasting deep fried zucchini took an extraordinary amount of time to burn and bring to the table. Second ding to appetizers. The table had become quite cluttered with dishes, silverware, paper, etc. and the server simply ignored it and also refilling our drinks. Second ding to the server. We then had the lunch special of a small deep dish pizza with a drink for around $5.95. The pizza was more than enough food to satisfy even a large appetite, despite its relatively small size; it was very dense. Two pizzas came with pepperoni, one with mushrooms, and one with plain cheese. The pepperoni (meat itself) was good quality. The ring of the crust was burnt in a caramelized manner. Interesting and strange. The pizza was good in an addictive way. Each bite demanded another. Not being a deep-dish fan (Chicago has always been a thin crust town except for the tourists and suburbanites), I was surprised I ate it all. The pizza was about half as deep as a classic Chicago-Style and the ingredients were fresh.  , The bill was wrong and needed to be corrected which required actually getting up and finding the server. If there was a manager present, it wasn't apparent. To round off the experience, I was in the men's room with one of the waiters (they all wear the same shirt) who left the room without washing his hands. I swear this is true as shocking as it is. This place is not for me. Apparently, not for my wife either, who had indigestion for a day and a half.

I'm not much of a deep dish pizza guy. Like Jon Stewart once said, I see it as more tomato soup in a bread bowl than an actual slice of pizza, but when in Rome (er, Chicago), why not indulge as the locals do? Pequod's was suggested by a friend who has awful tattoos, but a pretty solid taste in food and he didn't steer us wrong. A small deep dish was more than enough for two people and it was quite affordable as well (I believe it was somewhere in the neighborhood of $12). The best part were the burnt ends of the crust, and as someone who doesn't always end up eating the crust, this was a nice surprise at the end of the tomato saucy rainbow. The place itself is a bit of a dive and the perfect setting for a quick bite before a Cubs game. If I lived in town, chances are this would be my go to spot when craving a Chicago style pie (or "a f**king casserole" as Mr. Stewart calls it).
Pretty good pizza. On par with Lou's, but not as amazing as everyone makes it out to be. The inside of the restaurant is huge, so that was nice.
