Recommend the pan pizza pepperoni is my personal favorite.. Had the zucchini as an appetizer was great love this place !!!

Ordered delivery on a Sunday night at 7:30.  Told delivery would take about an hour and a half but it came in about an hour. Yeah! First time ordering- and it sure is yummy!! Got  a thin crust and a deep dish and both were fabulous.

Pizza was ok, when it finally arrived.  We waited over an hour for the pizza.  Kitchen never got the order, misplaced the order, whatever it was.  It could have been handled better.  With many good pizza options, we will not be going back here.

The service here has gone really down hill. They forgot our appetizers (we never got them), we had empty drinks for about an hour, and it took about an hour and 45 minutes for us to get our pizza from the time we ordered it.
Very good crust, overall presentation nicely done. Pepperoni tasted good. Sauce was lacking a little sweetness but as a whole a good pizza! The pan crust is the way to go. I would recommend to try.

Went here with my family and friends, it was quite a long wait even with reservations. Carry out would be a smart choice if you don't like waiting. The night we went was extremely muggy and it was even hotter inside because it was so packed with people.
I love Pequod's probably as much as I love my family. Deep dish with sausage is the way to go.

I will preface this review with having recently relocated from NYC, I have a different take on pizza than most locals here in Chicago (I know, I know...). That being said, I (of course) had their thin crust pizza- which was the best I've tried since being in Chicago. I thought they did a great job, and the atmosphere of the place was spot on. Once I finally get over the fact that I can't get Brooklyn style pizza here in Chicago, my rating will most likely move to 5 stars (just bitter!)

Came here on a Thursday night and it was pretty packed. Bf and I had been wanting to try this place out because we saw it on a list of all-time must-try pizzas and I read some great things about the famous caramelized cheese crust. They initially told us the wait for a table of two would be about 30 minutes, but our pager went off almost immediately after walking outside. No wait on a busy night was fine by me! We were led upstairs and seated before our waitress took our drink orders. Bf got his beer promptly but 10 minutes passed and I had still not received my water. Not being able to ignore my thirst, I had to flag down our waitress and ask the whereabouts of my water, to which she finally brought it out.  Knowing that deep-dish pizzas typically take a while to make, we ordered the onion rings to start off with. They came out pleasantly quick and were really delicious. They were big, flavorful, and perfectly crunchy; like an extremely upgraded version of bk onion rings. My bf couldn't stop smiling at his satisfaction and said they were probably the best onion rings he's had. Our pizza, however, took excruciatingly long to come out. I expected to wait, but we must have waited probably an hour AFTER we finished the onion rings. What bothered me even more was seeing some tables that arrived and ordered after us get their pizzas before us.  We ordered a medium pan pizza with mushroom, spinach, and pineapple and it looked and smelled amazing when it finally arrived at our table. While the pizza was flavorful and the cheese was wonderfully gooey, I was kinda disappointed at how doughy the pizza was. The thick dough in each bite made it seem as if it wasn't even a deep-dish. The caramelized cheese crust was good, but Pequod's didn't live up to the hype overall. So far I've tried three deep-dish pizza places in Chicago and Lou Malnati's is probably my favorite, followed by Pequod's, and then Giordano's.

I've been here on multiple occasions and I can definitely say I am a fan. They're not my favorite game in town, but they make a good pizza none-the-less. Their signature is caramelized crust on their deep dish pizza and that's what keeps me going back. My one gripe with this place is that I feel like the bottom crust is too bready in comparison to the rest of the pie. I get around this by ordering extra cheese any time I'm there. To my tastes, it corrects the ratio.

For the pizza, I'd give a hesitant 3, for everything else, I'm livid. I booked a table in advance knowing that it'd be packed and we had reservations to get to afterwards.  I did not realize that booking a table just reduces your wait time.  Pequod's PLEASE make it clearer on your reservation page that this isn't a "reservation" so much as a "wait time reduction." We took seats at the bar so we could avoid the wait time we didn't expect.  We were told the pizza would take about 45 minutes to an hour to come out.  An hour and 40 minutes later we were scarfing it down to be able to get to our show on time.  Absolutely no one was keeping us updated as to what the hell happened to our food.  We even pre-paid just to be able to walk out a tiny bit faster. To boot, we were told a small plus a medium would be "just right" for 4 people.  For real?  We ended up handing half of the pie to some lucky guy on the street just so we didn't feel it was totally wasted. I wanted to love this and really could not have been more heartbroken.
Good pizza, certainly earns four stars!!!

First let me say that the service was excellent both the waitress and server went out of the way to explain to us what made their pizza different to the rest and gave us great recommendations. We started with mozzarella sticks (very yummy) then we had pepperoni pizza which was different to a chicago deep dish because this was more crush but it was good. For dessert the lovely waitress recommend the brownie and we also ordered a peanut butter and chocolate chip cookie and both were delicious and served warm.

We opted for delivery and were severely disappointed. The deep dish consisted of 90% crust and very little cheese. To top it off, the crust was burned to a crisp.  I love pizza, and am really not that picky when it comes down to it, but after picking off over half of the crust of my first slice, I didn't even bother going back for another. Needless to say, I wouldn't order from here again.

This is more of a catch up review from last year. The girl friend at the time and I went to Pequods as a reference from her sister. Our first time there our pizza didn't taste very good, crust was cracked, and the waitress was rude. We figured that maybe it was just a busy night because every restaurant was swamped because of the Hawks game at the time so we tried a second time a week later. The food came out even worst the second time and looked almost inedible. When asked to replace or remake the food we received attitude/disgust from the waitress (not the same one) about it, and she even had the audacity to complain when we didn't leave a tip. Not sure if its because we ordered thin crust at a deep dish pizza place, but the now fiance and I both agreed we'd never go back to Pequods if given a choice again. Edit! Found the original review from last summer! My girl friend and I went here twice. The first time our food was drastically under cooked so we figured we give it a second time before making a final judgement on the establishment. The second time was worst. Our food had little to no sauce, disintegrated as we attempted to pick it up, and our waitress acted as if the work she was doing beneath her. Pequod's overall is your typical garbage college pizza bar with overpriced food, questionable quality of food, and horrendous service. If located anywhere else that wasn't a "college town" Pequod's wouldn't last more than a year before going out of business. Its a shame that "today's youth" find such a place desirable.

Obviously, the deep dish battle in Chicago will never reach a conclusion. That being said, Pequod's is my favorite. The deep dish is similar to Lou's but really does have that homemade taste that the larger chains lack. I tend to go for the Italian sausage and mushroom, but the pepperoni is also excellent. The sauce is somewhat plain, but allows for the toppings to really come through. I would ignore any thoughts about appetizers, none of them have really stood out to me and the pizza really does deserve your empty stomach. Make a reservation if you have a larger party or you will end up waiting for quite awhile. I went with my family (6) mid-week and was quoted for 40 minutes, learned my lesson! Overall, definitely worth the trip.

I was originally going to give Pequods 5 stars because their deep dish truly has a different character to it which I appreciate. However, last night's experience really turned me off. We waited outside for 45 mins. This wasn't a big problem because it was nice out and we put our order in as soon as we arrived so we knew as soon as we got seated the pizza was going to be soon to follow. The frustrating part was after waiting 45 mins, we had to wait another hour for the pizza to come.  We also got wedged in an uncomfortable booth in the back corner which was hot and had a pipe above is that was dripping water the whole time. Yes. The pizza was great. But the experience was not. To top it all off, the place is understaffed so it took 10 mins to get someone's attention to get and extra set of silverware, 30 mins to have someone get our check, 15 mins to run the credit cards, etc etc. Very frustrating. I wanted to rate this a 2-star experience but the pizza was really good so I would give it 3 or 4 stars. Hoping for a better experience if I go back ...

Wow, I sure don't get what all the hype is about. I found the pizza dry and unremarkable.  My Pie/Lil' Guys is a much better deep dish in my opinion.  But the real reason I'm giving them one star is that I called on a Tuesday night and was quoted a 90 minute delivery window. It actually took nearly 2 hours, and of course was barely warm when it go here. I'll not be ordering again.

Pequod's is delicious. I am not typically a fan of the deep dish, but they do really well with it here. If you have to do deep dish (like when your out of town relatives come to visit and have to have it), this is the place to go. The beer list is OK too. I'd recommend calling ahead to put your name in. They don't take reservations, but they do preferred seating so your name moves to the top of the list when your party arrives. Otherwise the wait times can be a little excruciating. I've tacked off a star for the service. In all of the times I've been here I've had to nearly stand on my chair to get our servers attention. I'll still visit you though Pequod's.
Excellent pizza.  This place is better than pizanos in my opinion.  A good tip for the thin crust pizza is to get a side of marinara sauce.  It's delicious

I wanted a deep dish slice but wasn't hungry enough to eat a whole pizza so i ordered their lunch special.  It looked like a deep dish but was all dough.  I was disappointed but  it did taste really good.  Then i looked at the deep dish pizza at the table next to me and hungered for more.  Don't order the special go strait for the dish.

Really good deep dish, but I didn't think it lived up to the hype or was the holy grail of deep dish like some Yelpers made it seem out to be. The pizza tasted like any other ol' deep dish pizza until you get to the crispy, burnt crust, which was indeed delicious, but not really a deal maker in my opinion. I did really like that they heaped on the toppings (pepperoni, mushrooms, and olives) and thought that the cheese/sauce ratio was perfect. My table also ordered the appetizer sampler, which was yummy because we were starving, but nothing special (besides the jalapeno poppers which were gross and filled with Cheez Wiz type cheese).  Like other Yelpers have said, the service here is definitely lacking. My friend pre-ordered the pizza at 7 PM and said we'd be coming in at 7:45 PM and the waiter rudely asked my friend to call back at 7:15 PM to place the order since the pies take 30 min. My friend then just suggested that they just write down our order and put it in at 7:15, which thankfully they agreed to. This kind of left a bad taste in our mouths, especially since the pizza wasn't ready until about 8:15 anyways. Overall, I think Pequods is a place that everyone who likes deep dish should try, but don't expect it to be out of this world if you've eaten a lot of deep dish because it's not much different from other good pizza joints (e.g., Lou Malnati's, Ginos East).

If pizza preference measured my city pride I'd be a terrible Chicagoan. Thin crust has always been much more appetizing to me than a block of melted mozzarella. If I must dive into the deep dish though this is the spot I do it. Their caramelized crust really steps the experience up a notch.  They don't get the national recognition of Malnati's or Giordano's, but I promise you Pequod's is where it's at if you like feeling like you're pregnant after eating pizza. Lots of topping options, decent sauce to cheese ratio, and again of course that caramelized crust.  I don't often do pies this way, but when I do I choose Pequod's.

Had this deep dish for the first time yesterday night after getting home late from ohare. I have to say my boyfriend and I were impressed. We got a 12" pan with sausage mushrooms onion green peppers. The Italian sausage was so tasty. We wanted some left overs and there was plenty! I could only eat 1 piece. So filling. Also the pricing was beyond reasonable. I was shocked that for all those toppings and size it was only $25. Will definitely be coming back.

The food and atmosphere in here were fantastic and I would definitely visit again. However, when we first arrived we were seated at the back upstairs and for some reason everything was vibrating (the table, chairs, cutlery, etc.). I can only assume that this is because it's situated above the kitchen fan. The waitress was very helpful and facilitated our move downstairs but if  you are coming here I definitely try and avoid the upstairs backroom.

made a reservation for 7PM - still had to wait 45 mins to sit. whats the point? by the time I actually got the pizza an hour later, it was completely BURNT not only on the crust but on the bottom as well. Was like eating carbon, but was so hungry at that point from waiting so long that I didn't even care. I understand the burnt crust is their thing, but the fact that the whole pizza was burned killed all the flavor. Was willing to see what all the hype about this place was, but it made me realize that Lou Malnati's is still the king.

WoW! First review ever, but stay away! They make you wait for a seat in an empty place. They wait you wait for the pizza that's burnt and not good at all. The crust is all dry, hard as a rock! Had both the pan and thin. Thin was to much dough not any good. What a waste of time. Don't see what people see in this place it's no Lou Malnati's! You want pan go there not here!

Like much of my dating life, I have been consistently underwhelmed by Pequod's.   Pequod's is the place that is recommended for out of town guests who want to try "real" deep dish.   What's real- A really long wait, although admittedly we got in much sooner than our quoted time. A less than stellar beer selection.  How hard would it be to get more diversity? Tasteless pizza.  Yes, I said tasteless.  While there's plenty of cheese, and the crust is so-so, the sauce tastes like canned meh.  There's more flavor on the pizzas I get from Trader Joe's. The staff is not rude, but I didn't find them to be exceptionally friendly, either. I won't seek out Pequod's on my own, and I doubt I'd recommend it, and it's not the first stop I'd go for pizza.
Fantastic pizza. Slow service for a slow lunch. Will absolutely come back.

This is a great deep dish pizza... Kinda reminds me of pizzarea UNO... But better... Nice crisp cheese all the way up the crust... Fresh sauce... Lots of toppings.... Beware this pizza is heavy... One to two slices and your done for hours... Tastes great even cold...

My husband and I wanted to try a deep dish pizza before we left Chicago so because of all the good reviews, we chose this place.  Let's start off, I love the atmosphere and the vibe of this place. I wish they had a bigger bar though, for both upstairs and downstairs.  We made our own deep dish of spinach, chicken, and mushrooms. The sauce was bland and watery. The bread was a lil too chewy as well. Along with the disappointment of the pizza, we also got the pizza bread which is like bread sticks. My husband really liked it.  Overall, if I come back to the city, I'm gonna find a different place to get deep dish pizza.

We had their pizza for the first time last night and we weren't too impressed.  I thought it was lacking sauce and my husband thought it was lacking cheese.  The toppings we chose were  giardiniera and Italian sausage.  The sausage was very good but the giardiniera was mostly jalapeños and a little bland.  While the pizza was edible the service was soooooo terrible.  We ended up just ordering from the bar bc a waitress never did come.  In my opinion, oven grinders is the best pizza in the city.

While Pequod's already have 1,000+ reviews, like Hot Doug's, I had to sing their praises! Hands down, the best deep dish pizza in Chicago. Hands down, the best environment to eat deep dish pizza in Chicago. You can be assured that there will be a wait of at least 45 minutes every time you come here, but it is totally worth it.  The quality of ingredients and specialty crust puts Pequod's above the likes Lou's, Giordano's, & Gino's East. While the aforementioned are fine estabilshments that I also enjoy, I'd rather go to Pequod's anytime. They have a cool environment as well, with TV's everywhere and memorabilia adorning the walls. The location in the heart of Lincoln Park doesn't hurt.  While Bourdain is partially correct that the only time Chicagoans eat deep dish is when visitors are in town, he's COMPLETELY FULL OF BOLOGNA when he says that deep dish sucks. Deep dish is amazing and so much better than your greasy shitpile New York slice. Who are we kidding, Chicago anything is better than the New York version. GO PEQUODS!

Yes! Amazing. Having never been a fan of deep dish pizza, the food here revealed a whole new kind of deep dish pan pizza to me. If you have had deep dish and think that the crust is too dry, this is the spot for you! Great service, which included the helpful tip that if you call ahead, they will make sure your pizza is 10min away from being ready when you are seated. Sweet!
Perhaps the best deep dish I ever had. Service was pleasant but slow. Server not to blame, they just need more help.

The deep dish was good and one of the places that serve the freshly made pizza right from the grill. The pizza was soft and well done. One of the few places that makes the best deep dish pizza. But the service is too slow. Other than that, the place was dim and loud.

I visited Pequod's on my first trip to Chicago after attempting unsuccessfully to get into uber-famous Lou Malnati's, which was jam-packed on a Friday night at 8PM. I wasn't going to wait 2 hours for pizza, so a friend who lives in the city suggested we try the less-famous Pequods. I am so glad we tried this place instead. We still had to wait an hour to be seated (this is after calling ahead for what I was told was "priority seating" and a 25 minute wait), but it was worth it. And, seriously, if you're getting pizza on a Friday night, you should expect heavy wait times. Our party of 4 ordered a medium deep dish pizza. The men in our group protested the idea of such a "small" pie, but the ladies were glad we stuck to our guns. 6 pieces of deep dish glory was plenty to go around. Our pan pizza had mushrooms, sausage and pepperoni on it. The crust was crunchy and delicious at first, though it did get soggy after a few minutes. But I have no complaints. The burnt cheese around the edge of this pizza was sublime. And the sausage:  Oh, the sausage. It was soft and casing-free (score! I hate chewing on sausage casings), and had a lovely hint of fennel. I've never tasted such yummy sausage. I wished there was more cheese, but I'm not complaining. This was my first Chicago pizza, and it was pretty darn good.

Possibly my favorite deep dish in the city. Dat carmelized crust, tho! Get the ground beef and pepp. It's the perfect meaty concoction on a cold evening before heading to a movie across the street. Very friendly, attentive service even on a Saturday.

U gotta go!!!! Best pizza , how is this possible when there giordano and Gino east in town. Affordable and local place. Take an uber driver there.  Ordered individual deep pan. Great to do when you don't want to share.
Decent originalish pizza spot. They have some of the better deep dish in the city but its not a memorable pizza place.

I suppose I should first share my thoughts on the other well known Chicago deep dish pizzas:  Lou Malnati's - Super buttery, super greasy, and super cheesy. Immediate food coma following the meal. If you love all of the above then you'll love Lou's. Giordano's - Heavy on the sauce and cheese and the crust felt wet. So basically it's a pile of yummy mush in your mouth. That's not necessarily bad, but also not amazing.  Pequod's is the perfect deep dish pizza. The ingredients are fresh. As in, the italian sausage is the best I've ever had and even the bell peppers still have a slight crunch. The crust isn't drenched in butter or grease and it has a light crunch. There's even a rim of burnt cheese around the top. (Don't make a face. Everyone loves burnt cheese.) Every person I have introduced to Pequod's has fallen in love. If you haven't already, go tonight.  Also, the pizza is made to order so you should expect to wait 30 minutes for the pizza after you've placed your order. Staff has always been awesome and the atmosphere feels like you're hanging out with your best friends at a divey sports bar.

Their pan pizza is my favorite in Chicago. The young ladies that answer their phone are my least favorite. Lived in Chicago for 14 years and ordered from them for most of that. Pizza was consistently good and their attitude and phone manners were consistently terrible. They make it obvious that they don't want to talk to you and don't give a shit about what you want. They're so popular and busy it probably doesn't actually hurt them very much, but yeah.. be advised. Rudest bunch of dicks to ever pick up a telephone.
I walked right past this place but I'm glad I turned around. I had the wings and the pan pizza.. D E L I C I O U S. I will be coming back!!!

Been here twice and haven't been disappointed.  It's not a "stuffed" pizza, but it's still delicious!  The difference being this pizza has a thick layer of fluffy crust/dough rather than a thick layer of cheese like you'd get from Lou's or Giordano's.  It does take about 45 minutes to make a pizza so keep that in mind.
We come here for our birthdays every year!! The deep dish cheese with giardineras is by farrrr our favorite! That Caramelized crust.... Yummmmmmmm!!

When I get back to Town this is one stop I would definetly take.  Had lunch here a few times, weekends and most nights gets packed. Had the Personal Pan Pizza with a beer, orderd a 2nd pan just for the beer! Great tasting pizza love the crust...

I am a little hesitant to write this review simply because I've heard so many good things about Pequod's (perhaps more recommendations than any other pizza place in Chicago) and also, I think I may have had some bad luck. But my experience with Pequod's last weekend can only be summarized as mediocre.  A friend and I went for a late lunch on a Sunday. I've heard crazy things about wait-times at this place, and we were seated instantly. (From what I've heard, waits typically only get bad around the dinner hour). Our service was just OK. The staff seemed a bit distant at first, but were increasingly friendly and more responsive as the meal went on, which was nice to see.  We started with an order of cheesy garlic bread which honestly was unimpressive for all I've heard about this place. It was good, but it wasn't anything I couldn't heat up in the microwave with some bread, butter, garlic, and cheese. And just two fairly small pieces for around $5.  The pizza itself is what really left me underwhelmed. There was nothing about this pizza's key elements that tasted any differently from any other tourist deep-dish place in Chicago. Quite frankly, the flavor and consistency of the crust is IDENTICAL to Gino's East. What's worse, the crust seemed even thicker, and there wasn't much cheese on my pizza. The thick/deep crust is something I don't mind if it's balanced out with the right amount of cheese and sauce, but this pizza didn't have that. We ordered pepperoni, and there was plenty of that. I had asked for half sausage, but for some reason I was brought a pizza with 1/4 sausage. When I asked the waitress about this, she did make sure I wasn't charged for 1/2 sausage, but then said that they don't do 1/4 or 1/2 toppings anyway (at least I think that's what she said). I was a little confused, but I was only charged for the one topping so that wasn't that big of a deal.  Perhaps I had a bad pie. I want to try my luck again and see if it is better. The carmelized cheese I noticed - but I was waiting for it to make this big impact on my tastebuds and it just didn't happen for me. Bottom line, the pepperoni was average, the sauce was average, there wasn't enough cheese, and there was way too much crust in proportion to the rest of the ingredients. I was really disappointed; for all I had heard about Pequod's I expected more. As far as deep dish goes, I think there's a lot more to Chicago pizza than deep dish and it's not something I want more than a few times a year. But again, I didn't find Pequod's to be any better than some of the more-known tourist places like Gino's East, Giordano's, Lou Malnati's, or Edwardo's. I've had better pizza from all of those places.  I hope my experience is better next time. Pequod's isn't bad at all - but I wasn't able to find anything substantiating the hype I'd heard so much about.

Quality pizza, one of my favorite deep dishes in the city and I love the caramelized crust.  They just don't have good service on a consistent basis and deliveries take awhile.   I think they have a great product but suffer from poor management (I have heard stories), high turnover and being busy.  For instance, Tuesday I took my 3 little cousins to see the 5 o'clock showing of Guardians of the Galaxy, I pre ordered 3 pizzas to be ready at 7:15, knowing they take awhile and I wanted to get the kids home to Beverly by 8:30 or so.  They "lost" the ticket number and pizzas were never even put in till about 7:45 and we didn't get out of there till around 8:45.   Nonetheless, a great place to hit if you have time.  Lunch special is good, you get a beer and a personal pizza for about $7.

Visiting Chicago with my daughter, I decided we needed to try some authentic deep dish Chicago Pizza. Pequod's seemed like the best place, only a 15 minute cab ride from where we were, and a lot of Great reviews on Yelp.   We arrived about 6:15 on Tuesday 8-5-2014. Its a Bar/restaurant. We walked in and were taken upstairs immediatly. They only had two soups, so we both ordered the Mushroom soup. For pizza we ordered deep dish with extra cheese, mushrooms and pepperoni. The mushroom soup came very quickly. It was good, nothing to rave about. I've had better, but I've had a lot worse. The pizza took a little while to arrive, but our waitress warned us. If you are getting fresh, deep dish pizza, you should expect it to take a while. It arrived and it was good. Now I am a Big Fan of Deep dish pizza, so I have tried a lot. Pequod's pizza is very good, but again, nothing memorable. The crust was overly cooked, a bit too burned and crispy for my daughter and I. We have a pizzeria in the Detroit area called Pizza Papalis, that is my all time favorite. It takes almost an hour to get your pizza and its made with several kinds of cheese's and has a crust that you will swear, comes out of a bakery.Pizza Papalis is what I judge all other deep dish pizza by. Pure heaven!  I have to say Peguod's got an extra star from me for their incredible service. Three people "tag teamed" our table. Rushing over food, picking up and dropping off plates and refilling outr water glasses. Their service was exceptional. Got us in and out in a hurry, but we didn't feel rushed in the least. I would say Pequod's is worth a visit, if you want good pizza and Great service!

Burnt cheese on the pizza!!!! My favorite part!!!! This place came very highly recommended by many people and everyone I refer falls in love! The service is always decent and the food never disappoints!!!!! It's a pretty easy place for families , after work, or date. It's not my favorite but if I'm in the area this is my to to spot for pizza. One of a kind and a crowd pleased!

Pizza preferences are usually based on where you're from, so let me start this by saying that I'm from Cincinnati. I like thick-ish pan pizzas with slightly tangy sauce and a chewy, stringy mozzerella topping. I like to eat pizza with my hands, and I like to eat more than one slice (lookin' at you, deep dish). Overall I like a balance of the sauce and cheese that, in my opinion, neither NY style nor Chicago style have a lock on (NY: too much cheese, Chicago: too much sauce).  So Pequod's: great or the greatest?? Lemmie break it down for you:  Sauce: Killer-diller. Not too sweet and not too tart. Cheese: Mozzerella--chewy and delicious. Weirded out initially by the cheese on the crust, but it gives the pizza a nice crunch at the end.  Crust: Oh god so good--this is the mother-of-all pan pizza crusts. Thick, but solid and not incredibly doughy like Chicago deep dish. Crunchy and crusty at the bottom so that you can actually eat a slice with your hands without it bending down.  Sauce-to-cheese ratio: Almost perfect! A little heavy on the sauce, but way closer to my ideal ratio than any other pizza joint in the area.  Toppings: This is the only thing that threw me. The garlic topped pizza was fantastic, but the sausage on the sausage-topped pizza was too chewy for me--almost seemed over-cooked.  Verdict: Sausage-less Pequod's is my true-heart's desire. I can't speak for the in-restaurant service, since I got it delivered.  Pequod's pizza all day, every day, now and forever, amen.

Pequod's ranks up there with Lou Malnatis or Gullivers Pizza when it comes to deep-dish pizza in Chicago.  They've got a thicker, denser, but still light and airy base crust to the pizza compared to the other deep-dish pizza places, but its easy to develop a craving for that unique texture. I've yet to venture outside my usual pepperoni-topped pizza, which comes with a few of the pieces charred to a delicious black.  They also cook the pizza long enough to crisp ("burn") some of the cheese on the edges of the crust.  I find it a delicious, salty, chewy addition to the texture of the pizza.
Definitely in my top 3 pizza joints in the city. Love the deep pan pizza but it's the crust that really makes it so special.
Some of the best pizza I have ever had. The crust is caramelized for a sweet taste. Service was excellent. Too bad they don't offer their pizzas frozen to go.
Better than Giordanos. The crust is pretty heavenly but next time I'll get extra sauce and cheese.  Best deep dish I've had in Chicago thus far.

$5 for a deep dish pizza lunch! Perfect crunch. There was a good amount of sauce and cheese. It is definitely fresh pizza so its a pretty long wait. It was a good 25 minutes before the pizzas came out.
UPDATE! Was told by server they no longer offer a beer with the lunch special. It's a soda only! Whack!!! Thus minus the 1star rating but pizza still gud

Ask your Chicago friends where to eat and they give you the best! Under the recommendation from my brother from another mother, he told us that this place is one of the best pizza places! He was right! It is walking distance to DePaul University (he went there) and about 3 miles from our hotel. We decided to cab it to this pizzeria and walk back to burn off those calories! The restaurant/bar looks small on the outside, but when you get in, it is actually bigger. It is two stories and there is plenty of seating upstairs. We arrived pretty early (round 12) to beat the crowds and there was no wait for us to be seated. This is the "official" Blackhawks bar. My friend says "EVERY bar" is the official Blackhawks bar. Anyway, we got the lunch special (individual pizza and soda) for about $6.00. It was a good deal! Apparently, they used to serve the special with beer, but that stopped due to the new laws. Anyway, we shared a salad which tasted very fresh and helped ease my hunger pains while waiting for the deep dish. Deep dish pizza takes awhile, but it is worth the wait! I got pepperoni and spinach for my deep dish and I am a fan of deep dish. Wow. The sauce is sweet but tangy and the cheese....so much goodness! The small individual pizza looks small, but is fairly big and difficult to finish. The crust is crunchy and a bit thicker than I hoped for, but still very tasty! I did not finish my deep dish because it was just so much (Shame, shame!), but was glad to have it while on the walk back. The staff is friendly and really nice. Our waitress gave good recommendations and told of us other tourist attractions. She was very knowledgeable! The atmosphere is very chill and seems to be frequented by the college audience, since DePaul University is within walking distance.

Pequod's is freaking awesome. My husband and I recently did a "Tour de Deep Dish," and went to all the big deep dish joints in Chicago over a 2 week time course. Here's my side-by-side comparison: 5. Uno's: Medium-density crust. Heavy on the cheese, medium on the sauce. Zesty sauce. Solid salads. 4. Giordano's: The most well-rounded (potentially) of the deep dishes. Medium-density crust. Heavy on the cheese, light on the sauce. Sweet sauce. Great salads--would go light on the dressing. 3. Lou Malnati's: High-density crust, probably the most densely infused with butter. Hard and crispy. Heavy on the cheese, medium on the sauce. Sweet sauce. Solid salads. 2. Pequod's: Light-density, airy crust (as airy as deep dish goes haha). Added bonus (!) acclaimed halo of cheese surrounding the crust. Medium on the cheese, heavy on the sauce. Sweet, savory sauce. Average salads; definitely more options for greens at the other deep dish venues.   1. Gino's east: Medium-density FLAKY, buttery crust. Heavy on the cheese AND sauce. Sweet, zesty sauce. Awesome salads. Definitely love Pequod's, and it would totally be my fave if the Gino's combo didn't strike my fancy so fittingly. I think the attraction in Pequod's is that they dare to be different. Most deep dish places are just a variation on the theme. Pequod's really does have a distinct deep dish that dances to the beat of its own hip drum.

I am only going to give it 4 stars because I feel like I'm having a food baby right now.  Because it was that good.  Very confusing I know I know but it's the way my pepperoni thick crust is going to have to crumble !
With almost 1800 reviews adding more of the same is redundant, this is great pizza. Take it from me, order extra sauce and cheese because the deep dish is pretty doughy.

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago, hands down!  If you want FLAVOR, with great crust, NOT over loaded with cheese, check this place out.  The sauce is awesome not sweet, has a tang...full of flavor; the crust is sturdy and crisp on the bottom, and a soft pillow on top; not too much cheese and the cheese creeps up the the edge and caramelizes -- wow is this fantastic!  Top it with sausage and pepperoni -- yum!
Hands down, BEST pizza in Chicago!! Delivery is fast and efficient as well.

I've been to Pequod's many many times - enough to write a fair review.  I give their deep dish pizza at least 4 to 5 stars because it's hand's down a delicious pizza.  Their crust is amazing (it's a little burnt with a nice carmalized crunch - just the way I love it!).  The host and the service, now that is a different rating all together - I give the service two stars and the host zero stars.  Their pizza is definitely better than Giordano's or Gino's East.  I keep going back because I love the pizza - that is the only reason.  The host is a complete joke.  One time we got there on a Saturday night and gave the host our name for the wait list.  Shortly after, he began seating five groups that arrived after us.  I was very upset because my group only consisted of two people, so I said something and he kept mumbling some ridiculous excuses that didn't make sense.  We waited for an hour and twenty minutes before he sat us.  I no longer go there at nights on the weekends - it's a nightmare to get seated and the service is extremely slow (you will wait for over an hour to be seated).  One time we waited an hour and twenty minutes for our pizza to arrive at our table - of course, it was cold.  It must have been sitting in the kitchen the entire time.  Also, the waitresses seem to be really slow.  I must say that they offer a sensational lunch special for five bucks - which I highly recommend.  As you can see, I have mixed review about this place, but I keep going back because the pizza is my favorite.   I am willing to tolerate the obnoxious host (the skinny guy with glasses) and the slow service just to take a bite of their delicious deep dish pizza!

Yes, you have to wait 40 minutes to get your food. Is it worth it? Absolutely! The crust on this pizza is the most amazing thing that will ever hit your mouth. I am a simple pizza eater so I can only speak on behalf of the cheese and pepperoni pizzas, but i'm sure any other options would be just as amazing. This is my favorite pizza spot in Chicago, and I will continue to talk all of my out of town friends/family to this location to get a true Chicago pizza experience.

I was raised on Home Run Inn and The original Giordano's on South California when it was BYOB. These were my childhood sweethearts. Both were outstanding pizzas in the late 70's but now that I'm older I have  found superior pie.  Lou's and Geno's East are good but this is the place for the best. You forget life for a while while eating this magnificent offering. Well done Pequods

The pizza was so-so. I had a small cheese which was a perfect amount for one person-I had two pieces and had leftovers for lunch the next day. I just felt like in comparison to Lou's or Giordanos-Pequod's just didn't hit the mark. I was excited to try the crust, given all the positive reviews, but it just tasted burnt and was less than satisfying. Side note-I ordered this for delivery and the girl who answered the phone had a bit of an attitude. I generally hate calling places-would much rather order online, but I didn't see an option to do so. I wanted to try this place since it had such good reviews, but the girl on the phone really turned me off.  Other side note-the guy who delivered it was totally cool, and definitely made up for the not-so-good service over the phone! Overall-meh. Not terrible, but wouldn't go out of my way for it.

We were told Pequod's has some of the best deep dish Chicago-style pizza in the whole city. Coming from the East Coast, we were excited to try it. Although the restaurant is known to be packed on the weekends, we easily got a table on a Monday evening. Each additional topping was $2.75, which seemed like a lot considering we only ordered pepperoni and black olive. Pequod's famously uses old cast iron pans that have been blackened over the years, allowing the crust and the cheese to melt together and form a crispy caramelized layer. We learned that "deep-dish" at Pequod's refers to a thick bottom crust, as opposed to "stuffed" deep dish where your chosen topics are incorporated inside the pizza. Pequod's was a great introduction to Chicago-style deep dish.

Pan pizza was amazing, messy and extremely fresh. Regarding the food, I would highly recommend it. Be prepared for a wait, but that's expected with fresh food. However, the service was absolutely terrible. Everyone was very nice, but the table service was beyond slow. And I mean slow. I'm a patient person, but after ordering only 1 pizza and it taking 70 minutes to come and THEN waiting 20 minutes for the check, I almost lost it. I would probably never come back and try a new place.

I moved out of Chicago last week, and based on yelp reviews, I picked this place for my last Chicago meal. It was underwhelming. We got the cheesy bread as an app and a medium deep dish pizza.  The cheesy bread was store bought bread, lots of cheese, with garlic powder on top. A 7 year old could have made this.  The pizza itself was meh. The famous crust was a little too burnt for me, I think the amount of black on the crust was unhealthy. It was good pizza, but nothing at all memorable.  I'm glad I read the reviews that said to get extra cheese, because their regular amount of cheese would not have been proportionate to the overall pizza.  I would give this place 3 stars, but I had to tack a star off for the poor and slow service.
Awesome Chicago deep dish pizza.  I've had Giordano's and Lou's... this place blows them both away.
Not usually a fan of deep dish/ or pizza in general but i liked it.  good treat every once in awhile,  the crust is delish too! service was mediocre.

Meatball, garlic and basil...   The best!!!    Another pizza at the table had sausage and I tried a chunk on our way back to the metro... the big chucks were so good I was tempted to go back and get one to-go...  It takes45 mins to cook but as thick as it is, I understand..   The best pizza I have ever eaten... And I have eaten many!!!   Sauce is not overpowering like many places...  Lots on it, but very mild...

I was drawn to Pequod's because of its $4.95 lunch special. The lunch special is a personal one-topping deep dish pizza and a drink of your choice. What a deal. The pizza is enough for 2 people, and the drink comes with free refills. I ordered the deep dish with giardiniera peppers, and this was the perfect combination of mozzarella cheese baked into the pizza "crust" shell. The peppers and sauce are on top of the pizza, and there was a good ratio of peppers to sauce. The sauce is well-seasoned, and not overly sweet or spicy.  Pequod's is located in a line of businesses on a busy street. There is street parking nearby. The establishment itself is dimly lit, which gives it a bar-like feel. There is a full service bar and flat screen TVs showing sports games above the bar. The space itself is small, but I would recommend it for a meeting with friends as many people were doing or just a solo lunch. The service is fast and friendly, and your pizza arrives in 20 minutes with no wait.

So a friend of mine  that leave in Cali told me about this pizza place that I have never hear before. I decided to yelp it to see pic and reviews and when I saw they had more than a thousand reviews I was like this must be good place. Line was long but totally worth. We ordered a deep dish pepperoni, basil, meatball pizza and also garlic bread since a lot of people said were good. This was my first time there and won't be last one this pizza was just AMAZINGGGGGGGG for me so far best in chicago.

I know this place has great reviews but I didn't like it so much.  Literally waited an hour for the pizza and it was average.  One thing I will say is that the cheese was pretty good but the dough was too thick on the bottom.... Idk I really wanted to like this place a lot but for a really good deep dish go  somewhere else!

I can only speak on Pequod's delivery as I have never actually been to the restaurant. Co-workers and I had a hankering for good Chicago style pizza, so we decided on Pequod's. I called right when they opened at 11am, and ordered two large pan pizzas for the 8 of us. The lady on the phone was less than polite, but it sounded like it was busy in there. Our office was out of the delivery zone but only by a few blocks, so they charged us a buck more and accommodated the order. She said it would be there in about an hour.  I ended up getting a call from the delivery guy an hour an a half later. Bye bye, 5 star rating.  The pizza was delicious. It had had enough time to cool off a bit and was the perfect temperature. Toppings were plentiful and that cheesy caramelized crust really sets it apart from its competitors.  Will definitely order again.

6 years ago I hated deep dish pizza (and yes, I'm am a Chicagoan born and raised), HOWEVER, when my wife brought me to Pequods in 2008 my taste buds experienced a moment of pure ecstasy that only a perfect Chicago deep dish pizza can create!  We had a sausage and spinach deep dish pizza and my mind was blown!  Alas, I have been forever ruined. When I eat regular pizza I think of only Pequods and how I could be experiencing something better. When I'm eating there I never wanna leave. My fat soul has been won over by their incredibly, mind changing recipe and all I wanna do is shout out their amazing-ness from the top of the Sears tower (I refuse to call it the "W" word)!  Anyways, please don't give up on deep dish till you have tried Peqouds... I DARE YOU!!!! Muahhaahaahhaaaaa!!!!!

Peqoud's is hands down the best pizza in the city! We bring all of our friends here, and each and every one of them becomes a fan. The deep dish is amazing, and the caramelized cheese crust takes it to another level.

Being new to Chicago, I was told prior to my move that Giordano's was the place to go for deep dish. Working at a Two Michelin Star Restaurant molecular cooks said that Pequod's is the place to go for a good pizza.  It certainly is, the flavors accent one another in a way that is extraordinary. The caramelized crust makes it unlike anything else you'll find in Chicago. Definitely making the trip to Lincoln Park whenever I'm in the mood for pizza.
If You want Pizza Cake (i.e. deep dish) Then caramelized crust coma it is. Yum.

Yaas, finally some outstanding deep dish!  I had the Pequod salad and the personal pan deep dish with sausage and pepperoni and both were amazing!!!  I live nowhere near this place but I'll drive the 35 min one way to eat it!  Definitely a must if your looking for good deep dish Chicago style pizza!

If you like lots of crust and bread this pizza is for you. I unfortunately love a cheesy pizza that is not 90 percent crust and only 10 percent toppings. I'm bummed out because I have heard great things about their deep dish. Thin crust was ok if I remember correctly but it was several months ago.
Very , very good.  Carmelized crust makes all the difference.  Service was good, had a bigger group and she still did all the proactive service you would think.

Very tasty! Visiting from out of town and given many recommendations of where to get deep dish, but Pequod's was the most recommended from friends. Not disappointed at all. We were told it would be a 20 minute wait, but were seated in less than 15. The appetizer combo was not bad - the jalepeno poppers were the best, so I think I would have just gone with those. Our deep dish was super yummy and surprisingly not too heavy. I've had deep dish before that left me feeling  uncomfortably full, but this deep dish was filling without the gross greasy feeling afterwards. We got mushrooms and fresh garlic toppings that were very fresh and delicious. I'll definitely come back next time I'm in town.

Well. After recommending this place to everyone I know who visits my hometown, I'm thinking my endorsements may have been a mistake. I defend this place A LOT against warnings of insufferable service and bad crowd control. I am willing to cut them a lot of slack for their pizza. It is an attraction for which a bad personality is sometimes forgivable. And I've been coming long enough that I know better than to expect reliable service on a Saturday, or to attempt a table during the NBA playoffs. But on a Tuesday night, in the summer offseason with zero sports, you'd think the expectation of actually getting to eat the pizza you called in 20 minutes prior that was put in 'right away' is reasonable. Yeah? We order at 6:30. We get there after a cross-town trek. We think we're fine, since there's no wait when we called, and the order went in awhile ago. We go to check in amid largely vacant tables... and are told it'll be a 40 minute wait JUST to sit. What? Pequods, I get it. Your justification makes sense, it's just not very good. I work in customer service, and I know there's 'technically' no responsibility for you to update patrons (who already ordered and are headed to your restaurant) that an influx of HUGE parties has added 40 minutes to your previously nonexistent wait, but when you are bitchy about it on arrival, and act like it's unreasonable to be taken by surprise by this development, that's what stops fans from endorsing you. Did you have to call? No. If you had? You would've saved your loyal customers $20 in cab fare, a shitload of traffic, respect, and a wasted pizza. My life isn't your problem, I get that, but there's a courtesy in not springing this on a party for whom you've already told you're cooking food for. That's how you become a restaurant whose patron recommendations start carrying warnings. I've happily put up with the unpredictability on weekends or during sports events, but as a loyal recommender of this place, I'm really disappointed. I don't whine. I just want whoever monitors this to know that it's becoming a reputation people are listening to.  Also, there were a ton of open tables given parties of 40 and 25 were supposedly occupying the bulk of the place, but given everything else I guess I'm not shocked we have a difference in logic.  Pizza's the best in chicago if you can deal with the side of shit. Up to you.
Best pizza I've ever had, well worth the wait. Deep dish, extra sauce and garlic. Amazing!

The best thing about this place is the atmosphere and building design. It's in a unique space that feels somewhat old and slightly bohemian but with LCD tv's. The space is significantly bigger than it seems at first. Each room is unique and has different twists and turns. The lighting is not too bright and not too dim. Now to the topic of greatest concern to any true Chicagoan, the deep dish pizza. First off I'd have to say that pizza is unusual and different from chicago's most famous deep dish places. Toppings were very generous. Ultimately I was not a fan of the crust or the sauce which was sweeter than average. I've wanted to like this place and gone back a couple of times. Wasn't really wowed by anything, but I expect some portion of the population might be into the pizza. We ordered 2 pasta dishes one time and we're not impressed.

I'm not a deep dish fan, but this is probably the best deep-dish I have had to date (I've also been to Giordano's and Lou Malnati's several times since they are closer to where I live).  We got the pepperoni pizza, which was great -- I only had one and a half slices because the wait for a table took quite a bit, and thus I filled up on beer. However, I def wished I could eat more -- the pepperoni was very tasty. We also got the appetizer combo, which consisted of mozzarella sticks, jalapeno poppers, zucchini slices & breaded shrooms -- all very tasty and fried. I stil prefer piece pizza in wicker park, but when I have friends who crave deep dish, this is where I'll go from now on.

"Give it 20 minutes." "It will be out in 20 more minutes" We were given promises from our waitress that the pizzas would be out in twenty minutes, but as a period of twenty minutes passed, we got nothing but another 20-minute promise. After multiple 20-minute promises, we have been sitting for nearly two hours with all our water cups empty, still pizza-less, in the hot AC-less environment.  Our head of the party finally had enough and demanded to speak to the manager. When the manager came, he curtly asked, "Okay, who is going to yell me?" Fortunately, our head of the party was an assertive man and made that manager know that we were angry at the endless wait. The manager went to see the situation and informed us what we have long suspected: our order was forgotten. He apologized to us, demanded our waitress to fill our water cups and send out more appetizers, and promised twenty more minutes. An hour after speaking to the manager, the pan pizzas finally arrived. Admittedly, the pizza was delicious but it was too late at that point because it was not worth the three-hour ordeal.

Service is horrible. Been here for 2 and a half hours and still no pizza. Wait staff and management is of no help. People all around us have gotten their food ahead of us. Manager with ponytail is an asshole. No matter how good the pizza it is not worth this.

After hearing all the hype on Pequod's, I dragged my family there on our last trip to Chicago in lieu of Hot Doug's (can't convince them to line up for hot dogs, no matter how good they are!). What we discovered was a dark dive-lite atmosphere and OK pizza. The hallowed burnt cheese crust was not the umami bomb I was expecting and the toppings were pretty watery (don't order mushrooms!). Not bad but I will stick with Malnati's in future.

I'm not sure why anyone wouldn't give this place 5 stars. Malnati's shouldn't even be mentioned in the same sentence. There is a reason it's 4 stars overall and not 1 or 2 like some peoples' reviews suggest. They're probably bitter or their tastebuds are non -existent.

Average at best.  This was recommended by my roommates as the best pizza in Chicago.   It was good,  but nothing special.   If you put this next to the top pizzas in Chicago you wouldn't even notice it.

This place is nothing special, in fact its pretty sub par. I'm not sure if Pequod's USED to be good and has just lost its touch but I can definitely say this place's pizza is boring. What I ordered: Onion Rings (about 7 of them pathetically displayed on a plate) 12 inch Deep dish pizza with Sausage and Basil The Crust - Spongy cornmeal somewhere in between buttery, crispy and soggy. Not terrible but as far as a foundation for a pie its nothing exciting. The Sauce - If there were any herbs or spices in the sauce, I couldn't taste them. Pizza suffers the most when the sauce is bad and this was just tomato paste and sugar with maybe a sprinkle of pepper. The Cheese - this was the most disappointing part of the whole meal, there was no flavor and no salt. My professional guess is that they use a cheap skim milk mozzarella, no provolone or whole milk. It reminded me of peal and eat mozzarella sticks from a gas station, but that would be insulting cause at least those are loaded with sodium. The Toppings - the second worst part about this pizza, it was adorned with about 10 pieces of sausage the size of golf balls and what was probably 3 leaves of furiously fine shredded basil. The sausage was actually pretty good but there wasn't nearly enough of it, about 2 pieces a piece. And the basil, I'm not sure they even put any on it.

I moved to Chicago from Canada a few months ago and a lot of my friends have been visiting the last couple months (the summer months... not the winter months, they don't even know my name during the winter months). Whenever one of them visits, they request 'the best deep dish' in Chicago.  I've tried about 15 different pizza places since i've been here and although a lot are close, and ALWAYS delicious; Uno, Lou Malnati's, Giordano's, I have to say, they all lose their shit over Pequod's. The toppings are plentiful and always taste fresh, the tomato sauce is signature and their crust is unlike anything i've had, it's caramelized and impossible not to finish (I usually never finish the crust). * During Peak hours, there's about an hour wait, The Drinking Bird next door to Pequod's has great cocktails!
Lackluster pizza flavor.  There are so many better chicago style pizza places; try another one. Even touristy genos east is a better option.

I haven't had Lou Manalti's, but I figured I would give this place a try first because it is harder to get to for me.  Disclaimer: I don't usually like deep dish pizza, and if I had a choice, I would go for NY style any day. This deep dish was different than those I had before. There's actually very little tomato sauce and the toppings lie on top (compared to ones I've had before which were filled with a tomato sauce / topping mixture). What I really like is the caramelized cheese edges, so crispy! I also like that despite all the wet toppings on top, the bread on the bottom below the cheese remained completely dry! Not soggy at all! I think that's a huge feat to accomplish. For these two things alone, I give this place 4 stars.  Also, the slices are huge! I shared a small pizza ( 4 slices) with one other person, and was pretty satisfied after just 1 slice. I continued to stuff my face, and ate another 1/2 of a slice. Yum!

These guys do deep dish right! I got the personal size pizza with pepperoni and olives. After I ordered, I feared they would overdo it with the olives like some places, but they keep the olives to a moderate amount. The crust! It was amazing. The carmelized cheese was delicious and the pizza in general was solid.
My favorite pizza! :)

We called ahead to order deep dish pizza since it usually takes about 45 minutes to make. They typically cook it for 20-25 min before you come and then finish cooking it when you get there. We arrived at about 610 and were planning on seeing a movie next door at 715. We didn't get our pizza until 715 which meant they did not cook it before we got there. We clearly missed our movie. Moreover, our waitress was incredibly rude and avoided us knowing that we were getting inpatient. Lastly, we accidentally left our leftovers at the table and came back within 2 minutes;  the waitress said they had thrown it out already. Why did the quick service suddenly appear when we left?

As a Chicagoan, I was seriously missing out what Pequod's has to offer when it comes to Chicago Deep Dish Pizza! Came here for a date during Blackhawks season (not sure if that was a good idea) and they happen to be playing at the same time (Go Hawks!) This place was a serious deep dish pizza spot mixed with a sports bar. If you lived in Chicago, you probably have had Lou Malnati's Pizzeria and Giordano's Pizza which are both GREAT traditional Chicago deep dish pizza however Pequod's Pizza takes it to another level with a caramelized deep dish pizza crust. Do NOT let that crust scare you. The burnt cheese caramelized crust is amazing! Let's not forget about the rest of the pizza! They build their deep dish pizza just as good as Lou Malnati's Pizza and Giordano's Pizza. A small deep dish pizza comes out to be 4 slices of heaven and just right for two people. Throw down on some local beer and your meal will be perfect! The original location is in Morton Grove which still exist today. It is also a smaller place but not as busy as the Chicago location. Wait times at the Chicago location can get up to 2 hours specially when there is a game playing. They do not take reservations but BEST TIP is to call ahead and put your name on the waiting list. The service was great and they were on top of everything even when they were busy with a wait at 2+ hours. Great vibe in the place especially when there is a game on. You cannot even tell they had a fire in the place at one point (January 2006) which they shut down for six months to rebuild. Be glad they did rebuild because it is amazing pizza that would be missed. I would bring everyone here including folks from out of town (which I have!) Small groups might be good but large groups might be difficult. It might be a little rowdy to come here on a date during a game but it would be worth it if they are into Chicago teams. Impress them by calling ahead and passing up the line when you get there! If you had to wait, it is totally worth it. And if you cared, the Hawks won the same night it was my first time I had Pequod's Pizza! Food - 5 Décor - 5 Service - 5

I'm with Jannice C.  Just not getting it.  I'd say 2.5 if I could.  Not worth rounding up though.  Not on par with Lou's, Gino's East, Giordano's --- just not.  I expected more from the crust...which looked great and sounded stellar per reviews...but it disappointed in person.  Kind of a solid vibe to the place, friendly service to boot---but not a fan of the product.

What the? I'm not exactly sure what all the hype is about.  SERIOUSLY.  I went here a couple of years ago and didn't like it,  but decided it give it a second chance tonight with my cousin from out of town. ..Holy overrated!  First of all, our waitress was wack...I mean,  she could've just been having a bad day so whatever. Secondly, the menu is outdated and they really should invest in a drink menu or drink specials. The food?  No bueno. The burnt crust aka 'caramelized' crust on the 'deep dish' that everyone raves about was just awful. The pizza was bland and the sausage was gross. I mean, honestly I don't understand all of these elite reviews,  are we eating at the same place?! I love pizza, I really do & I guess you should give it a chance...I guess. Will I be going back?  Negative.

Great pizza! There is usually a wait, but totally worth it - place an order ahead. Good brews on tap, good ambiance - fun, homey and inviting.  Extremely flavorful pizza, great atmosphere and great drinks and very filling. Order the sausage & pep with green bell pepper and onions and you will not be disappointed. Yes a small is sufficient for 2 people, though I wish I could eat more in one sitting.  Highly recommend!

Gets busy and the pan pizzas take time so plan ahead. I like the option to do toppings to just half of the pizza to get variety. We opted for Canadian bacon and pineapple on one side, and pepperoni and green peppers on the other side. The crust is Carmelized and so so good. We ordered a medium which was 6 huge slices. It was way too much. I'd like to come back and try the thin crust. That looked good also. Service was friendly.

Best deep dish in Chicago. Recommend the sausage & jalapeño. Thick deep dish with burnt cheese crust. Nothing compares to a Pequods pie, unlike any other pizza I've ever tried.  Take out frequently from here. However, if you prefer to dine in it's a hip & swanky atmosphere. Great selections of brews.

Cheese crusted deep dish. Bam. My first ever legit deep dish chicago style pizza in the city of chicago. I can't compare it to any other "best chicago style pizza" joints since I didn't have time to check those out but my foodie local friend took us here because, "once you have cheese crusted deep dish why would you ever go back?" to lighten it up, i got only veggies on mine and it was nothing short of blissful heavenly pizza. my husband had the meat heavy topping and he enjoyed both styles.  con: the immensely long wait. we sat down and waited for an eternity (maybe 45 min?) to get our pizza. but, it was also during the nhl play offs so the place was packed (chicago vs la) so perhaps it was just due to overcapacity. great, now i'm dreaming of this place.

One of my all-time favorite pizza places ever!  This is by far the best deep dish pizza in Chicago!  I've tried so many different deep dish pizzas around town and all others just seem mediocre.  Once I tried Pequod's there was no going back!  I only let myself eat Pequods on special occasions, like after a triathlon or something, otherwise I would eat it ALL THE TIME!  It's the thing I look forward to the most after a race, because then I can eat all the pizza I want!  Hands down, best pizza in Chicago!

we came here to watch the world cup game and made reservations ahead of time just in case.  when we arrived they weren't too busy and we were immediately seated. we ordered some cheesy garlic bread to start and then a medium pizza.  we really struggled to finish our pizza since it was so filling.  most of it was bread and it was too dense.  i usually only eat the toppings anyways, but i'm guessing people would be disappointed since most of the pizza was bread.  i was hoping for more cheese and even the caramelized cheese on the crust was not very good.

Color me saddened. Color me disappointed. Color this place overrated.  I'm not going to argue with the Yelpers that have crowned this pizzeria. Everyone has their personal choice for pizza and suggesting what's best can be very personal. That said this pizza, for myself and 3 others, was wildly average.  The thin crust is not worth your time to even consider. The crust is dry, insulted with excess cornmeal, and the sauce must have pulled a Houdini (disappearing act).  Really, really poor.   The deep dish does not measure to others in the city. Aficionados will quickly distinguish that a wait time of 45 minutes demands excellence - - this does not meet such a metric. As an aside, our dish took nearly 1:45 to create.  No bueno.   Service was actually awful, but I will chalk that up to a busy night. Otherwise, this rating would have received two stars.  I recommend another choice... especially if from out of town and this is your one shot at a Chicago deep dish.

In a nutshell: Chicago deep dish in Wicker Park. Came here with family, as it was highly recommended and we were driving through the area. Pequod's is located caddy corner to a fairly new shopping center, with a movie theatre, Barnes and Nobles, etc. Parking 3/5 Fairly easy. Found street parking a couple blocks down. There is lot parking across the street, but we didn't want to have to pay. Ambience 3/5 The place essentially looks like a long sports bar ( yelp.com/biz_photos/pequ… ). Bar on the left as you walk in, and most or all of the tables are stool height. Restrooms are in the back across from the kitchen and are pretty clean for a sports bar. Service 4.5/5 Actually really good. This earned them the fourth star for me. Our server was really nice, and checked in with us pretty regularly. There was a mix up with our order (I'll get to that later), but she fixed it by giving us half off our food bill. She didn't have too, but the fact that she did was pretty awesome of her. Wait time 1/5 Seating - B Waited about 20 minutes for seats. Not bad Drinks - A Ordered a pitcher of 312 of the menu ( yelp.com/biz_photos/pequ… ) and this came out quick. Food - F Expect to wait longer for deep dish, but this time there was a mix up with our order. The tables around us all got their food before us. We ended up not getting our food for almost an hour and a half. By the time it showed up we were hungry and grumpy. However, we were not as grumpy as we could have been, as the server told us beforehand that she would take half off the price of food for us. Food 4/5 Jalapeno poppers - 3/5 They didn't suck and they tied us over.....kind of. Large Pepperoni Sausage and Onion ( yelp.com/biz_photos/pequ… ) - A Bomb. Very comparable to Lou Malnati's. I'm a huge fan of deep dish, since I don't eat it very often. I'm not a big fan of pepperoni in general (shame on me), but everyone else wanted it. Small Sausage Mushroom and Basil ( yelp.com/biz_photos/pequ… ) - A- Very tasty but the crust was a bit burnt. Not enough to make it a crappy meal, but then again we had been waiting for over an hour for this.  Overall 4/5 Food was good, and the service staff did an amazing job trying to make us happy despite of the mix up in the kitchen. Sometimes $h!t happens, but it's all about how they react to it that sets them above other restaurants. Happy with the experience, and I would definitely come back here.

This review is based solely on the food. The service here was great. Our friend took us to Pequad's as the place to go to for Chicago deep dish pizza while we were in town visiting. While the pizza was very good it didn't really make me a fan of deep dish pizza. I've had similar pizzas to this outside of Chicago. During our visit there was a great debate between whether to go to Pequod's or Lou Malnati's. We ended up settling on Pequod's and I think it was a mistake. Basically I think Pequod's is for people who like sloppy greasy pizza. If that is your thing then I bet you will think Pequod's is one of the best. For my tastes I think Lou Malnati's classic would have been more up my alley. Maybe next time.

Can't get enough of this place. Even though I'm a Chicagoan at heart I have never been a deep dish girl. This place has managed to make me have a change of heart. Super delish not to mention their lunch special is awesome!
Best Thick Pizza Up North. That Burnt Crust is Flame-O. Those Fries are the Best!!!  The Cheesy Garlic Bread is amazing and the salads are great to make you think that you are eating healthy. LoL.

I finally had a chance to try Pequod's by the DePaul campus. How can you beat $4.95 for a personal pepperoni pan pizza and a drink? The verdict? In the battle of the deep dish pizza.....Lou Malnati's wins by a landslide. I didn't enjoy the crust at Pequod's and the sauce was a little too strong. My soda was also very watered down. The best part of the meal was the cheesy garlic bread. It was so tasty I would consider coming back and just ordering that.

Love the pizza. Seriously. Delicious. Customer service though? Woof. Twice now they've disappointed hard when I showed up with friends (lost reservations, rude host and waitstaff). I usually recommend everyone come here when they visit Chicago, but I'm not sure that's going to happen any more. May be time to explore new deep dish options!
Best deep dish pizza I've ever tried. This was my first experience with Chicago deep dish ... Damn good!  Was a long wait but well worth it.

Stop reading this review and order this pizza right now! I seriously crave and miss this pizza every day. The lunch special is amazing! You get a personal size pizza with one topping and a drink for $4.95 (or at least what I remembered)!! If they could deliver this to Ohio, I would order it weekly by the pallet. The burnt caramelized crust makes the dough so sweet and savory.. Now my mouth is watering thinking about it. What I love most about this place is that it's not a chain and it's one of a kinda. Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to a slice of Pequod's heaven!!

I am updating my review of Pequod's thanks to their great manager, Sean, who reached out to me after reading about my less-than-awesome customer service experience.  He was kind enough to take the time to address my concerns and so I gave the restaurant another go.  I am never disappointed with the pizza when we go here, so I appreciate the effort to make the entire experience positive.  Thank you!

Extremely well seasoned cast iron. Gooey high quality cheese fantastic sauce and stellar toppings all make for an extremely enjoyable pizza. What separates their pizza from the rest is the caramelized crown that surrounds the edge of the pizza. NOTHING compliments pizza crust like caramelized cheese!!! Must go

I''m not really sure what the fuss is about.  The pizza wasn't anything special and there was an hour wait for our reservation (that they lost).  This place is so busy it will give even those with the calmest demeanor an anxiety attack.   I just don't get it.  I just don't.

Yelp reviews turned me on to this place and by golly, this place is the real deal for Chicago deep dish. I love pizza and there are many different styles of pizza: NY Pizza, Chicago deep dish, Sicilian style Sfinguni (not sure about spelling), and they are all good. But, for all those places out there that claim to have Chicago style deep dish pizza, come here and be humbled. Is there better out there? Maybe, but I have yet to find it. I am sure if I go to more places in the Windy City I'll find other places that compare but Chicago is a BIG city! In the mean time, I will continue to stop here whenever I visit Chicago until they disappoint me, twice (I always figure everyone has one bad day).

THE MOST OVERRATED PIZZA IN CHICAGO! Wow, I really wanted to like this pizza after all the hype but it was a great disappointment. I am a lover of ALL pizza but especially deep dish. I just don't get the praise especially for the burnt cheese crust - it just tasted bad. Pequods wouldn't even make my top 50 list seriously. Other pizzas nearby are sooooo much better like Art of Pizza. and nearly all others. I do understand how tough the restaurant business can be. Maybe they had an off night? I am very hesitant but maybe some day I will give it one more try, but then again, maybe not.

My fellow New Yorkers know - Chicago deep-dish pizza ain't pizza. The dense vessel of bread augmented with a vertical growth of irrelevant toppings and something like an inch of cheese is more like pie, or bad lasagna... or some other obscene thing characterized by gross excessiveness rather than a relationship to that majestic food form we call pizza. That said, Pequod's serves up a damn delicious deep dish "pizza" (yes, you still need a fork to eat it). The difference between Pequod's and the other, very overrated Chicago deep-dish heavyweights is that Pequod's lines the cast-iron pan with cheese before baking the pizza. The result is a beautifully blackened edge of, yep, fried cheese - that holds the pizza together instead of becoming soggy after a minute and breaking off from the rest of the pie. The crust is also slightly thinner than the refined carb parties of Lou Malnati's or Giordano's, both of whom have totally mediocre deep-dish due to a dry monster crust of solid bread and an avalanche of cheese and too-sweet sauce that slides off the second you lift your slice out of the pan. Our medium "pan pizza" (as they call it) with jalapenos and mushrooms cost $20 and was ready for pickup in 30 minutes. The restaurant looks like a regular old Chicago bar: low-key, dirty worn wooden floors, maybe you'd see lots of daisy dukes if it had been warm enough. It was totally empty on a Wednesday at 10:30pm, though they're open conveniently til 2am. Call ahead to place an order even if eating in, since the pizza takes a half hour to cook either way. The first deep dish I've actually liked as food and not spectacle! Mmm.

Can't believe I never wrote a review since I love this place. Their deep dish pizza is amazing! Their lunch specials is that too. Not sure if they still do it but Monday-Friday from 10:30AM - 3-PM you can get a small deep dish with your choice of toppings (for like $1 extra if you choose 3 or more but that's including meats). I ordered their medium sized deep dish before and it was huge! I only finished 2 slices and I was full. It took me like 2 days to finish it. This is coming from someone who has a ridiculous appetite and can probably compete in those food contest. Check this place out if you love pizza. It is kinda pricey but that's because of all the ingredients they put into their pizza. Oh, the wait is really long. So if you're an impatient eater like me sometimes, you'll definitely wanna take that anger out on the pizza.

Am I the only one that doesn't like this place?  It was SO overrated!  The pizza was very average and nothing special, especially for the prices.  But, the worst part was definitely the sound of crashing plates coming from the kitchen....I felt like I was at a concert.  I couldn't even hear the people at my table! As a side note, the priority seating list completely failed.  We still had to wait 30 minutes for our table.  Even though we pre-ordered our pizza, it still took another 20+ minutes! Chicago is a GREAT pizza city, but this place is definiely not at the top of the list.

Our daughters swear this is the best pizza. It is very very good. Service is very good. Street parking is difficult. The decor is Chicago bar / pizza place. Price point is just fine. Definitely not heart healthy, but I recommend if you are in the area.

Maybe I was expecting a lot. I was in Chicago for a few days and I really wanted to try their famous deep dish pizza. Given the high reviews, I thought this would make an excellent first experience.  Thinking this place might be busy, I had called this place to make a reservation. When I arrived and told them of my reservation, I was asked to wait for almost half an hour despite there being open tables. They were however very busy so I let this one slide. I was told the pizza would take a while to cook so I ordered some appetizers while we waited. I ordered the appetizer combo which consisted of mozzarella sticks, jalepeno poppers, breaded mushrooms, and something else that I dont even remember. Why dont i remember? because they all tasted the same. They were all just breaded up in some bread crumbs and deep fried and tastes more like something from the frozen foods aisle of a grocery store than a restaurant. Even the presentation sucked. But I let this one slide as well. This is a pizza place after all, and I should let pizza be the judge of this place.  So the pizza came and it looked great. After a few bites, I must say that it was okay. I really really tried to like it, but it tasted okay. The "carmelized crust" was more like burnt crust. Unlike a normal deep dish where it is comprised mostly of cheese and toppings with a thin crust, here the pan pizza had a very thick crust and a very thin topping. I felt like I was eating a pizza bagel. After this experience, I almost believed that I just didnt like chicago pizza. Thank god I went to Lou Malnati's two days later and had some real deep dish. It was delicious!

This is by far...The. Best. Pizza. In. Chicago.  I was going to say, "in the world", but I don't want to over-sell.  Granted, I only lived in Chicago for 4 precious, wonderful, joyful years, but I had the opportunity to eat a lot of pizza, including the more "trendy" ones.  You know which ones I'm talking about.  This pizzeria blows all the rest away.  The caramelized crust...Oh-Mylanta!  The only downside is that it's SORT OF off the beaten path.  So the nearest El stop is 0.8 miles away.  No bus that I know of goes near their either.  My recommendation: get off the red/brown line stop at Fullerton and just enjoy a nice walk there and back...it'll help burn off the calories you are sure to accumulate from stuffing your face full of delicious pizza!  Just trust me.  GO NOW! Oh, I forgot to mention the whole "Is this really deep-dish pizza?" question.  Now, I am a fan of deep-dish pizza, BUT it can get a little overwhelming.  Pequod's airs on the side of a "conservative deep-dish", so you aren't going to get a pizza that is quite as pie-like as the other guys.  I appreciate this.  You may not.  But I just wanted to throw that out there so there are no surprises!
Gotta love the caramelized crust!

Definitely a tasty deep dish spot. I wasn't thrilled with the service - it felt like it took us forever to get drinks, and then forever again to order. Once we actually got our food they were pretty attentive, though. Somewhat limited drink selection, but it's definitely worth a try!

Pequod's is, by far, my favorite deep dish pizza place in Chicago. Now...I know that this is a rather sensitive topic...given there are some hard-core Giordano's and Lou's supporters out here. But let me just say, I'm reviewing from the point of view of an "outsider" (Cali-girl) and that I actually prefer thin crust over deep dish. But I've come to really be able to appreciate a good deep dish pizza, and Pequod's is where it's at! I particularly love the carmelized crispy crust. My fav.
